questions.text: A 50-year-old man who has been on dialysis for 2 years presents with bone pain and bowing of legs. Further evaluation reveals hyperparathyroidism and hyperphosphatemia. What is the initial treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of secondary hyperparathyroidism (HPT) and hyperphosphatemia in a patient with CKD. Sevelamer is the best initial treatment for this patient. It is a phosphate binder that reduces the absorption of phosphate from the gastrointestinal tract.

Other phosphate binders that can be used include:

  • Calcium containing
    • Calcium acetate
    • Calcium carbonate
  • Non-calcium containing
    • Sevelamer
    • Lanthanum

Calcitriol and cinacalcet are used to decrease PTH levels in secondary hyperparathyroidism. However, they also cause increased serum phosphate levels. Hence, they should not be given as initial treatment in patients with hyperphosphatemia.

Bisphosphonates like pamidronate are used in the treatment of primary hyperparathyroidism.

World Kidney Day is a global health event celebrated annually on the 2nd Thursday in March since 2006. This year, on March 14, the theme is "Kidney Health for All: Advancing equitable access to care and optimal medication practice." The focus is on overcoming barriers like gaps in early diagnosis, limited healthcare coverage, low awareness among healthcare workers, and challenges in medication accessibility and cost. The goal is to promote awareness about the vital role of kidneys and address issues to ensure optimal kidney care worldwide.

questions.text: Identify the heart chamber marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above CT image is the left ventricle. 

Transverse CT images are to be observed from the foot end of the supine patient, as if we are sitting at the patient's feet. So the right-hand side of the observer corresponds to the left-hand side in the CT.

questions.text: While performing a PET-CT scan, uptake in which of the following areas is likely to be a false positive?
questions.solution:
On 18F-FDG PET-CT scan, the urinary bladder shows normal physiological uptake and is a potential source of false-positive in oncologic imaging. 

The following are areas of normal physiological uptake on PET CT:

  • Brain tissue
  • Skeletal muscle, especially after strenuous activity and laryngeal muscles following speech
  • Myocardium
  • Gastrointestinal tract - intestinal wall
  • Genitourinary tract - as FDG is excreted via the renal system and passes into the collecting systems
  • Brown fat - FDG accumulates here as glucose and ATP are required for heat production
  • Thymus
  • Bone marrow

The following image shows supraclavicular uptake on a PET scan, due to the presence of brown adipose tissue.

questions.text: A patient presented with a deformity as shown in the image below. What is this deformity known as?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the midline of the dorsum of the nose from the frontonasal angle to the tip is curved in a C- or S-shaped manner which is known as crooked nose deformity.

 

Option B: Deviated nose - midline is straight but deviated to one side.

Option C: Hump nose is due to excess of bony or cartilaginous dorsum.

Option D: Saddle nose is depressed nasal dorsum.

questions.text: A 43-year-old multiparous woman presented with menorrhagia and secondary dysmenorrhea. On examination, Halban's sign was positive. The transvaginal USG findings are given below. Which of the following is the definitive treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) showing the Venetian blind appearance is suggestive of adenomyosis. The definitive treatment for adenomyosis is hysterectomy.

Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of the endometrium directly into the myometrium. Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical assessment. Painful, symmetrical enlargement of the uterus is suggestive of adenomyosis. On bimanual examination, the uterus is softened and tender. This is known as Halban's sign. 

TVS findings include salt and pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of subendometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance. MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.

The image below is of a sagittal MRI showing a uterus with adenomyosis in the posterior wall. Gross enlargement of the posterior wall is noted, with many foci of hyperintensity.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first-line imaging investigation done in a child presenting with an episode of UTI?
questions.solution:
In a child presenting with an episode of urinary tract infection (UTI), initial imaging should be ultrasonography of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.

A voiding cystourethrogram is indicated only if the ultrasound study is abnormal, the patient has atypical features or after a recurrent febrile UTI.

DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan may be done after 4–6 months of acute infection as it may help to locate and delineate the scarring

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was found to have excessive urinary glucose levels. However, her blood glucose levels were normal. Further investigations revealed high levels of only L-xylulose in the urine. A genetic defect in which of the following pathways is most likely?
questions.solution:
High levels of L-xylulose in urine point to a diagnosis of essential pentosuria. It is a benign condition caused due to a defect in the uronic acid pathway.

Essential pentosuria has no clinical consequences. However, it can give false-positive results when urinary glucose is measured using alkaline copper reagents (Benedict’s test).

The lack of enzyme xylulose reductase of the uronic acid pathway leads to essential Pentosuria. Affected individuals excrete large amounts of L-xylulose in urine. Xylulose being a reducing sugar gives Benedict's test positive. Bial's test is positive as xylulose is a pentose.

Essential pentosuria is a part of Garrod's tetrad which includes :

  • Pentosuria
  • Albinism
  • Cystinuria
  • Alkaptonuria

Related Pearl: Essential Pentosuria

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with right-sided ear discharge, itching and pain for the past 4 days. He gives a history of insect entry into the external auditory canal which he removed himself. On examination, there is purulent discharge in a narrow canal and the tympanic membrane is normal. Which of the following is the most effective single treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of diffuse otitis externa following a trauma. Aural toilet remains the most effective single treatment for this condition.

All exudate and debris should be carefully removed, with special emphasis on the anteroinferior meatal recess, which forms a blind pocket and acts as a reservoir of infective secretion. The aural toilet can be done by dry mopping, suction clearance, or irrigating the canal with warm, sterile normal saline.

Further treatment modalities:

  • After the aural toilet is done, wicks medicated with antibiotic-steroid preparation can be used. These wicks have to be changed daily for 2 to 3 days, which thereafter can be substituted by ear drops.
  • Broad-spectrum systemic antibiotics are used when there is cellulitis and acute tender lymphadenitis.
  • Analgesics are usually a part of management, as otitis externa is associated with severe pain.
  • Gauze wick soaked in 10% ichthammol glycerine is used to reduce swelling.
  • Astringents such as aluminum acetate (8%) or silver nitrate (3%) are used to dry up an oozing meatus.

questions.text: A patient presents with a loss of extension of the knee joint. On examination, decreased sensation over the anterior aspect of the thigh is noted. Which of the following nerve is likely damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
Loss of extension of the knee joint with decreased sensation over the anterior aspect of the thigh suggests damage to the femoral nerve.

The femoral nerve innervates the quadriceps femoris muscles which are the extensors of the knee joint. It provides sensory branches to the anterior and medial aspect of the thigh by medial and intermediate cutaneous nerves of the thigh.

The image given below shows the course of the femoral nerve.

The quadriceps femoris muscle translates to “four-headed muscle” from Latin. These muscles differ in their origin but share a common quadriceps femoris tendon which inserts into the patella.

questions.text: A pregnant teacher presented with complaints of difficulty concentrating at work. Investigations revealed normal MCV with blood picture as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario presence of microcytic hypochromic RBCs indicates iron deficiency anemia, and hyper segmented neutrophils indicate anemia due to folic acid or vitamin B12 deficiency. This is also known as dimorphic anemia.

Blood picture in iron deficiency anemia:

  • Microcytic hypochromic RBCs
  • Typical photo pencil cells
  • Presence of poikilocytes (pre-erythrocytes)

Blood picture in folic acid/vitamin B12 deficiency anemia:

  • Hyper segmented neutrophils - earliest change
  • Macrocytic RBCs

questions.text: A patient with leprosy, who has completed a course of multi-drug therapy, presents with complaints of developing painful, tender, and raised lesions on his forehead recently as shown in the image below. What is the first-line treatment for him?

choices.text: Restart multi drug therapy and start thalidomide
Restart multi drug therapy and start prednisolone

questions.solution:
The presence of new erythematous and tender subcutaneous nodules in a patient with leprosy indicates that he has developed type II lepra reaction. It is also known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) and the first line of treatment is prednisolone.

Multi-drug therapy (MDT) should not be restarted in patients who develop lepra reactions after the completion of treatment.

Prednisolone is started at a dose of 40 mg per day and gradually tapered by 5 mg every 2 weeks. 'Prednisolone card' is given when treatment is started. If the patient becomes steroid-dependent, then clofazimine is added.

The  key targets of the Global Leprosy Strategy 2021-2023 announced by WHO (Accelerating towards a leprosy-free world) are:

  • 120 countries reporting zero new autochthonous cases.
  • 70% reduction in the annual number of new cases detected.
  • 90% reduction in rate per million population of new cases with Grade 2 disability.
  • 90% reduction in rate per million children of new child cases with leprosy.

The current goal is the elimination of leprosy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding amoebic liver abscess is false?

choices.text: Culture of the aspirate is positive.
The diagnosis is based on the detection of antiamebic antibodies.
Management mainly consists of conservative treatment with metronidazole.

questions.solution:
The culture of the amoebic abscess is usually sterile or negative.

The most useful laboratory evaluation is the measurement of cir­culating anti-amoebic antibodies, by enzyme immunoassay. The antibody can be present because of prior infection, and hence, detection of Entamoeba histolytica lectin antigen in the serum and liver abscess pus is more useful for acute infections than chronic infection.

Nuclear medicine studies, such as gallium scanning or technetium (99mTc)  liver scans, can be helpful in differentiating pyogenic from amebic abscesses because amebic abscesses typically do not contain leukocytes and therefore do not light up on these scans.

The mainstay of treatment for amebic abscesses is metronidazole (750 mg orally, three times daily for 10 days), which is curative. Luminal agents such as iodoquinol, paromomycin, and diloxanide furoate can be administered into the cysts.

Related Pearl: Difference between pyogenic and amebic liver abscess

questions.text: You are performing an ultrasound abdomen and notice the below finding. Which of the following conditions is it associated with?
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound abdomen depicts the target sign suggestive of intussusception.

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. Clinically, it presents with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, and passage of red currant jelly stools.

A plain radiograph may show a meniscus sign, i.e. soft tissue mass contrasting the bowel that is air-filled. The target sign of intestinal intussusception, also known as the doughnut sign or bull's eye sign, is a diagnostic feature observed on abdominal ultrasound. This appearance is due to concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by the mucosa and muscularis, and the hypoechoic bands are formed by the submucosa.

Other ultrasound signs of intussusception include:

  • Pseudokidney sign - This is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel. The edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma, and the mesentery, which is dragged into the intussusception, resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign - A hyperechoic semilunar structure caused by mesenteric fat pulled into the intussceptum.

The below images show USG films depicting the target sign and pseudo-kidney sign respectively.

questions.text: Pinky, a high school girl, has difficulty in combing her hair and climbing up stairs since 6 months. On examination, Gower sign is positive and maculopapular rash present over MCP joints. What is the next appropriate investigation to be done?
questions.solution:
A maculopapular rash over the metacarpophalangeal joints is indicative of Gottron papules in a child with proximal muscle weakness is suggestive of juvenile dermatomyositis. As it is an inflammatory myopathy, the next investigation is serum creatine kinase.

Though the gold standard investigation is a muscle biopsy, it is indicated only when the diagnosis is in doubt or when grading of the disease severity is required. Nerve conduction studies are usually normal unless associated with severe muscle necrosis and atrophy. Electromyography would show the characteristic signs of myopathy and muscle fiber necrosis but is preferably performed in a specialized center.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with diarrhea, bloody stools, weight loss, and intermittent fever for the past 2 months. Endoscopy revealed the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation along with the endoscopy image showing a cobblestone appearance are suggestive of Crohn's disease (CD).

Endoscopic findings in Crohn's disease include:

  • Aphthous ulcers - small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers - linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance - deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures 
  • Fistulas

Strictures and fistulae are the commonly associated complications of long-standing Crohn's disease.

questions.text: You have to give 180 mg of ceftriaxone to a patient in a 2 ml syringe that has 10 divisions per ml. The concentration of the drug in the vial is 500 mg/5 ml. How many divisions should be filled in 2 ml of the syringe to give 180 mg?
questions.solution:
The 2ml syringe should be filled up to 18 divisions to deliver 180 mg ceftriaxone to the patient. 

Concentration of ceftriaxone in the vial is: 500mg/5ml = 100mg/1mL.

Since 100mg is present in 1 mL, we can calculate the volume required for 180mg:   180mg ÷ 100mg/1 mL = 1.8 mL. Thus, we need to draw 1.8 mL of solution into the syringe.

The given 2 mL syringe has 10 divisions per mL. Therefore, the total number of divisions in 2 mL is 20 divisions. Since 1 mL = 10 divisions, the required 1.8mL corresponds to: 

1.8mL x 10 divisions/ mL = 18 divisions. Hence, to administer 180 mg of ceftriaxone, the syringe should be filled up to 18 divisions.

questions.text: A newborn is admitted to the NICU with the following teratoma. Which embryonic layers is this derived from?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an oropharygeal teratoma, which contains derivatives from all three germ layers.

The tumor may include gut, bone, skin, and teeth. These tumors arise from pluripotent stem cells that differentiate into any of three germ layers forming tissues of all three germ layers.

questions.text: A normal anion gap metabolic acidosis occurs in patients with_____
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea is a cause of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis produced as a result of increased HCO3- loss in feces.

This is because a decrease in HCO3- is replaced by an increase in the concentration of Cl-.  This is a measurable anion and hence the anion gap is normal.

Extra - edge : Siggard-Anderson curve normogram is used to plot the acid-base composition of the blood 

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

questions.text: What is the maneuver depicted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Trotter’s method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to control epistaxis.

Other options:

Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).

Option C: McGovern’s technique is used in choanal atresia. A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway.

Option D: Valsalva maneuver is performed by forceful attempted exhalation against a closed nose and mouth. It is used as a test of cardiac function and autonomic nervous control of the heart, or to clear the ears and sinuses.

questions.text: A patient was prescribed an antipsychotic drug following which he developed parkinsonism. Which of the following drugs​ can be given?
questions.solution:
Trihexyphenidyl is the drug of choice for drug-induced parkinsonism. It is a central anticholinergic.

Drug-induced parkinsonism is a condition caused by certain drugs having D2 antagonistic action (typical antipsychotics). The decrease in dopaminergic activity results in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Anticholinergics act by restoring the balance.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is to be avoided in a hypertensive patient?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is avoided in a hypertensive patient as it has intrinsic sympathomimetic properties and hence can aggravate hypertension.

Ketamine increases arterial blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output. This is due to central stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system and inhibition of the reuptake of norepinephrine. And hence it should be cautiously used in patients with uncontrolled hypertension, coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure and arterial aneurysms.

Its stimulatory effects may be beneficial to patients with acute shock. All other intravenous induction agents like propofol, thiopentone and etomidate produce a fall in blood pressure.

questions.text: Individuals with fluoride intake above which of the following are at risk of developing crippling fluorosis?
questions.solution:
Individuals with fluoride intake > 10 mg/L are at risk of developing crippling fluorosis.

Complications of fluorosis seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake are:

  • Dental fluorosis - 1.5 mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis - 3-6 mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis - > 10 mg/L

Genu valgum may occur in people who consume jowar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

The Nalgonda technique is used for the defluoridation of water bodies. It involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

questions.text: A woman complains that her 5-year old child has become very indifferent towards her. He attempts to squeeze his genitals and is always stuffing his mouth with food and objects like knives and toys.  Which of these syndromes could her child be suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 5-year boy who mouths non-food items (hyperorality/hyperphagia), constantly squeezes genitals (hypersexuality), indifferent to parents is suggestive of Kluver-Bucy syndrome.

Kluver Bucy syndrome is characterized by hyperorality, hyperphagia, hypersexuality, hypermetamorphosis (constantly shifting attention). It is due to damage to the temporal lobe and amygdala, which leads to an inability to access memory and emotional connections.

Option A: In medial hypothalamic disease, there is an increase in eating behavior, marked by a lack of satiety and resultant obesity.

Option B: Kleine–Levin syndrome, also known as sleeping beauty syndrome, is a rare sleep disorder characterized by persistent episodic hypersomnia, hyperphagia, and hypersexuality with cognitive or mood changes.

Option D: Charcot Willbrand disease leads to loss of visual imagery with occipitotemporal damage.

questions.text: A 30 yr old male presents with recurrent attacks of sweating and dizziness. Further workup reveals hypoglycemia, elevated insulin and C-peptide levels. He is diagnosed with insulinoma and given diazoxide. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Opening of the ATP Sensitive K+ channels
Closing of the ATP Sensitive K+ channels
Increase in number of GLUT-4 receptors
Opening of the voltage sensitive Ca2+ channels

questions.solution:
Diazoxide acts by opening ATP sensitive K+ channels and causing a decrease in insulin secretion. 

Glucose enters beta cells of the pancreas via GLUT-2 receptors. Once inside, it is phosphorylated by glucokinase (rate-limiting step) to glucose-6-phosphate which is oxidized to form adenosine triphosphate (ATP). This ATP causes closure of ATP-sensitive potassium channels and hence depolarization. This leads to opening voltage-gated calcium channels and Ca2+ influx. This stimulates fusion of the insulin-containing vesicles with the cell membrane and secretion of insulin into the extracellular fluid by exocytosis. 

Diazoxide keeps the ATP sensitive K+ channels open and prevents depolarization and subsequent insulin release. 

Sulfonylureas cause closure of the ATP sensitive K+ channels, leading to increased insulin secretion.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is the 'Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing.

The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever.

Management:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction. Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.
  • Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>IV>IM ). It is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)

Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

questions.text: Herd immunity threshold does not vary with which of the following?

choices.text: Efficacy of the vaccine for the disease
Number of vaccines for the disease

questions.solution:
Herd immunity threshold does not vary with the number of vaccines for the disease. It varies only due to the virulence of the disease, efficacy of the vaccine and contact parameter for the population.

Related Pearl: Herd Immunity

  • Herd immunity is the level of protection of a community against a particular disease brought about by vaccination or immunization.
  • It refers to group protection beyond what is afforded by the protection of immunized individuals.
  • It is difficult to maintain the chain of infection if a large portion of the population is immune to a certain disease.
  • Elements which contribute to herd immunity are:
    • Occurrence of clinical and sub-clinical infection in the herd
    • Immunization of the herd
    • Herd structure
  • The herd structure not only includes the primary species but also the presence and distribution of alternative animal hosts, vectors and other environmental/social factors that are related to disease spread.
  • It is not possible or necessary to achieve 100% herd immunity in a population.
  • The proportion of immune individuals above which a disease may no longer spread is called herd immunity threshold.
  • This threshold depends upon the virulence of the disease, efficacy of the vaccine and contact parameter for the population.
  • Herd immunity is determined by serological surveys.
  • Herd immunity doesn’t offer protection against diseases like tetanus.

questions.text: A patient with advanced esophageal cancer in the lower third of the esophagus is undergoing transhiatal esophagectomy. The surgeon enlarges the esophageal hiatus with four fingers. All of the following structures are likely to be injured, except:
questions.solution:
The left phrenic nerve is unlikely to be injured as does not pass through any specific opening in the diaphragm. It passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm anterior to the central tendon, just lateral to the left cardiac surface and more anterior than the right phrenic nerve.

Structures passing through the esophageal hiatus are:

  • Esophagus
  • Vagal trunks
  • Gastric nerves
  • Esophageal branches of the left gastric vessels 
  • Some lymphatic vessels

Clinical significance:

In carcinoma esophagus involving the lower third, the Orringer approach or transhiatal esophagectomy is done. The stomach and lower part of esophagus are mobilised via laparotomy and the upper part is mobilized via the left side of the neck. Blunt dissection is done at the hiatus to approach the thorax from the abdomen. Other alternatives to this procedure are robotic and thoracoscopic techniques

questions.text: A farmer presents with blurring of vision in his left eye. He has a history of injury with a bush to the same eye while working. An ulcer is seen in his cornea with feathery margins. Slit-lamp examination shows infiltrates in the corneal stroma in a circular fashion. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction causes these infiltrates?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation points towards a fungal corneal ulcer and the infiltrates of stroma in a circular fashion are suggestive of the immune ring of Wessely. This immune ring is due to type 3 hypersensitivity reaction (antigen-antibody complex).

The immune ring of Wessely can be made out as a deep stromal haze in a slit lamp. It occurs as a result of the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the stroma. Once deposited it draws the immune cells, inciting further inflammation.

The given shows an ulcer in the cornea and the adjacent immune ring of Wessely.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
A patient who has had exposure to HBV will have anti-HBc antibody even when he has moved into the chronic or recurrent stages. IgM anti-HBc reappears during acute recurrences while IgG anti-HBc is found in chronic states. 

The HBsAg antigen is present in chronic hepatitis B, while the antibody anti-HBs is not.

questions.text: A 69-year-old male presented with diplopia. Investigations revealed an aneurysm of the right anterior inferior cerebellar artery that is directly impinging on the nerve arising at the pontomedullary junction. Which of the following extraocular muscles is likely to be paralyzed?
questions.solution:
The lateral rectus muscle is likely to be paralyzed as it is innervated by the VI cranial nerve, which emerges from the pontomedullary junction (PMJ). 

Cranial nerves VI, VII, and VIII arise at the PMJ.

Extraocular muscles are innervated by the III, IV, and VI cranial nerves. The superior oblique is innervated by CN IV, the lateral rectus by CN VI, and all the other muscles by CN III. 

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with a history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and amenorrhoea for six months. On examination, a pelvic mass is felt on the left side and signs of ascites are positive. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with abdominal pain, amenorrhoea, pelvic mass and ascites is suggestive of genital tuberculosis.

Genital tuberculosis:

It is caused by M. tuberculosis and almost always occurs secondary to primary infection elsewhere in the extragenital states. The sites and frequency of involvement are as follows: 

  • Fallopian tubes (90-100%)
  • Endometrium (50-60%)
  • Ovaries (20-30%)
  • Cervix (5-15%)
  • Vulva and vagina (< 1%)

Presentation is variable and it can be asymptomatic in 10-20% of cases, infertility, menstrual irregularities, abdominal pain and mass, vaginal discharge, fistula formation, ectopic pregnancy and ascites. The mass is made up of rolled-up omentum that is adherent to the uterus and adnexa.

Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weakness, anorexia or night sweats may be present. 

Investigations: 

  • CBC, ESR and Mantoux test 
  • Hysterosalpingography shows a lead-pipe appearance of the fallopian tube, calcification of the tube, beading and variation in the filling, cornual block, jagged fluffiness of tubal outline and tobacco pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx.
  • Laparoscopy establishes the diagnosis of genital TB. It shows tuberculous lesions and perihepatic adhesions (if present).

Differential diagnosis:

  • Ovarian cyst, broad ligament cyst or encysted fluid 
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease 
  • Ectopic pregnancy 
  • Carcinoma cervix 
  • Elephantiasis of the vulva 
  • Pregnancy 
  • Puberty menorrhagia and postmenopausal bleeding 
  • Fungal infection and sarcoidosis

Management: 

It is treated with anti-tubercular therapy for 6 months (DOT strategy):

First 2 months 

 Next 4 months 
  • Isoniazid 15 mg/ kg body weight
  • Rifampicin 450-600 mg
  • Pyrazinamide 30 mg/body weight
  • Ethambutol 30 mg/ kg body weight 

3 times a week. 
  • Isoniazid 15 mg/kg body weight 
  • Rifampicin 450-600 mg

3 times a week 

Indications and contraindications for surgery: 

Indications  Contraindications 
  • Unresponsiveness of the disease in spite of adequate antitubercular chemotherapy.
  • Tubercular pyosalpinx, ovarian abscess or pyometra.
  • Persistent menorrhagia and/or chronic pelvic pain causing deteriorating health status 
  • Presence of active tuberculosis in extragenital site
  • Favorable response to antimicrobial therapy with the diminishing size of the pelvic mass
  • The accidental discovery of tubercular tubo-ovarian mass on laparotomy in a young patient. 

Types of surgery include vulvectomy (if vulval hypertrophy is present), removal of the adnexal mass, drainage of pyometra and fistula repair.

TAH+BSO is rarely required nowadays. Tuboplasty is contraindicated.

Option B: Ovarian tumors usually don't affect menstrual cycles. Though virilizing tumors can cause amenorrhoea, other features of virilization such as hirsutism, flattening of breasts, and enlargement of the clitoris are generally present.

Option C: Though ectopic pregnancy may be suspected here, the tube is likely to rupture with exacerbation of pain, bleeding, and peritonitis before six months of gestation. Additionally, the absence of vaginal bleeding/spotting, and the presence of weight loss makes the diagnosis unlikely.

Option D: Submucous fibroid is associated with menorrhagia.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

  3. Patients >14 years of age.

questions.text: A patient has a dead space of 150 mL, a functional residual capacity of 3L, tidal volume of 650 mL, expiratory reserve volume of 1.5 L, a total lung capacity of 8L, respiratory rate of 15 breaths/min. What is the rate of alveolar ventilation?
questions.solution:
The rate of alveolar ventilation in this patient is 7.5 L/min.

Alveolar ventilation per minute is the total volume of new air entering the alveoli and adjacent gas exchange areas each minute. It is equal to the respiratory rate times the amount of new air that enters these areas with each breath.

Alveolar ventilation=Respiratory rate X (Tidal volume – Physiologic dead space)

                               = 15 X (650-150)

                               = 7500mL/min or 7.5L/min.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents with the following finding after a trivial fall. His lab investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Platelet count - 4,00,000 /μL

Bleeding time - normal

PT - normal

aPTT - prolonged
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing hemarthrosis and elevated aPTT is suggestive of hemophilia. 

Specific tests for measuring levels of factor VIII and factor IX can determine whether it is hemophilia A or hemophilia B respectively.

Clinical features of hemophilia:

  • Hemarthroses - joint hemorrhages, later causing progressive deformities
  • Recurrent bleeding
  • Pseudotumour syndrome - fascial hemorrhages that occur as blood-filled cysts with calcification and proliferation of fibroblasts, giving the appearance of the tumor

It is associated with elevated aPTT and normal platelet count, bleeding time, and PT.

Option A: In ITP, the platelet count is low and bleeding time is prolonged.

Option B: In functional platelet disorders, like Bernard Soulier syndrome, the platelet count is normal and bleeding time is prolonged.

Option D: In vitamin K deficiency, both PT and aPTT are prolonged. PT is relatively more prolonged than is the aPTT.

Related Pearl: Differences between Bleeding Disorders and Coagulation disorders

questions.text: Identify the ions A and B based on conductance graph of a neuron shown below:
questions.solution:
Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

Na+ channels are fast activating and are responsible for depolarization phase of action potential.

K+ channels are slow activating and open for prolonged duration than the sodium channels. They are responsible for repolarization phase of action potential. Also, the postassium channels return slowly to their closed state, which is responsible for after-hyperpolarization.

The sequence of events during the action potential occur in 7 steps as described below.

1. Resting state - Both channels are closed

2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters into the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.

3. The sodium influx causes opening of more sodium channels through positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs.

4. Sodium conductance decreases.

5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.

6. Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.

7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman presents with fatigue and weight loss for the past 6 months. She tells you that her father is also a diabetic. Further evaluation reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Body mass index - 21 kg/m2

Fasting blood sugar - 252 mg/dl

Glycosylated hemoglobin - 8.2%

Urinalysis for ketones - Negative
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY). 

MODY is a monogenic form of diabetes mellitus that is transmitted in an autosomal dominant fashion. It affects young adults < 25 years of age. It occurs due to reduced insulin secretion. Etiological factors of type 1 and 2 diabetes such as insulin resistance, obesity, and antibodies are not associated with this condition.

Stable hyperglycemia is usually seen, hence complications like diabetic ketoacidosis are uncommon. Macrovascular complications like hyperlipidemia or hypertension are not seen. It is treated with sulfonylureas.

Latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA) is a form of type 1 diabetes that occurs between 30-50 years of age.

questions.text: An  infant presented with delayed eruption of her teeth. An image of her teeth are shown below. She also has history of blisters over the face, hands and feet on exposure to sunlight since the first week of birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An infant with delayed eruption and reddish discoloration of teeth, and blisters over sun-exposed areas suggests a diagnosis of congenital erythropoietic porphyria. 

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria, also is known as Gunther's disease, is an autosomal recessive porphyria. There is uroporphyrinogen III synthase deficiency, leading to uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulation in teeth, bone marrow, erythrocyte, plasma urine and feces.

Infants present with port wine urine or pink stained diapers, severe cutaenous hypersensitivity, and reddish-brown teeth known as erythrodontia. When illuminated with UV light, the teeth show reddish fluorescence. It may cause non-immune hydrops in utero or shortly after birth in severe cases. 

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: A 52-year-old​ woman with postmenopausal bleeding has an endometrial thickness of 7 mm on ultrasound. What is the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
The next line of management in a patient with increased endometrial thickness is an endometrial biopsy.

In a postmenopausal woman, the normal endometrium should not exceed 4 mm in thickness. If it exceeds 4 mm, then histopathological examination (HPE) of the endometrium is mandatory, irrespective of the presence or absence of symptoms. In a perimenopausal woman, the cutoff for normal endometrial thickness is 10mm. 

Hysteroscopy and biopsy is preferred over other blind curettage methods for HPE. A biopsy is made from suspicious areas after visualization so chances of missing the lesion are reduced.

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:
questions.solution:
Personal monitoring of radiation is done by a TLD badge.

The TLD badge (thermoluminescent dosimeter) should be positioned according to local or national practices. In India, one TLD badge has to be worn at the chest level inside the lead apron if the apron is used. An additional wrist badge has to be worn for procedures requiring hands close to the primary beam. 

The thermoluminescent material used is calcium sulfate doped with dysprosium or lithium fluoride. Radiation exposure is monitored every three months. The maximum dose limit for occupational radiation workers is 30 mSv in a year, provided the cumulative dose in a block of 5 years does not exceed 100 mSv. 

The given image shows a TLD badge.

questions.text: A mother asks for LASIK surgery for the correction of her 15-year-old daughter's myopia. Which of the following is not an eligibility criterion for this procedure?

choices.text: Stable refraction for the past 1 year

questions.solution:
Age of 15 years is not a criterion for LASIK surgery. LASIK surgery is performed after 18 years of age.

Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is performed using excimer laser in individuals aged > 18 years who have a stable refractive error for 1 year. It is done in individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment. Corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus must be ruled out before this procedure.

questions.text:
Ravi, an adolescent with sickle cell disease presents to the emergency room with chest pain and respiratory distress. Pulse oximeter shows 85% saturation in room air. Chest X-ray shows new radiodensities. Sputum and blood culture showed no growth. Which of the following are used in the management of this condition?
  1. Macrolide antibiotics
  2. Incentive spirometry
  3. Blood transfusion
  4. Third-generation cephalosporins
  5. Supplemental oxygen
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute chest syndrome and all of the above are used in the management. 

Acute chest syndrome (ACS) refers to a life-threatening pulmonary complication of sickle cell disease. It is diagnosed with the presence of a new radiodensity on chest radiography with any 2 of the following:

  1. Fever
  2. Respiratory distress
  3. Hypoxia
  4. Cough
  5. Chest pain

In this case, the child with sickle cell anemia satisfies the above criteria. He presented with chest pain and respiratory distress and his chest X-ray image shows new radiodensities. 

Most patients with ACS do not have a single identifiable cause. Infection is the most well-known etiology, yet only 30% of ACS episodes will have positive sputum or bronchoalveolar culture. The most common bacterial pathogens implicated are S. pneumoniae, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and Chlamydia spp.

Oxygen should be supplemented to all patients who demonstrate hypoxia. 

Blood transfusion is the only method to abort a rapidly progressing episode of ACS.

Because of the clinical overlap between pneumonia and ACS, all episodes should be treated promptly with antimicrobial therapy, including at least a macrolide and possibly a third-generation cephalosporin.

Regular use of an incentive spirometer at 10-12 breaths every 2 hours can significantly reduce the frequency of subsequent acute chest pain episodes.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presented with progressive pain and swelling over the right leg. An X-ray of his leg is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the Codman triangle which is suggestive of osteosarcoma.

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. Distal femur, proximal tibia and proximal humerus are the common sites.

The Codman's triangle is marked out in the X-ray given below. It is formed due to raising of the periosteum by the tumor.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with AIDS presents to the local clinic complaining of fever, nausea, vomiting and confusion. A lumbar puncture is performed and the microscopic appearance of India ink-stained CSF specimen is given below. Which of the following drugs is most beneficial in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the India ink preparation demonstrating clear halos is suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. Flucytosine and amphotericin B are used in the treatment of this condition.

C. neoformans spreads from inhalation of the yeast cells in pigeon feces, causing infection in HIV/AIDS and other immunosuppressive conditions. It causes influenza-like respiratory infection in immunocompetent persons. In immunocompromised individuals, it disseminates to CNS, causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, and patients may complain of headaches, neck stiffness, and disorientation, as in this case. Other common sites of dissemination include the skin, adrenals, bone, eye, and prostate gland.

Diagnosis is made by demonstration of yeast cells or cryptococcal antigen in CSF. India ink stain is used to demonstrate capsulated budding yeast cells in CSF as they have a distinctive appearance because their capsules exclude ink particles. Rapid detection of cryptococcal antigen in CSF and blood can also be done. Colonies develop within a few days on most media at room temperature or 37°C. Media with cycloheximide should be avoided as it inhibits Cryptococcus.

Combination therapy of amphotericin B and flucytosine has been considered the standard treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

Other options: 

Ketoconazole is usually used for chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

Nystatin is also used for mucocutaneous forms of candidiasis.

Miconazole is used for topical fungal infections like oral thrush, and vaginitis.

questions.text: Mohit is brought to the pediatrician by his mother because of red-eye. He complains of blurring of vision and on examination, the pupil appears as shown in the picture. Which of the following subtype of JIA is associated with the highest risk for the ophthalmic complication noted in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has red-eye and the blurring of vision along with the finding of the irregular pupil, which is suggestive of uveitis. ANA-positive oligoarthritis is associated with the highest risk for uveitis in patients with Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis.

The presence of a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) confers increased risk for uveitis in children with JIA and requires periodic slit-lamp examination every 3 months.

questions.text: Valid consent for sexual intercourse cannot be given by a girl aged less than:
questions.solution:
Minimum age of a girl to give consent for sexual intercourse is 18 years.

This was changed from 16 years to 18 years by the Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2013.

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman who presented with foul-smelling discharge per vaginum and dyspareunia has been diagnosed with carcinoma cervix. What is the most accurate method to identify nodal metastasis in this patient?
questions.solution:
PET-CT is the most accurate method of diagnosis of nodal metastasis.

The revised staging permits the use of any of the imaging modalities according to available resources, i.e.ultrasound, CT, MRI, positron emission tomography (PET). This helps provide information on tumor size, nodal status, and local or systemic spread.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. Upon arrival, the patient was unconscious with blood pressure of 90/64 mmHg and a pulse rate of 139 per minute. He was immediately transfused with 4 units of packed RBCs. All of the following complications can occur in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The complication of massive transfusion includes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia.

The lethal triad of massive transfusion includes acidosis, hypothermia, and coagulopathy. Other complications which can be seen in massive transfusion are:

  • Hypocalcaemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: For effective chest compression during CPR, where should the hands of the healthcare provider ideally be placed?
questions.solution:
In children and adults, chest compressions are performed by locating the xiphoid process and placing the heel of the hand over the lower half of the sternum. The other hand is placed over the hand on the sternum with the fingers either interlaced or extended and the elbow extended so that the weight of the upper body is used for compression.

In infants, if there is a single rescuer, compressions are effected by placing 2 fingers in the center of the chest, just below the nipple line. If there are 2 or more rescuers, then 2 thumb technique is used.

In infants and children, the depth of compression should be at least one-third of the anteroposterior diameter of the chest, which is about 5 cm in children and 4 cm in infants.

For pediatric patients, the ratio of chest compression to rescue breaths is 30:2 for a single rescuer and 15:2 if 2 or more rescuers are present. In adults, the ratio is 30:2 irrespective of the number of rescuers.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman having lower abdominal pain and shock is diagnosed with a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. The gynecologist decides to perform an emergency laparotomy via the incision shown in the image below. Which of these structures is not incised in this approach?
questions.solution:
The image shows a midline incision used for emergency laparotomy. Transversus abdominis muscle is not incised in this approach.

Layers of the abdomen pierced in the midline approach (from superficial to deep):

  • Skin
  • Superficial fascia (Campers and Scarpa)
  • Linea alba
  • Transversalis fascia
  • Extraperitoneal fat
  • Parietal peritoneum

There are no muscles pierced in this approach. 

Layers of the abdomen pierced in the flanks (from superficial to deep):

  • Skin
  • Superficial fascia (Campers and Scarpa)
  • External oblique
  • Internal oblique
  • Transversus abdominis
  • Transversalis fascia
  • Extraperitoneal fat
  • Parietal peritoneum

These layers are shown in the image below:

Clinical Note: Umbilical and epigastric hernias can happen due to a congenital or acquired defect in the linea alba such as a midline abdominal incision.

questions.text: A woman who is on treatment for schizophrenia says that she loves her child and wants to hug him, but also thinks that he is the devil personified and wants to harm him. She is torn between the two, and can't decide what to express. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Ambivalence is the inability to decide for or against, due to the co-existence of two opposing impulses for the same thing, at the same time, in the same person.

Ambivalence is an important feature of schizophrenia. It is also seen with OCD and other borderline conditions.

Option A: Abulia is an inability to make a decision generally. Unlike ambivalence, there are no opposing impulses present.

Option C: Anhedonia is a loss of pleasure in previously pleasurable activities.

Option D: Alexithymia is an inability to recognize and describe feelings.

questions.text: From which of the following layers does the regeneration of endometrium take place?
questions.solution:
Endometrium regenerates from zona basalis.

The basal layer adjacent to the myometrium remains intact and is the source of new endometrium. This arises from the proliferation of the endometrial glandular remnants and the stroma of the interglandular connective tissue.

questions.text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures?
questions.solution:
The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani. It allows for the electrodes to be in close proximity to the ganglion cells and their dendrites which are located in the modiolus and bony spiral lamina of the cochlea. 

A cochlear implant is an electronic device for severe to profound SNHL and who cannot benefit from a hearing aid. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the auditory nerve. Prerequisites include an intact cochlear nerve and higher auditory pathway.

In the auditory brainstem implant, the site of the implant is the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle. It is used when the cochlear nerve is not intact.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with the following skin lesion. How will you describe it?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a round lesion without central clearing is called a nummular (coin-like) or a discoid lesion. 

Both, the edge and center are equally active and uniformly colored. It is seen in discoid eczema, psoriasis.

Option A: Annular lesions are ring-shaped with central clearing i.e., only the edges are active and appear raised, or in a different color. It is seen in tinea corporis, granuloma annulare. 

Option C: Arcuate lesions are arc-shaped or incomplete circles.

Option D: Polycyclic lesions are several circles that have merged together.

Related Pearl: Shapes of skin lesions

A filled circle

Discoid eczema, Psoriasis

Seborrhoeic dermatitis on the trunk

Open circles with different central skin compared with the rim

Tinea corporis, granuloma annulare

Epidermal naevi, late‐stage incontinentia pigmenti

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with mitral stenosis. Which of the following features is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Left ventricular hypertrophy is not seen in mitral stenosis. On the contrary, right ventricle hypertrophy is seen.

Mechanism of mitral stenosis (MS):

In a normal mitral valve, there is no obstruction to the flow of blood from the left atrium(LA) to the left ventricle. Therefore a small LA pressure is sufficient to empty the blood into the ventricle.

When the MVA is <~2 sq cm, blood flows from the left atrium to the left ventricle, propelled by a mildly elevated atrial pressure. Hence, patients are usually asymptomatic and may develop dyspnea only when the heart rate increases, as seen in exertion, excitement, fever, etc. All these conditions:

  •  Increase the rate of blood flow across the mitral orifice, resulting in further elevation of the LA pressure
  •  Decrease the diastolic filling time, resulting in a reduction in cardiac output

The image below explains the mechanism of mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with a history of intractable diarrhea. Based on the histological image shown below which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. 

The image shows Russell bodies which are eosinophilic, large, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing inclusions usually found in a plasma cell undergoing excessive synthesis of immunoglobulins. Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum.

Globular inclusions are Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) and Dutcher bodies (if nuclear). 

The below image shows Russell bodies:

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: A 66-year-old man with chronic hypertension presents to the ER with altered mental status and elevated blood pressure of 210/110 mm Hg. You suspect intracranial hemorrhage. What is the most common site of hemorrhage seen in such cases?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of hypertensive intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The most common site (50-60%) of hypertensive hemorrhage in the brain is the putamen.

Hypertension is the most common cause of intracerebral hemorrhage.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are seen in McArdle's disease. This patient has muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency.

The lack of muscle glycogen phosphorylase results in excess glycogen build-up in muscles. The image given below shows the vacuolar myopathy seen in McArdle's disease.

Clinical features include poor exercise tolerance, abnormally high muscle glycogen (2.5-4%), and a very low blood lactate after exercise

The images given below show myophosphorylase enzyme histochemistry showing (A) Normal muscle and (B) McArdle's disease.

questions.text: During a clinical trial, it was found that some individuals who showed radioactive uptake on Sestamibi scan, showed no other evidence of hyperparathyroidism. They were instead found to be suffering from a Hurthle cell nodule of the thyroid gland. Which of the following radioactive tracer tests could be used to rule out the false positives?
questions.solution:
A thyroid-specific tracer like 99Tc-Pertechnetate and subsequent subtraction images could be used to rule out the false positives caused by the solid thyroid nodules such as Hurthle cell nodule.

The Sestamibi scanning is a nuclear-based imaging test used to localize the parathyroid glands. Sestamibi is a monovalent lipophilic cation that accumulates in mitochondria. Due to this, there is a difference in the rate at which it gets washed out depending upon the number of mitochondria in each tissue. Parathyroid adenomas often have a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content and they retain tracers and have a slower washout compared to the normal glands.

In patients with nodular goiter or functional tumors of the thyroid gland, increased uptake of sestamibi by the thyroid gland makes parathyroid visualization difficult. There are two primary techniques to differentiate sestamibi uptake by abnormal parathyroid and thyroid tissue:

  • Dual-isotope subtraction imaging (with sestamibi and either iodine-123 or 99mTc pertechnetate) -  99mTc pertechnetate is taken up only by the thyroid. The 99mTc pertechnetate scintigram is then digitally subtracted from the sestamibi scan to allow parathyroid localization.
  • Single-isotope dual-phase imaging (with sesta­mibi alone with early and delayed imaging) - since the rate of washout from the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland is slower when compared to the thyroid gland.

The image given below shows the dual-isotope subtraction imaging.

questions.text: Which of the following ascending pathways enters the cerebellum through the peduncle highlighted in green in the image?
questions.solution:
The peduncle highlighted in the image is the superior cerebellar peduncle. The anterior spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through it and terminates in both sides of the cerebellum. 

Dorsal spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle and terminates on the same side as its origin.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheeze, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest revealed bilateral wheeze. Sputum microscopy reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows in below image), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.

Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:

  • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma
  • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease
  • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma

The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:

  • Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10
  • Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles
  • Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells
  • Numerous eosinophils

Note: The hygiene hypothesis was previously used to explain the development of asthma and other hypersensitivity disorders.

questions.text: A woman presents with a positive urine pregnancy test and states that her LMP was 8 weeks ago. However, she has a history of irregular cycles. Which of the following would be the most accurate way of dating the pregnancy?

choices.text: Abdominal circumference on transabdominal or transvaginal USG
Crown rump length on transabdominal or transvaginal USG

questions.solution: The most accurate way of dating the pregnancy is using the crown-rump length (CRL) on transabdominal or transvaginal USG. It has a variance of about 3 to 5 days.

questions.text: What is the study of heritable changes in gene expression that are not caused by alterations in DNA sequence?
questions.solution:
Epigenetics is the branch of molecular biology that deals with the study of heritable changes in gene function not involving changes in the DNA sequence.

These heritable changes involve factors that mediate processes such as:

  • Histone organization 
  • DNA methylation 
  • Chromatin organization

These in turn regulate the genomic organization and gene expression in a cell-type-specific fashion. The dysregulation of these epigenomic factors plays a major role in the development of malignancy.

Green tea catechins have been reported to modulate epigenetic processes. They can reverse DNA methylation of tumor suppressor genes and increase the transcription of these genes.

questions.text: The weight of the head, arms and chest act as a constricting force in which of the following types of hanging?
questions.solution:
The weight of the head, arms, and chest acts as a constricting force in partial hanging.

Types of hanging:

  • Complete hanging - the weight of the entire body acts as a constricting force.
  • Partial hanging - the bodies are partially suspended, the weight of the head (5-6 kgs), arms, and chest act as a constricting force.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with sudden onset blindness. He gives a history of frequent headaches along the sides of his scalp. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of giant cell arteritis.

Giant cell / temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries that especially affects the temporal arteries. It is seen in people over 50 years of age. It usually presents with facial pain or headache along the course of the superficial temporal artery.

It can also affect:

  • Ophthalmic arteries- leading to sudden onset diplopia or blindness
  • Aorta- leading to giant-cell aortitis
  • Vertebral arteries

A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Giant cell arteritis needs to be promptly diagnosed and treated with steroids to prevent permanent blindness.

Related Pearl: Important Vasculitis with Features

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Medium-sized and large arteries) Aortic arch, great vessels, pulmonary artery, coronary and renal arteries

Lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, granulomas, giant cells

Pulseless disease

Small or medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Spares pulmonary vessels, 30% of patients with  chronic hepatitis B

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Necrotizing glomerulonephritism (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis leukocytoclastic vasculitis

Medium and small arteries

 

Eosinophils (required), lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils

Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

questions.text: Vulvar carcinoma was diagnosed in a 68-year-old woman who presented with itching and mass over the vulva for 6 months. Sentinel lymph node biopsy revealed positive inguinal nodes. What is the stage of the tumor?
questions.solution:
According to FIGO staging, tumor with positive inguinal lymph node is classified as stage III.

Related Pearl: Staging of Vulval Cancer (FIGO)

Stage Features
I Tumor confined to vulva
IA Lesions ≤2 cm in size, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis
IB Lesions >2cm in size or with stromal invasion >1mm , confined to the vulva or perineum, with negative nodes
II Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with negative nodes
III Tumor of any size with/without extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IIIA i) With 1 lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm) or,
  ii)1-2 lymph node micrometastases(<5mm)
IIIB i) With 2 or more lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm), or
  ii) 3 or more lymph node micrometastases (<5 mm)
IIIC With positive nodes with extracapsular spread
IV Tumor invades other regional structures (upper 2/3rd urethra, upper 2/3rd vagina) or distant structures
IVA Tumour invades any of the following:
  i) Upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  ii) Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IVB Any distant metastasis including pelvic lymph nodes

questions.text: What is known as the time period in which a second stronger impulse can elicit action potential after the application of one stimulus?
questions.solution:
The refractory period is the time period in which a second stronger impulse can elicit action potential after the application of one stimulus. It can be absolute or relative. 

During the rising and much of the falling phases of the spike potential, the neuron is refractory to stimulation. This refractory period is divided into an

  • Absolute refractory period, corresponding to the period from the time the firing level is reached until repolarization is about one-third complete
  • Relative refractory period, lasting from this point to the start of after-depolarization

During the absolute refractory period, no stimulus, no matter how strong, will not excite the nerve. However, during the relative refractory period, stimuli that are stronger than normal can cause excitation.

The absolute refractory period for large myelinated nerve fibers is about 1/2500 second.

Related Pearl: Absolute and relative refractory period

Types of refractory periods

Absolute refractory period

Relative  refractory period

Property

No stimulus, no matter how strong, will  not excite the nerve

 Stronger than normal stimuli can cause excitation 
 Period Period from the time the firing level is reached until repolarization is about one-third complete Begins at the end of the Absolute refractory period to the start of after-depolarization 
 Basis Closure of the Inactivation Gates of the Na+ channel in response to depolarization  

Na+ channels are reset and can open upon arrival of a stronger stimuli

K+ channel remain open

questions.text:
A study was conducted in a village with 180 eligible couples, to gather data on the different contraceptive methods used. The data obtained are given below. What is the couple protection rate in the village?

Vasectomy – 15

Tubectomy – 15

Intrauterine device (IUD) users – 8

Oral pill users – 15

Condom users – 7
questions.solution:
Couple protection rate (CPR) is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning. 

In the given scenario, 60 out of 180 eligible couples are using different contraceptive methods. Therefore, CPR = (60/180) x 100 = 33%.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presents with meningococcal meningitis. He has a history of recurrent bacterial chest and ear infections. Family history reveals that he has a male cousin (maternal side) who died in infancy from infection. The physician suspects X-linked agammaglobulinemia. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: It is caused by a mutation of the BTK gene
Both humoral and cell mediated immunity are affected
All classes of immunoglobulin levels are reduced
Lymph node biopsy shows depletion of follicles

questions.solution:
X-linked or Bruton's agammaglobulinemia is primarily a disease of humoral immunity. Cell-mediated immunity is not affected.

It is an inherited immunodeficiency disease caused by mutations in the gene coding for Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK). B cells do not differentiate and mature. They are arrested in the pre-B cell stage.

There are extremely low IgG levels (below 100 mg/dL) and an absence of other immunoglobulin classes. The tonsils and lymph nodes are usually atrophic. Lymph node biopsy reveals depletion of cells of B cell-dependent areas (follicles). Babies born with this disorder have virtually no peripheral B cells (<1%) and suffer from recurrent bacterial infections.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A man with chronic alcoholism presented with orthopnea and pedal edema. On investigation, cardiomegaly is noted. Which vitamin deficiency can lead to this presentation?
questions.solution:
Cardiac failure (orthopnea and pedal edema) and cardiomegaly in a patient with chronic alcoholism suggest a diagnosis of wet beriberi. Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to this condition. 

Chronic alcohol consumption is associated with thiamine deficiency due to inadequate dietary intake, malabsorption of thiamine from the gastrointestinal tract and impaired utilization of thiamine in the cells. This deficiency presents as:

  1. Wet beriberi: The cardiovascular system is affected. Patients present with high output cardiac failure (orthopnea, pedal edema), dyspnea, cardiomegaly, and pulmonary edema.
  2. Dry beriberi: Both the peripheral and central nervous systems are affected. Patients present with symmetric motor and sensory neuropathy (pain, paresthesia, loss of reflexes) especially in lower limbs. In severe cases, muscle atrophy may also be seen.

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

Assay and test

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

RBC Trans-ketolase

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

Vitamin B9 (Folic acid)

FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamine)

Serum methyl malonate level
