questions.text: A man is heartbroken because his girlfriend recently left him to marry another man. He decides to get drunk that night, to cope with his feelings. On waking up the next morning, he finds that he has set fire to her car. Which of the following statements is true with respect to the man?

choices.text: He is guilty under Sec 84 IPC (Sec 22 BNS)
He is guilty under Sec 85 IPC (Sec 23 BNS)
He can be charged under Sec 510 IPC (Sec 355 BNS)
He can be charged under Sec 86 IPC (24 BNS)

questions.solution:
This man can be charged under Sec 86 IPC (Sec 24 BNS).

According to this section, an act is considered a crime only if done with certain knowledge or intent, a person who commits the act while intoxicated will be assumed to have had that knowledge as if they were not intoxicated. This assumption does not apply if the person was intoxicated without their knowledge or against their will.

Option A: Section 84 IPC (Sec 22 BNS) - Act of a person of unsound mind—No act is an offence which is undertaken by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act or understanding of what is being done is either wrong or contrary to law. This does not apply to the man, who was not of unsound mind. Section 84 IPC (Sec 22 BNS) does apply in the case of delirium tremens.

Section 85 IPC (Sec 23 BNS)- No act is an offence which is done by a person who at the time of doing it, by reason of intoxication, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act or what he is doing is either wrong or contrary to law; provided that what intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will. Here, Section 85 IPC (Sec 23 BNS) does not apply because the alcohol was not administered to him against his will.

Option C: Section 510 IPC (Sec 355 BNS) - Misconduct by a drunken person in public is punishable with imprisonment of up to 24 hours. This does not apply here as the man was not caught committing the crime while in a state of intoxication.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the Spaulding classification?

choices.text: Semi-critical items require high level disinfection
Non-critical items do not require disinfection
Cardiac catheters are classified as critical items
Critical items are associated with a high risk of infection

questions.solution:
Under the Spaulding classification, non-critical items require intermediate or low-level disinfection.

Related Pearl: The Spaulding Classification

The Spaulding classification classifies medical devices according to the degree of risk of infection if they are contaminated.

Device

Description

Examples

Disinfection

Non-critical device

Lower risk of infection as the device comes in contact with intact or normal skin.

Stethoscope, walls, furniture, BP cuff, etc.

Intermediate/low-level disinfectant.

Clean, dry and store for future use.

Semi-critical devices

Lower risk of infection as these devices come in contact with mucosa and do not penetrate into sterile areas of the body.

Fiber-optic endoscopes, laryngoscopes, bronchoscopes, cystoscopes, vaginal specula, etc.

High-level disinfectant to be used after proper cleaning or sterilization by heat.

Critical devices

High risks of infection as these devices come in contact with sterile areas of the body like blood.

Needles, cardiac catheters, implants, intrauterine devices, urinary catheters, etc.

High-level disinfectant is indicated with sterilization with heat, ethylene oxide, etc.

questions.text: A young patient came with complaints of acute abdominal pain on and off and tingling sensation of limbs and at times weakness of limbs. She had a history of eating paint from the wall of a newly built house.  Which of the following enzyme defect will be the cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
A child with acute abdominal pain, tingling sensation and weakness of limbs with history of eating paint likely has lead poisoning. It is characterized by impaired ALA dehydratase enzyme activity.

Lead is a potent inhibitor of both ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase/ heme synthase (option C). However, it has the greatest inhibitory action on ALA dehydratase. Lead poisonining thus leads to the buildup of protoporphyrin and ALA. Lead also substitutes for calcium in many fundamental cellular processes. It can cross red blood cell membranes as well as the blood-brain barrier and enter the neuroglial cells which support brain function. The fatal dose of lead is 20g of lead acetate and the fatal period is 1 to 2 days.

Other options: 

Option A: ALA synthase 2 defect causes X-linked protoporphyria. 
Option C: Heme synthase, or ferrochelatase, defect causes erythropoeitic protoporphyria. 
Option D: Coproporphyrinogen oxidase defect causes hereditary corproporphyria.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: Which of the following is a radiological sign that is not seen in patients with adenocarcinoma of the pancreas?

choices.text: Narrowing of C-loop of the duodenum

questions.solution:
Widening of the C-loop of the duodenum is a barium meal finding seen in the adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

Radiological features of adenocarcinoma pancreas:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) findings:

  • Scrambled egg appearance
  • Double duct appearance

Barium meal findings:

  • Inverse 3 sign
  • Rose thorning of 2nd part of the duodenum
  • Widened duodenal C-loop

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented with the following skin finding. On inquiry, he also tells you that his father has similar complaints. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a periungual fibroma or Koenen tumor, which is characteristic of tuberous sclerosis (TS). They appear at or after puberty as smooth, firm, flesh-colored excrescences emerging from the nail folds. 

Other cutaneous features of tuberous sclerosis:

  • Angiofibromas - Firm, discrete, red-brown, telangiectatic papules, 1 to 10 mm in diameter that become more extensive at puberty and then remain unchanged. They extend from the nasolabial furrows to the cheeks and chin and are occasionally found in the ears.
  • Shagreen patch - An irregularly thickened, slightly elevated, soft, skin-colored plaque, usually in the lumbosacral region.
  • Ash-leaf macule - White ovoid or ash‐leaf‐shaped macules, 1–3 cm in length, most easily detectable by examination under Wood’s light, are frequently present on the trunk or limbs. They are a valuable physical sign as they may be found at birth or in early infancy, some years before other signs of the disease develop.
  • Other cutaneous manifestations- include firm fibromatous plaques, especially on the forehead and scalp, soft pedunculated fibromas around the neck and axillae, and poliosis.

questions.text:
A woman presents with breathlessness and hemoptysis since yesterday. Examination findings are given below. CT scan shows localised ground-glass opacity in the left posterior lobe of the lung. What is the likely diagnosis?

Pulse- 96/min,

BP- 118/68 mmHg,

Temperature- 100.3 F

RR- 15 cpm

SpO2- 82% on room air
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of COVID-19. Hemoptysis is one of the atypical manifestations of COVID-19 and it may be present with more common features such as breathlessness, fever, and cough. CT-finding of localized ground-glass opacity is also supportive of the diagnosis.

Other atypical manifestations of COVID-19 include:

  • Respiratory-
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemoptysis
  • Cardiac-
    • Myocardial infarction
    • Myocarditis
    • Pericarditis
    • Pericardial effusion
  • Neurological-
    • Stroke
    • Guillain‐Barre Syndrome
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxic encephalopathy
    • Acute hemorrhagic necrotizing encephalopathy
    • Olfactory and taste disorders
  • Gastrointestinal-
    • Diarrhea
    • Nausea
    • Vomiting
    • Abdominal pain
  • Ocular-
    • Conjunctivitis
    • Epiphora
  • Cutaneous-
    • Erythematous rash
    • Widespread urticaria
    • Chickenpox‐like vesicles
    • Localized pruritic lesions
    • Petechial skin rash

Option A: Tuberculosis would have a more chronic history and radiologically appears as dense, homogeneous parenchymal consolidation in subpleural sites of lower and middle lobes.

Option B: In necrotising pneumonia, CT imaging is likely to show distinct areas of low attenuation with decreased parenchymal enhancement representing liquefaction.

Option D: Invasive aspergillosis is likely to occur in the setting of immunosuppression. The associated ground glass opacity, occurring due to hemorrhage, surrounds a pulmonary nodule and is known as the halo sign.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with hypertension and diabetes mellitus is on dialysis for chronic renal failure. Which of the following forms of gastritis is the patient at risk of development?
questions.solution:
Patients with renal failure develop acute gastritis as a consequence of uremia.

In uremia, gastric injury is due to inhibition of gastric bicarbonate transporters by ammonium ions.

Causes of acute gastritis:

  • Alcohol
  • Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • Smoking
  • Ischemia/shock
  • Steroid use
  • Uremia
  • Chemical ingestion
  • Stress

Histologically, the presence of neutrophils above the basement membrane in direct contact with epithelial cells signifies acute gastritis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old nulliparous woman presents to you with primary infertility. On examination, stage 2 uterine prolapse is present. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse, who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing function

Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy - cervical supports are fixed to the abdominal wall
  • Shirodkar’s sling operation - cervix is fixed to the lumbosacral fascia using Mersilene tape
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation - isthmus of the cervix is fixed to the anterior superior iliac spines. It is not done anymore due to the risk of periosteitis. 
  • Virkud's sling operation - the tape is fixed from the isthmus and attached to the rectus compartment 
  • Joshi's sling operation - the uterus is suspended from the pectineal ligaments.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Category Treatment
Nulliparous or congenital prolapse 

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation
Pregnancy and postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks period of gestation)
  • Pelvic floor exercises
<40 years            
  • Fothergill's repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar's procedure
>40 years - with completed family  Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair 
>60 years - unfit for surgery 
  • Le Fort's repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with papillary thyroid carcinoma developed a palpable lymph node in the suprasternal space of Burns. Which of the following structures is not closely related to these metastatic lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
The external jugular vein is not present in the suprasternal space of Burns. It is present in the supraclavicular space, along with the supraclavicular nerve.

Contents of the suprasternal space of Burns include:

  • The jugular venous arch, formed by the anterior jugular veins
  • Sternal head of right and left sternocleidomastoid
  • Lymph nodes
  • Interclavicular ligament.

Investing layer of deep fascia encloses:

  • 2 muscles - sternocleidomastoid, trapezius
  • 2 glands - parotid and submandibular gland
  • 2 spaces - suprasternal space and supraclavicular space
  • 2 ligaments - stylomandibular and sphenomandibular ligament

The supraclavicular space includes:

  • Supraclavicular nerve
  • External jugular vein

questions.text: A 50-year-old previously healthy man presents to the clinic with complaints of episodic palpitations, sweating, and giddiness which are relieved with food or fruit juices. Laboratory investigations are suggestive of insulinoma. Which of the following will be the best imaging modality to localize the site of the tumor in this patient?
questions.solution:
Intra-operative ultrasound is the best method in localizing the site of the insulinoma. 

This is a dynamic imaging modality that provides interactive and timely information during surgical procedures. This is essential for the identification of small tumors, especially within the pancreatic head or uncinate process.

Preoperatively, the site of the tumor can be assessed by endoscopic ultrasound or CT scan.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic man has been prescribed empagliflozin. Which of the following processes will most likely be affected by this drug?
questions.solution:
Empagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor. SGLT-2 or sodium-glucose transport protein 2 is an example of a cotransporter that plays a key role in glucose absorption from renal tubule by secondary active transport. This process is blocked by SGLT-2 inhibitors, leading to renal loss of glucose and improved glycemic control.

  • A special property of the transport protein involved in secondary active transport is that a conformational change to allow Na+ movement to the interior will not occur until a glucose molecule also attaches to the transport protein. When they both become attached, the conformational change takes place automatically, and the Na+ and glucose are transported to the inside of the cell at the same time.
  • The figure shows glucose is transported uphill and Na+ is transported downhill. Energy derived from the downhill movement of Na+ is maintained by the Na+-K+ ATPase pump on the basolateral side.

questions.text:
What is the investigation of choice for evaluating posterior urethral valves in a newborn male?

MCU - MIcturating cystourethrography; Tc DTPA - Tecnetitium-99m Diethylenetriamine Pentaacetate; DMSA - Dimercaptosuccinic acid
questions.solution:
Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) or micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) is the best imaging technique for diagnosing posterior urethral valves.

Posterior urethral valves result from forming a thick, valve-like membrane from a tissue of Wolffian duct origin (failure of regression of the mesonephric duct). This membrane courses obliquely from the verumontanum to the most distal portion of the prostatic urethra. They act as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow.

Diagnosis is most commonly made antenatally with ultrasound. However, the diagnosis is best made during the micturition phase of VCUG in lateral or oblique views so that the posterior urethra can be imaged adequately. The following findings are seen:

  • Dilatation and elongation of the posterior urethra - the equivalent of the ultrasonographic keyhole sign (as shown in the image below). 
  • Linear radiolucent band corresponding to the valve - seen occasionally. 
  • Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) - seen in 50% of patients. 
  • Bladder trabeculation/ diverticula.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old lady presented with polydipsia and polyuria. Her symptoms started soon after a road traffic accident 6 months ago. Her blood pressure was recorded at 120/80 mmHg with no postural drop. The daily urinary output was reported to be between 6-8 liters. Clinical investigation results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Na = 130 mEq /L 

K = 3.5 mEq/ L

Urea = 15 mg/dl

Sugar = 65 mg/ dl

Plasma osmolality = 268 mOsm/L

Urine osmolality = 45 mOsm/L
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for the given clinical scenario would be psychogenic polydipsia.

The normal range of urine osmolality is 500-850 mOsm/L and that of plasma osmolality is 280-295 mOsm/L. Hence in the given scenario, both urine and plasma osmolality are low, along with hyponatremia suggestive of psychogenic polydipsia.

Condition

Plasma osmolality

Urine osmolality

Sodium concentration

Central and nephrogenic DI

High

Low

Hypernatremia

Psychogenic polydipsia

Low

Low

 Hyponatremia

SIADH and cerebral salt wasting

Low

High

Hyponatremia

questions.text: A microbiologist is about to run a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay on the serum of a patient suspected to have Q fever. He wishes to quantify the PCR by monitoring the amplification process while the PCR is ongoing. Which of the following types of PCR should he perform?
questions.solution:
Real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) can be used to quantify the PCR by monitoring the amplification process while the PCR is ongoing. 

Polymerase chain reaction is a rapid method used to amplify specific DNA sequences. It consists of several cycles of sequential DNA replication. Types of PCR include:

  • Reverse transcriptase PCR- The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complementary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR.
  • Real-time PCR- This helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR)
  • Multiplex PCR- Primers to more than one pathogen are used simultaneously and hence multiple products are obtained. 
  • Nested PCR- It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the amplicon obtained is then used as a target sequence for second amplification. This ensures specificity.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme deficiency most commonly causes the disease shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows a child with albinism and is due to a deficiency of copper-containing enzyme tyrosinase causing a defect in melanin production. The affected child has milky white hair and milky white skin.

In untreated phenylketonuria, the baby looks normal at birth, with a skin and hair color lighter than other members of the family. Later, the child has blonde hair, skin with a light complexion, and blue irides. Manifestations are not so severe as in OCA. The image shows an infant with white hair, so albinism is the best choice.

Note - Tyrosine hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of catecholamines. Tyrosine is first hydroxylated to form 3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) by the enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase. This enzyme is abundant in the central nervous system, the sympathetic ganglia, and the adrenal medulla.

Related Pearl: Amino acid Enzymatic Disorders and the Associated Enzymes

questions.text: You are asked to auscultate a patient presenting with chronic cough. Which of the following is not a boundary of the triangle of auscultation?
questions.solution:
The serratus anterior is not a boundary of the triangle of auscultation. As there are fewer impedances between the examiner's stethoscope and the lungs, this area allows for better auscultation of the patient. 

Boundaries of the triangle of auscultation:

  • Medially- trapezius muscle’s lateral border
  • Laterally- scapula’s medial border
  • Inferiorly- lattssisimus dorsi’s upper border  
  • Floor- 5th and 7th rib, 6th intercostal space, and the rhomboid major

The triangle overlies the inferior lobe of both lungs. For exposure of the floor of the triangle, the patient needs to fold their arm across their chest to rotate the scapula laterally and bend forward resembling somewhat a fetal position.

The image given below illustrates the triangle of auscultation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man recovering from COVID-19 presents as follows. His medical and personal histories are insignificant with no exposure to cold. What would you suspect?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of COVID toes. The image shows pernio-like lesions caused due to COVID-19.

Pernio / chilblains are skin lesions on the acral surfaces of the body characterised by the development of erythematous-violaceous or purpuric macules. They may be accompanied by edema and pruritus. 

It is usually due to cold exposure or underlying hematological disorders but has also been reported in patients with COVID-19 disease. The underlying mechanism is thought to be an inflammatory process. The lesions appear late (postviral phase) with the patients exhibiting positive  IgM/ IgG antibodies for SARS-CoV-2 and negative RT-PCR. However, pernio like lesions can also be seen in early stages of the disease when the patients are still infective. 

There are no treatment guidelines but high-potency topical corticosteroids may be helpful if the lesions are causing discomfort. Other cutaneous manifestations include exanthematous rash, livedo reticularis, urticaria, MIS-C etc.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman had an autonomic neuropathy that disrupted the sympathetic nerve supply to the pupillary dilator muscle of her right eye. While having her eyes examined, the ophthalmologist placed a sympathomimetic drug in both her eyes. The right eye became much more dilated than the left  eye. This suggests that:

choices.text: The sympathetic nerve to the right eye had regenerated
The parasympathetic nerve supply to the right eye remained intact and compensated for the loss of the sympathetic nerve
The left eye also had nerve damage and so was not responding as expected

questions.solution:
Denervation supersensitivity develops in the muscle after the nerve supplying it is cut. Since the nerve to her right dilator pupillae is damaged, the right eye becomes excessively sensitive to the sympathomimetic drug. So, the right eye becomes much more dilated than the left.

Denervation Supersensitivity:

  • When the motor nerve to skeletal muscle is degenerated, the muscle gradually becomes extremely sensitive to acetylcholine. This is called denervation hypersensitivity or supersensitivity.
  • Normally nicotinic receptors are located only in the vicinity of the motor endplate where the axon of the motor nerve terminates. When the motor nerve is severed, there is a marked proliferation of nicotinic receptors over a wide region of the neuromuscular junction.
  • Denervation supersensitivity also occurs at autonomic junctions. Smooth muscle, unlike skeletal muscle, does not atrophy when denervated, but it becomes hyperresponsive to the chemical mediator that normally activates it.
  • This hyperresponsiveness can be demonstrated by using pharmacologic tools rather than actual nerve section. Prolonged use of a drug such as reserpine can be used to deplete transmitter stores and prevent the target organ from being exposed to norepinephrine for an extended period. Once the drug usage is stopped, smooth muscle and cardiac muscle will be supersensitive to subsequent release of the neurotransmitter.

Option a) If the symapthetic nerve would have regenerated, both right and left eye would have been equally sensitive to the drug and so, would have dilated equally.

Option b) Parasympathetic nerves supply the spinchter pupillae muscle. So, if stimulated they would constrict the eye not dilate it. Also, the drug added was a sympathomimetic agent. So, parasympathetic nerves are not stimulated in the first place

Option d) If the left eye was damaged, it would also have denervation supersensitivity. Again, both eyes would dilate equally, but more than that of normal.

questions.text: A 55-year-old multiparous woman who presented with chronic lower abdominal pain has been diagnosed with chronic PID. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for an old multiparous woman with chronic PID is abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

A radical hysterectomy involves the removal of the whole uterus, tissue from the sides of the uterus, the cervix, and the upper part of the vagina. It is generally done only in cancer patients.

A supracervical hysterectomy involves the removal of only the body of the uterus and is not done in chronic PID. It is done for the treatment of endometriosis, uterine fibroids, and uterine prolapse.

Related Pearl: Treatment of choice in chronic PID

Patient characteristics

Choice of surgery

Young woman

Conservative surgery or Salpingectomy or Salpingo-oophorectomy

When extensive damage precludes conservative management

and

When the patient is multiparous and of an older age group

Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

Mild case of PID adequately treated

and

Minimal damage but the infection may lead to infertility

Tuboplasty

questions.text: A baby was delivered at home in a village. Until which day of life should an ASHA worker visit this baby?
questions.solution:
Under the Home Based Newborn Care (HBNC) guidelines, ASHA workers should visit all newborns up to 42 days of life, according to the following schedule. 

Mode of delivery No. of visits Schedule of visits
Home delivery 7 Days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 42
Hospital-based normal vaginal delivery 6

Days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 42

(except day 1)
Hospital-based LSCS delivery 5

Days 7, 14, 21, 28, 42

(except days 1, 3)

During her visits, ASHA workers must record weight, ensure vaccination, and registration of births. On completion of all these visits, they receive an incentive of Rs. 250. 

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with facial asymmetry. On examination, there is loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, absent acoustic reflex, and normal Schirmer test. What is the site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The site of lesion in this patient with loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue and absent acoustic reflex is at the tympanic segment.

Injury to the greater superficial petrosal nerve leads to loss of lacrimation which is detected by the Schirmer test. It is the first branch given at the level of the geniculate ganglion.

Injury to the nerve to stapedius, the first motor branch of the facial nerve, leads to loss of stapedial reflex and hyperacusis, which can be detected by tympanometry.

Injury to chorda tympani nerve leads to loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue which is detected by electrogustometry and reduced submandibular and sublingual salivary flow detected by salivary flow test.

So in this patient, the lesion is proximal to the origin of nerve to stapedius i.e. tympanic segment, and not proximal to geniculate ganglion as the lacrimation is normal.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man suffering from uncontrolled diabetes mellitus came for a routine checkup. His lipid profile revealed increased TG (triacylglycerol) and VLDL (very low-density lipoprotein). What is the cause of this abnormal lipid profile?

choices.text: Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase
Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity
Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors
Increased in activity of hepatic lipase

questions.solution:
In chronic diabetes, the values of TG and VLDL are increased due to an increase in hormone-sensitive lipase and a decrease in lipoprotein lipase.

Insulin has an inhibitory effect on hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). In diabetes, low insulin corresponds to an increase in HSL activity. This promotes the breakdown of lipids and the release of TG and free fatty acids from the adipose tissue.

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) which is present on the capillary walls. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TG and the degradation of the transport proteins, VLDL, and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity which corresponds to an increase in VLDL and TG.

Related Pearl: Hormone sensitive lipase Vs lipoprotein lipase

   HSL  Lipoprotein lipase
Location  Adipocyte  Capillaries
Action  Hydrolyse TAG in adipose   tissue  Hydrolyse TAG in chylomicron , VLDL
Acts in the state of  Fasting (Glucagon)  Fed (Insulin)

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with a complaint of recurrent abortions. Upon investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective procedures has the best obstetric outcome?
questions.solution:
Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.

The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving obstetric outcomes.

Metroplasty is the surgical resection of the intrauterine septum. This is done by approaching the uterus transabdominally via 3 methods:

  • Jones metroplasty
  • Strassmann metroplasty
  • Tompkins metroplasty

All of these methods are not preferred nowadays as they cause uterine scarring. 

 

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman came to the surgeon with a thyroid swelling that had developed a year ago. On examination, the swelling was 3 cm in size, firm and immobile. Further, lymphadenopathy was present. A biopsy of the swelling is given below. Which of the following is incorrect regarding management and post-op care in this condition?

choices.text: Thyroxine is withheld after the surgery

questions.solution:
The given histological image depicts papillary formation with a fibrovascular stalk, characteristic orphan annie eye nuclei and psammoma bodies, diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.
Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection would be the appropriate management in this condition, because there is lymphadenopathy, although the tumour size is less than 4 cm.

Surgical management of differentiated thyroid cancers (DTCs) is as follows:

Extent of cancer Surgery done

Low-risk DTC
(Fulfilling all 5 of the following conditions)

  1. < 40 years (better prognosis)
  2. Unifocal lesion
  3. Size ~ 1-4 cm
  4. No lymphovascular invasion
  5. No capsular invasion
 Hemithyroidectomy

High-risk DTC without LN involvement / not fulfilling any of the above 5 conditions

 Total thyroidectomy

High-risk DTC + level VI LN involved

 Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection

High-risk DTC + other LNs involved

 Total thyroidectomy + Modified radical neck dissection

 

The other options:
Option 1: Post thyroidectomy, calcium supplementation is given to all patients to prevent hypocalcemia.
Option 2: Prophylactic neck dissection is done for papillary carcinoma thyroid
Option 3: Thyroid hormone replacement is not given to patients who are to receive radioactive iodine therapy within 2 to 3 weeks of surgery. The absence of thyroid hormones raises the TSH, which stimulates the radioactive iodine uptake.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: Select the wrongly matched pair of excipients and vaccines.
questions.solution:
Formaldehyde is not used in the BCG vaccine. It is used in IPV and diphtheria and tetanus vaccines. 

Excipients (other vaccine constituents) include: Adjuvants: serve to enhance the immune reaction to the vaccine , Stabilizers : stabilize and prolong the shelf-life of the vaccine  and 

Preservatives : preserve the components. Some examples are listed below:

  • As stabilizing agents-
    • MgCl2 - OPV
    • MgSO4 - measles
    • Lactose-sorbitol and sorbitol-gelatine
  • To prevent microbial growth and contamination-
    • Thiomersal- DPT, hepatitis B, Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), rabies, influenza, and meningococcal diseases. It contains very small amounts of organic mercury.
    • Neomycin- MMR and IPV
  • Other preservatives-
    • 2-phenoxyethanol - IPV
    • Phenol - Typhoid vaccine

questions.text:
A 33-year-old with a large dirty wound on his knee and abrasions on his palms presents to the casualty. He does not remember the last time he received a TT injection and was thus given tetanus immunoglobulin. Which of the following is false about this type of immunity?

TT- Tetanus Toxoid
questions.solution:
Giving pre-formed immunoglobulin (e.g. Tetanus immunoglobulin) directly is an example of passive immunity, which is not long-lasting. 

The differentiating features between active and passive immunity:

Active Immunity

Passive Immunity

Actively produced by the host’s immune system

Passively received by the host

Induced by infection or immunogens

Readymade antibody is transferred

Immunological memory present

No memory 

Immunity is effective after a lag period or latent period

Immediate immunity

Broad specificity

Narrow specificity

A negative phase may occur 

No negative phase. 

Booster effect on subsequent dose

The subsequent dose is less effective

Secondary type response seen 

No secondary type of response

More effective

Less effective 

Long-lasting (Years)

Short-lasting (Days to weeks)

Example: Vaccines

Example: Antisera 

Negative phase: It is the time period during which the level of measurable immunity is lower than it was before the antigenic stimulus. This is because the antigen combines with any pre-existing antibody and lowers its level in circulation. It is seen at the beginning of the active immune response.

Secondary type response: If an individual who has been actively immunized against an antigen experiences the same antigen subsequently, the immune response occurs more quickly and abundantly than during the first encounter.

Related Pearl: Innate and Adaptive Immunity

Innate immunity

Adaptive immunity

Immediate maximal response

Lag phase between exposure and maximal response

Non-specific

Highly pathogen-specific

Limited diversity

Extensively diverse

No memory

Memory present

Subsequent exposure → Amplified response

Receptors: Pattern-recognition receptors

Receptors: T-cell and B-cell receptors

questions.text: A 58-year-old man died 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm. On autopsy, an atheromatous plaque was seen obstructing the left anterior descending artery. Which type of calcification is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Atheromatous plaques are associated with dystrophic calcification. This is seen in the presence of normal calcium levels in the serum.

The deposition of calcium in dead or dying tissues is called dystrophic calcification. Although it occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium, it can be worsened by hypercalcemia.

Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type. Some examples include atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis and areas of caseous necrosis in tuberculosis.

Related Pearl: Types of calcifications

  Dystrophic calcification Metastatic calcification
Location Dead and dying tissues Normal interstitial tissues of the vasculature, kidneys, lungs, and gastric mucosa.
Calcium metabolism Normal deranged causing hypercalcemia
Examples

Calcific valvular stenosis

Advanced Atheromatous plaque

Monckeberg medial sclerosis

Parathyroid tumors

Hypercalcemia of malignancy

Paget disease

vitamin D intoxication

Sarcoidosis

Renal failure

questions.text:
A second autopsy is performed in which of the following scenarios?
  1. The relatives are not satisfied with the first autopsy report
  2. The first autopsy was not performed in the light of the circumstances which are now available
  3. The investigating authority demands a second autopsy
  4. The first autopsy was done in the absence of the investigating officer
  5. The first autopsy was done in the absence of relatives
questions.solution:
A second autopsy may be performed when relatives are not satisfied, new circumstances emerge, or investigating officer demands it.

After an autopsy, when a repeat medicolegal postmortem is performed with the authorization by law it is called a second autopsy.

The magistrate/commissioner of the police vested with such power, orders the second autopsy.

A second autopsy may be performed in the following cases:

  • The relatives of the deceased are not satisfied with the first autopsy report and they have pointed out certain lapses in the first autopsy.
  • The first autopsy was not performed in the light of the circumstances which are now available.
  • The investigating authority demands a second autopsy for setting the investigation on the right track.

questions.text: Which anesthetic agent does not undergo metabolism in our body?
questions.solution:
Nitrous oxide does not undergo any metabolism in our body.

Methoxyflurane undergoes maximum metabolism while desflurane undergoes minimal metabolism.

questions.text: All of the following supply the marked structure except :
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the right ventricle. It is not supplied by the diagonal artery.

The diagonal artery is a branch of the anterior interventricular artery supplying the left ventricle. This is present in about 30-50% of the population.

The right ventricle is mostly supplied by the right coronary artery and its branches such as the marginal artery.

The anterior interventricular artery gives off 1-2 anterior right ventricular branches.

questions.text: The following image shows the picture of the fundus in a patient taken 48 hours after sustaining severe head trauma. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows multiple cotton wool spots around the disc. This is Purtschers' retinopathy, which is classically associated with severe head injury. 

It is also seen in pancreatitis and chest trauma due to fat/air embolism. Ophthalmoscopy reveals multiple, variably sized cotton-wool spots and intraretinal hemorrhages around the optic nerve. There is no effective treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not found in a shotgun ammunition?
questions.solution:
A shotgun cartridge does not have a metal cylinder. It has a metal base, but the cylinder is made of cardboard.

The ammunition for the shotgun is a cartridge made of a cardboard or plastic cylinder fitted into a metal base. The base carries a percussion detonator that is struck by the spring-loaded firing pin when the trigger is pulled. The primer is located in the percussion cup and contains the detonator. The cartridge contains a charge of propellant (gunpowder), above which are ‘wads’ or pistons of felt, cardboard or plastic discs, or both. Above these is the charge of shot (pellets), which varies greatly in number and size, finally covered by a card or plastic disc.

The image given below shows a shotgun cartridge.

The ammunition of a rifled weapon has a metal cylinder, closed at one end, which is the shell or cartridge. The cylinder carries a percussion detonator in the base, either centrally or peripherally. The shell is loaded with an explosive propellant such as nitrocellulose and the bullet is firmly clamped into the open end.

The image given below shows the cartridge of a rifled gun.

questions.text: After assessing a patient with a traumatic head injury, a score of 3 was given for motor response. According to the Glasgow Coma Scale, what does the score indicate?
questions.solution:
Motor response of 3 indicates decorticate posture or abnormal flexion to pain stimulus.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with craniotabes, rachitic rosary and bowed legs. Diagnosis of rickets was made. To investigate the cause of rickets and to find the status of vitamin D in the body, which of the following should be measured?
questions.solution:
Measurement of 25 hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol) provides more accurate information about vitamin D levels. 

PTH is increased in vitamin D deficiency. PTH is a major stimulus for the 1α-hydroxylase, so there is increased synthesis of the active hormone, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. Paradoxically, levels of this hormone are often normal in severe vitamin D deficiency. Therefore, measurements of 1,25- dihydroxyvitamin D are not accurate reflections of vitamin D stores and should not be used to diagnose vitamin D deficiency in patients with normal renal function.

questions.text: Sample from a patient with bleeding PV at 30 weeks showed a positive Apt test. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Apt test is an alkali denaturation test to detect fetal haemoglobin (HbF). It is positive in vasa previa and Rh incompatibility.

Apt test is based on the principle that HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation, while HbA is not. It is done by taking the blood sample in a test tube containing water and adding 10% NaOH. Maternal blood turns yellow-brown, while fetal blood remains pink in the test tube.

Bleeding due to vasa previa must be managed immediately with an emergency caesarean section. Hence, Apt test is not practically done in all cases.

Other options: Bleeding due to cervical polyp, placenta previa, and abruptio placenta is of maternal origin. So, Apt test will be negative in these cases.

questions.text: Colonoscopy and biopsy on a 35-year-old man revealed hundreds of adenomatous polyps in the entire descending and sigmoid colon. Options for prophylactic surgery are discussed. Which of the following procedures will reduce the occurrence of malignancy the most?

choices.text: Total colectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis
Total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is diagnostic of familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome. To prevent an occurrence of cancer, total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis is the management of choice. This procedure is usually accompanied by resection of the rectal mucosa.

Following surgery, the patient has to be routinely followed up for ileoanal-pouch surveillance. Upper GI endoscopy should also be performed to evaluate for the presence of duodenal adenomas.

questions.text: A patient is to be started on a cephalosporin antibiotic. His serum creatinine levels yesterday at the time of admission was 1.1 mg/dl and now it is 1.5 mg/dl. Which of the following cephalosporins can be started without dose reduction in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of acute kidney injury and the cephalosporin that does not require dose reduction in this patient is cefoperazone.

All cephalosporins are usually excreted by glomerular filtration and tubular secretion. They need a dose reduction in renal failure, except cefpiramide and cefoperazone that have predominant biliary excretion.

Dose reduction is necessary for cefoperazone and cefpiramide in patients with hepatic impairment.

questions.text: In the 2 vessels shown below, assume the pressure along both the vessels is the same and both follow linear flow pattern. What will be the amount of blood flow in A compared to B
questions.solution:
The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed mathematically in the formula called as Poiseuille's law :

Blood flow (F) inside the vessel depends on: 

  • Pressure difference: directly proportional
  • Viscosity: inversely proportional
  • Radius: directly proportional to the fourth power
  • Length of the vessel: inversely proportional

Here, the radius is doubled so the flow increases by 2 to the power of 4 = 16. 

the length of the vessel is also doubled, so the flow decreases by half (÷2) = 8

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the procedure shown below?

choices.text: Compression/distraction at fracture site enhances osteogenesis
The rate of compression or distraction is 2 mm per day
K wire is required for this procedure
Nerve palsy is a complication of the procedure

questions.solution:
The above radiograph depicts the lengthening of the limb using Ilizarov apparatus. The rate of compression/distraction is 1 mm per day, not 2 mm per day.

Ilizarov's technique is based on the principle of distraction osteogenesis. This is the mechanical induction of new bone which occurs between bony surfaces that are gradually pulled apart. Compression and distraction at the fracture site enhance osteogenesis.

A careful fracture of the bone is performed, followed by a short wait. The young callus formed is gradually distracted using a circular or unilateral external fixator system called a ring fixator. Transfixing thin Kirschner wires (K-wires) are the key components of the Ilizarov fixator regarding its axial stiffness. This affects the mechanobiological environment in which the bone heals.

Distraction or compression can be applied by twisting nuts on the fixation system at the fracture or corticotomy site. Distraction or compression is carried out at the rate of 1 mm per day. 

The uses of Ilizarov's apparatus are as follows:

  • Limb lengthening
  • Non-union
  • Deformity correction
  • Osteomyelitis - as it offers the possibility of liberal excision of bone
  • Arthrodesis - crushing articular surfaces can stimulate union between opposing bones

Disadvantages of this technique include pin tract infection, nerve palsy, and joint stiffness.

The below images show the Ilizarov apparatus and an illustration of distraction osteogenesis.

questions.text: Chotu, a 5-year-old boy is on regular outpatient follow-up for growth hormone deficiency diagnosed 2 weeks back. He is planned for recombinant growth hormone therapy. All of the following are possible side effects except-
questions.solution:
The use of recombinant growth hormone is associated with the risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (not type 1 diabetes mellitus).

Other adverse effects:

  • Pseudotumor cerebri
  • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
  • Gynecomastia
  • Worsening of scoliosis

Children who have been treated with rhGH have a higher risk of developing hemorrhagic strokes in adulthood.
Some studies show an increased risk of new neoplasms in cancer survivors.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of inability to move his 4th and 5th digit, cannot hold a pen and he was not able to hold a paper between fingers. Which of the following sites given below is the probable cause of injury to the nerve in question?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests an ulnar nerve injury. The most likely site of injury would thus be medial epicondyle (marked as C)

Tests for ulnar nerve lesions are as follows:

  • Card test positive
  • Claw hand deformity
  • Froment's sign positive
  • Wartenberg sign
  • Palmaris brevis sign

Positive card test is due to weakness of palmar interrosei, causing loss of adduction. As a result, the patient is unable to hold the card firmly between his or her fingers.

Option A: It is the radial groove where radial nerve runs along with profunda brachii artery.

Option D: It is the neck of humerus where axillary nerve runs around.

Option B: It is the lateral epicondyle. Fracture of this part may lead to tardy ulnar nerve palsy, but incidence is less.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding tracking of blood pressure?

choices.text: BP increases with age in all individuals
BP falls steadily in the elderly
Hypertensive children become hypotensive as they grow
BP of hypotensive children tends to remain low in adult life

questions.solution:
If the blood pressure of individuals is followed up over years from early childhood to adult life, low blood pressures tend to remain low and high blood pressures become higher as the individuals grow older. This phenomenon of persistence of the rank order of blood pressure is described as tracking.

This is helpful in identifying children and adolescents who are at risk of developing hypertension in the future.

Although blood pressure is known to increase with age in both sexes, some communities have been identified whose mean blood pressure does not rise with age. This is because their salt intake and calorie consumption are at a subsistence level.

questions.text: In the case of rape of a young child, the hymen is usually:

choices.text: Ruptured since it is superficially situated
Ruptured since it is very thin
Unruptured since it is deeply situated
Unruptured since it is highly elastic

questions.solution:
In the case of a young child, the hymen is deeply situated and usually intact after intercourse. As the vagina is very small, it is impossible for the penetration of the adult organ to take place.

In children, there are few or no signs of general violence, as the child is unaware of the assault and incapable of resisting. A few indicators for inquiry are:

  • Pain on urination and/or defecation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Inability to sleep
  • Sudden withdrawal from peers/adults
  • Feelings of anxiety
  • Nervousness
  • Helplessness
  • A feeling of ending one’s life

questions.text: You would classify all of the following patients as having major risk factors for severe COVID-19 except:

choices.text: A 19 year old female undergoing dialysis for CKD
A 49 year old male who has recently undergone liver transplantation
A  42 year old man who had malaria 2 months ago
A  65  year old male with no comorbidities

questions.solution:
A middle-aged man who had malaria 2 months ago is not at major risk of developing severe COVID-19 disease.

The major risk factors for severe COVID-19 are: 

  • Increasing age (>60 years) 
  • Underlying non-communicable diseases       
    • Cardiac disease 
    • Chronic lung disease 
    • Cerebrovascular disease 
    • Hypertension
    • Diabetes
    • Obesity
    • Chronic kidney disease
    • Immune suppression
    • Cancer

questions.text:
A newborn baby develops severe umbilical cord bleeding soon after birth. Lab investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Bleeding time - normal

Platelet count - normal

PT - normal

aPTT - normal

TT - normal

Urea lysis test - positive
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of factor XIII deficiency. A positive urea lysis test confirms the diagnosis.

Factor XIII is also known as clot-stabilizing factor that converts unstable fibrin clot into a stable clot. Its deficiency typically presents as excessive umbilical cord bleeding in the newborn.

Laboratory findings in this condition are:

  • Normal levels of bleeding time (BT), platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), and thrombin time (TT)
  • Positive urea lysis test - confirmatory test which demonstrates lysis of clot by hyperosmolar urea in affected individuals

The parameters for the given diseases:

Condition PT aPTT BT TT Platelet count Urea lysis test 
Vitamin K deficiency increased increased increased normal/increased normal/decreased negative
Von Willebrand disease normal normal/increased increased normal normal negative
Hemorrhagic disease of newborn increased increased increased normal/increased normal/decreased negative
Factor XIII deficiency normal normal normal normal normal positive

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be depicted by the image given below?

choices.text: Rural - urban distributions of a disease

questions.solution:
The given image is of a spot map. Spot maps are not used to depict rural-urban distributions of a disease. They help to understand the local distributions of a disease.

They are also called shaded maps. This method was used by John Snow to investigate the epidemic of cholera in London in 1854. They depict areas of high or low frequency, the boundaries, and patterns of disease distribution.

questions.text: A 32-year-old professional boxer was brought to the emergency department following a blow to the abdomen. On examination, his vitals were normal, and his abdomen was tender on palpation. Which among the following is the best modality to assess the injury to the abdominal organs for this patient?
questions.solution:
A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the best diagnostic modality (gold standard) for stable patients with blunt trauma to the abdomen.

It is a non-invasive and sensitive investigation. It can identify haemorrhage, intraabdominal as well as retroperitoneal organ injury. However, performing CECT is time-consuming (when compared to FAST) and therefore it can be used only in stable patients.

FAST ultrasound is a limited examination directed to look for intraperitoneal fluid or pericardial injury as a marker of the underlying injury. The best imaging modality for hemodynamically unstable patients with blunt trauma of the abdomen is FAST.

questions.text:
Which of the following features in a patient would prompt you to anticipate a difficult intubation?
  1. Mallampati class 4 airway
  2. Thyromental distance of 7.8 cm with neck extension
  3. Neck circumference of 17.5 inches
  4. Ability to extend neck at the atlantooccipital joint
  5. A history of previous difficult intubation
questions.solution:
The following are indicators of difficult intubation:

  • Mallampati class 3 and 4 airways
  • Thyromental distance <6cm with neck extension
  • Neck circumference >17 inches in men and 16 inches in women
  • An inability to extend the neck at the atlantooccipital joint
  • A history of previous difficult intubation.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: During your casualty rotation, you accidentally injure yourself while suturing a patient. You had taken the full schedule of hepatitis B vaccination during your first year of medical school. Which of the following markers will you get measured to determine the need for HBIG administration?
questions.solution:
The need for administration of hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin (HBIG) in a previously vaccinated individual can be determined based on anti-HBsAg levels. It is the marker for determining the efficacy of hepatitis B vaccination.

The complete hepatitis B vaccine schedule consists of three intramuscular doses at 0, 1, and 6 months.

Post Exposure Prophylaxis:

The prophylaxis can be done using the hepatitis B vaccine or hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG).

Vaccination status of the exposed person Recommended prophylaxis
Unvaccinated HBIG (0.06 mL/kg) and initiate hepatitis B vaccine series
Known responder to previous vaccination (anti-HBs titer>10 mIU/ml) No action required
Non-responder to previous vaccination (anti-HBs titre <10 mIU/ml) HBIG: 2 doses (1 month apart) OR HBIG: 1 dose + initiate hepatitis B revaccination.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - +/- +/- IgM +

Acute HBV - recovery phase

-

 + - +/- IgG +/-
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG +

HBV infection in the recent past

 - + - - IgG -

HBV infection in the remote past

 - - - +/- IgG -

Post-vaccination

 - + - - - -

questions.text: In a patient who is under anaesthesia, which is the most common method used to evaluate intraoperative awareness?
questions.solution:
The bispectral index (BIS) is the most commonly used method, which helps to monitor the depth of anaesthesia and intraoperative awareness.

It processes the EEG and provides an index value between 0 and 100 that indicates the patient’s level of consciousness.

BIS index range: 

  • 100– Awake (Response to normal voice)
  • 65-85- Sedation
  • 40-65- General anaesthesia
  • < 40 - Cortical suppression
  • 0- Flatline EEG (Deep coma)

Recommended range of BIS index values for anaesthesia- 40-60.

questions.text: Combined use of ACE inhibitors and ARBs are not routinely indicated primarily due to the increased risk of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The combined use of ACE inhibitors and ARBs are not commonly indicated as they increase the risk of hyperkalemia. 

They also increase the risk of hypotension and renal injury. Any such use should be done under the supervision of specialists with frequent monitoring.

questions.text: A young patient presents with loss of central vision. There is a family history of a similar condition. Both EOG and ERG are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given scenario is Stargardt's disease.

Stargardt's disease also known as Stargardt macular dystrophy or fundus flavimaculatus is the most common macular dystrophy. It most commonly is inherited in an autosomal-recessive manner caused by a mutation on an adenosine triphosphate-binding cassette (ABCA4) gene.

Characterized by macular "pisciform" flecks that accumulate at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), sometimes resulting in central macular atrophy early in life. Patients develop a macula with a “beaten bronze” appearance caused by atrophic changes in the RPE. In addition, a "dark" or "silent" choroid is seen on the fluorescein angiography that appears as a prominent retinal circulation against hypofluorescent choroid. 

The electroretinogram (ERG) and electro-oculography (EOG) are normal early in the disease but may be reduced in more advanced cases. Of note, the ERG findings do not directly correlate with clinical findings.

There is no known proven treatment for this disease. Because ABCA4 plays a role in vitamin A processing in the visual cycle, additional vitamin A is suspected to make the disease worse.

The image below shows macular pisciform flecks.

Other options: 

Option A: Retinitis pigmentosa: abnormal electroretinogram (ERG).

Option B: Rod–cone dystrophy: abnormal ERG.

Option D: Best's disease: Normal ERG with abnormal electrooculogram (EOG).

questions.text: Identify the marked ECG feature in a patient diagnosed with ventricular tachycardia.
questions.solution:
The ECG feature of ventricular tachycardia seen in the given image is a fusion beat. It occurs when a sinus and ventricular beat coincide to produce a hybrid complex.

Ventricular tachycardia (VT) is defined as ≥ 3 consecutive premature ventricular contractions at a rate of >100/min. It is characterized by:

  • Wide QRS complex
  • AV dissociation- Atrial activity independent of ventricular activity, seen on the ECG as every p wave not followed by QRS complex
  • Fusion beats- occur when a sinus and ventricular beat coincide to produce a hybrid complex
  • Capture beats occur when the SA node transiently ‘captures’ the ventricles, that is, ventricles are depolarized by the impulses from the SA node producing a QRS complex of normal duration.

The given ECG shows a fusion beat (red arrow), and a capture beat (green arrow) can also be seen:

 

The given image shows capture beats in VT:

 

Option C: Polymorphic QRS, that is, continuously changing QRS morphology is seen in polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.

Option D: Triphasic QRS (eg. RSR′ pattern on V1) is seen in supraventricular tachycardias with the wide QRS complex.

questions.text: Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of _____________
questions.solution:
Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy.

Primary abdominal pregnancy is the rarest type of ectopic gestation. The conceptus implants on the peritoneal surface of the abdomen.

Studdiford’s criteria:

  1. The presence of normal bilateral tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past pregnancy.
  2. No evidence of a uteroperitoneal fistula.
  3. The presence of pregnancy, related exclusively to the peritoneal surface, early enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation

Criteria used in the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy are:

  • Cervical pregnancy: Paalman and McElin (clinical criteria); Rubin's criteria (histological criteria)
  • Ovarian pregnancy: Spiegelberg’s criteria

Although the incidence of abdominal pregnancy is only 1 in 10,000, diagnosis at the earliest is of utmost importance due to the possible complications. The classic ultrasound finding is the absence of myometrial tissue between the maternal bladder and the conceptus.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presents with fever, cough with scanty sputum, and fatigue. He had a throat infection a week ago. His blood investigations and chest X-ray are given below. Which is the most likely causative agent for his condition?
Parameter Values
Hb 8.3 g/dl
LDH 560 U/L
AST 23 IU/L
ALT 24 IU/L
Unconjugated bilirubin 1.8 mg/dl
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with chest X-ray and lab values is suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. The blood investigations show decreased hemoglobin, elevated LDH, and elevated unconjugated bilirubin suggestive of hemolytic anemia. 

Mycoplasma is the most common bacteria causing atypical pneumonia and the second most common cause of pneumonia.

Clinical Presentation: 

  1. Pulmonary manifestations:
    • URTI- tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis
    • Pneumonia( seen in only 10% patients)
  2. Extrapulmonary manifestations:
    • Cold agglutinin disease( IgM mediated autoimmune hemolytic anemia)
    • Erythema multiforme or Steven Johnson syndrome
    • Arthralgia with adenopathy
    • Guillain Barre Syndrome
    • Myocarditis
    • Pericarditis
    • Encephalitis
    • Bullous myringitis

Chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery.

Azithromycin is the drug of choice. Doxycycline is the second-best drug for the management of atypical pneumonia.

questions.text: A 4-month-old child was brought with a history of recurrent episodes of jaundice. Blood investigations were suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis.  Which of the following liver function test findings is likely to be seen here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes recurrent hemolysis in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis leading to jaundice. In hemolytic conditions, only the unconjugated/ indirect bilirubin is raised and conjugated/direct bilirubin remains normal i.e. <15% of total bilirubin.

Bilirubin is synthesized from heme which is released primarily from the breakdown of old RBCs. This bilirubin is in its unconjugated form. It enters the circulation and reaches the liver. It is converted to conjugated bilirubin which is then secreted into the biliary tree.

Therefore, in a healthy person, most of the circulating bilirubin is unconjugated/indirect bilirubin. Hence, the normal liver function tests show indirect bilirubin >85% and direct/conjugated bilirubin <15% of the total bilirubin. The normal bilirubin values are as follows:

  • Total bilirubin levels - 1 to 1.5 mg/dL
  • Direct bilirubin - <0.3 mg/dL

questions.text: A dead body was recovered from a forest. On close examination, maggots were seen crawling on it.  What is the estimated time since the death?
questions.solution:
If a cadaver is recovered in a state of putrefaction and is infested with maggots, the time since death is likely to be 1 to 2 days. 

The rationale of forensic entomology is that after death, invasion of an unprotected body by sarcosaprophagous (feeding on dead and decay) insects comes in successive waves.

Different arthropods colonize the body after death and some species pass through complex life cycles. They can be used to determine at least the minimum time since death by studying the stage of the life cycle of the insects.

Estimated time of death according to fly lifecycle (in summers):

  • Maggots - 1 to 2 days
  • Pupae - 3 to 6 days
  • Adult flies - 6-7 days

In winters, the life cycle can be of 8-20 days.

questions.text: What is the analysis of routine measurements aimed at detecting changes in the health status of a population called?
questions.solution:
The analysis of routine measurements aimed at detecting changes in the health status or environment of a population is called monitoring.

Surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and ill health.

Sentinel surveillance is a method of identifying the missing cases and thereby supplementing the notified cases.

Systematic reviews involve a detailed plan with the goal of reducing bias by identifying, appraising, and synthesizing all relevant studies on a particular topic.

questions.text: A middle-aged diabetic man who had undergone a tooth extraction presents with fever and trismus. On examination, his posterior pillar is pushed medially and there is a swelling in the neck at the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of parapharyngeal abscess.

Parapharyngeal abscess presents with:

  • Trismus due to spasm of medial pterygoid
  • Tonsils pushed medially
  • Swelling in the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid (space limited to the level of hyoid bone).

Option A - Retropharyngeal abscess presents as a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of the midline.

Option C - In Ludwig’s angina, tonsils are not pushed medially.

Option D - Peritonsillar abscess doesn’t produce swelling in the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid.

questions.text: A G3A3 patient was admitted to the hospital with catastrophic APLS following a spontaneous abortion. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is a rapidly progressive thromboembolic disorder
At least 2 organ systems should be involved to make a diagnosis
Infections can act as a trigger
IVIG can be used for treatment

questions.solution:
Catastrophic antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (CAPS) is a complication of APLA syndrome, in which ≥3 organ systems are involved. It is also known as Asherson syndrome.

It is seen in both primary and secondary APLA syndrome. Triggering factors include infections, trauma, and obstetric causes. IVIG can be used in CAPS when the first-line therapies with aspirin and heparin have failed.

Note: Asherman syndrome is an acquired condition characterised by formation of intrauterine adhesions or synechiae.

questions.text: An infant is brought with abdominal distention and increased irritability for 10 days. Physical examination showed jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a boiled cabbage odor. Investigations showed elevated transaminases and succinylacetone. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with abdominal distension, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a boiled cabbage odor is suggestive of type 1 tyrosinemia (tyrosinosis). It is treated by a combination of nitisinone and dietary restriction of phenylalanine and tyrosine.

Type 1 tyrosinemia is the most common form of tyrosinemia caused by defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme. They usually present between 2-6 months of age with acute liver failure. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, and vitamin D-resistant rickets.

An odor resembling boiled cabbage resulting from increased methionine metabolites can be noted. Elevated levels of succinylacetone in blood or urine is diagnostic of type 1 tyrosinemia.

Note: A boiled cabbage odor can also occur in hypermethioninemia.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was found to have an absence of coronary sinus associated with other cardiac defects. Failure in the development of which of the following structures will most likely lead to the given condition?
questions.solution:
The coronary sinus develops from the left horn of the sinus venosus. Hence, its developmental failure will lead to defects of the coronary sinus.

Initially, the communication between the sinus venosus and the atrium is wide. Later, the entrance of the sinus venosus shifts to the right side due to the establishment of left-to-right shunts of blood.

The fate of sinus venosus and its branches near the heart is as follows: 

  • Right horn of sinus venosus gets incorporated into the right atrium
    • Right umbilical vein: obliterates
    • Right common cardinal vein: Becomes part of the superior venacava
    • Right vitelline vein: Becomes the terminal part of inferior venacava 
  • Left horn of sinus venosus reduces in size and becomes the coronary sinus 
    • Left umbilical vein:  obliterates
    • Left common cardinal vein: reduces the size and becomes the oblique vein of the left atrium
    • Left vitelline vein: obliterates

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with Marfanoid features presented with sudden onset breathlessness. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray demonstrating tracheal deviation and displacement of the heart away from the affected side along with the partial collapse of the left lung in the above condition points to a diagnosis of left-sided pneumothorax. 

Marfan's syndrome is one of the causes for seconday spontaneous pneumothorax in adults. 

Pneumothorax refers to the collection of air in the pleural space. 

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Thin, sharp white line, demarcating the visceral pleural edge
  • Absence of lung markings seen peripheral to this line
  • Peripheral space radiolucent compared to adjacent lung 
  • Complete lung collapse, as well as subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum, may be seen
  • Deep sulcus sign (on supine chest radiograph)

Deep sulcus sign: On a supine position(common in the ICU), air collects anteriorly and basally, within the non-dependent portions of the pleural space, abnormally deepening the costophrenic angle. This sign is indicative of pneumothorax in such patients and may be the only visible clue, especially when patient can not be imaged upright.

The image below is plain chest x-ray showing pneumothorax with deep sulcus sign (shown by arrow):

When there is a progressive accumulation of air intrapleurally in the thoracic cavity (caused by a valve effect during inspiration and expiration), it is called Tension pneumothorax. It can result in compression of mediastinal structures and compromise cardiopulmonary function. It is life-threatening and requires emergency intervention.

questions.text: Cytotoxic and expired drugs are disposed by:
questions.solution:
Cytotoxic and expired drugs are collected in a yellow bag and then disposed of by incineration. 

Expired cytotoxic drugs are to be returned to the manufacturer and subjected to incineration, encapsulation, or plasma pyrolysis. Other discarded medicines can be disposed by incineration.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

 

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)  

Type of Waste

  Treatment and Disposal Options

Human anatomical waste

Animal anatomical waste

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial
Soiled Waste: Items like dressings, cotton swabs, and plaster casts contaminated with blood and body fluids and bags containing residual discarded blood.

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial

or

Autoclaving/Microwaving/ Hydroclaving

Later - Shredding/mutilation
Discarded linen, mattresses, beddings contaminated with blood or body fluid, routine masks, and gowns

Non- chlorinated chemical disinfection
followed by incineration or Plazma
Pyrolysis or for energy recovery.
In absence of the above facilities, shredding, mutilation, or a combination of sterilization and shredding is used.

Microbiology, biotechnology, clinical laboratory waste

(Autoclave safe plastic bags used)

Blood bags, laboratory
cultures, stocks or specimens of microorganisms,
