live or attenuated vaccines, human and animal cell cultures used in research, industrial laboratories, production of biological, residual toxins, dishes, and devices used for cultures.

Pre-treatment with nonchlorinated chemicals

Later - Incineration

Expired/discarded medicine, cytotoxic drugs

 Incineration/plasma pyrolysis/ disposal in a secured landfill
 

Chemical waste

Chemicals used in biological production and used or discarded
disinfectants.

Disposal- incineration/plasma
pyrolysis

Encapsulation- hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility.

Chemical liquid waste :
Liquid waste generated due to the use of chemicals in the production of
biological and used or discarded disinfectants, silver X-ray film
developing liquid,
discarded formalin,
infected secretions,
aspirated body fluids, liquid from laboratories and floor washings, cleaning, house-keeping and
disinfecting activities etc.

 

 After resource recovery, the chemical
liquid waste shall be pre-treated before mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vacutainers with needles cut, and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by Shredding/mutilation

And later, Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/road-making

Not to be sent to landfill

 

  White (translucent)  
(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/mutilation/
encapsulation

Later by - Iron foundries/sanitary landfill/waste sharps

 

   Blue  
(Puncture proof and leak proof containers with blue colored marking)

Type of Waste 

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Glassware

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampules except those containing cytotoxic waste.

Metallic body implants

Sodium hypochlorite/Autoclaving/
Microwaving/Hydroclaving

Later - Recycling

 

 Note: Ash from the incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at a common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may also be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl was brought by her parents with complaints of weight loss, increased appetite, and a decline in scholastic performance. Following investigations, a diagnosis of Grave’s disease is made. Which of the following is the drug of choice for initial therapy?
questions.solution:
Methimazole is the initial drug of choice for treating Grave's disease (hyperthyroidism) in children.

Option A: Propylthiouracil is not recommended in children because it is associated with fatal hepatotoxicity.

Option C: Radioactive iodine is not preferred as the first-line treatment in hyperthyroidism for children.

Option D: Levothyroxine is used to treat hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A post-coital test was done in a couple who presented with an inability to conceive despite staying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse. Which of the following conditions cannot be detected by this test?
questions.solution:
The post-coital test can not detect a fallopian tube block. It can evaluate the following conditions:

  • Sperm count
  • Sperm morphology
  • Ferning during the estrogenic effect
  • Ovulation
  • The ability of the cervical mucous to allow sperm penetration
  • Detection of anti-sperm antibodies in the cervical mucous

In the post-coital test, the couple is advised to have intercourse early in the morning close to the ovulation phase. The woman is asked to visit the clinic within 2 hours of having intercourse. The mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and spread over a glass slide. Another smear made from the posterior fornix serves as a control.

On microscopy, 10–50 motile sperms are normally seen per high-power field. The cervical mucus is also examined for its quantity and viscosity. The post-coital test is useless in the presence of cervical infection.

An immunological factor causing infertility is encountered in around 5% of infertile couples.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with severe pain in the buttocks extending down the back of the right leg. MRI revealed inflammation of the piriformis muscle. Entrapment of which of the following nerves is likely to cause the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of piriformis syndrome, which occurs due to the entrapment of the sciatic nerve.

It is triggered by sitting for a long time or running, climbing stairs, or applying firm pressure directly over the piriformis muscle. Early signs include pain, tingling, or numbness in the buttocks. Later it may lead to severe pain extending down the length of the sciatic nerve.

questions.text: What is pegloticase used for?
questions.solution:
Pegloticase is used in the treatment of chronic gout.

Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase). It catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, which is a more soluble and inactive metabolite.

It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated.

questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of
questions.solution:
Klenow fragment lacks 5’ → 3’ exonuclease activity.

DNA polymerase I is an enzyme involved in DNA replication. It has polymerase activity along with both 3' → 5' and 5' → 3' exonuclease activity. When the 5' → 3' exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment is called Klenow fragment. It retains the polymerization and proofreading activities of DNA polymerase I.

questions.text: A patient with Hodgkin’s disease on chemotherapy with an alkylating agent develops behavioral disturbances and experiences sedation. He presented to the emergency room with a disulfiram-like reaction. What is the drug being described here?
questions.solution:
The most likely alkylating agent being described here is procarbazine. It is associated with behavioural disturbances and sedation. Concomitant CNS depressants should be avoided.

Procarbazine is a weak MAO inhibitor and can potentiate tyramine and catecholamines action. It also has disulfiram-like actions and alcohol should be avoided.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the ER with fever, splenomegaly, and a rash as shown in the image below. After admission, he developed intestinal perforation  and an exploratory laparotomy revealed several longitudinal ulcers in the small bowel. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Rose spots. The combination of this with fever, splenomegaly, presence of longitudinal ulcers in the intestine and intestinal perforation is suggestive of enteric fever.

The term enteric fever includes typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi and paratyphoid fever caused by Salmonella paratyphi A, B and C.

Enteric fever presents with step ladder pyrexia. The fever is accompanied by relative bradycardia which is known as the Faget sign. Hepatosplenomegaly is a common finding on examination. Rose spots that fade on pressure appear on the skin during the second or third week. 

Since bile is a good culture medium for the bacilli, they multiply abundantly in the gallbladder and are discharged continuously into the intestine. In the intestine, it causes inflammation and necrosis leaving behind the characteristic typhoid ulcers which are oriented along the axis of the intestine (longitudinal ulcers). Ulceration of the bowel leads to two major complications- intestinal perforation and hemorrhage.

Option B: In intestinal tuberculosis, ulcers are perpendicular to the axis of the intestine (transverse ulcers).

Option C: Flask shaped ulcers are characteristic of amoebiasis.

Option D: Hemorrhagic colitis is caused by Shigella dysenteriae and some strains of E. coli. It is characterised by bloody diarrhea with tenesmus.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl suffers from an inadequately treated type 1 diabetes mellitus. She is currently hyperglycemic. Which of the following is most likely to occur?

choices.text: Increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA

questions.solution:
With the background of inadequately treated type I diabetes mellitus, an insulin-deficient state in the body is expected which will lead to increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA.

Type 1 diabetes mellitus is commonly found in the adolescent population.  In response to certain precipitating factors, such patients may develop a severe insulin-deficient state. Since insulin is an inhibitor of hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL), an insulin-deficient state will cause HSL overactivity in adipocytes and the breakdown of lipid into fatty acids (lipolysis). Free fatty acids will undergo beta-oxidation and produce a large amount of acetyl CoA, which gets converted to ketone bodies ( acetoacetate, acetone, beta-hydroxybutyrate, etc.)

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient came to the OPD with cervical lymph node enlargement. The biopsy was examined, which showed a variant of the Reed-Sternberg cell given in the image. Which of the following types of Hodgkin's lymphoma frequently has this cell in its histology?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the lymphohistiocytic variant (L&H) of Reed–Sternberg (RS) cell. It is seen frequently in lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma.

The cell has the following features:

  • Polypoid nuclei
  • Inconspicuous nucleoli
  • Moderately abundant cytoplasm  

As it resembles popcorn in its morphology it is also termed popcorn cell.

Note: A unique paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma is the occurrence of pain in the affected lymph nodes during alcohol consumption. This has been attributed to the enlargement of the affected lymph nodes following alcohol consumption, which stretches the capsule of the lymph node and produces pain.

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence. 

Related Pearl: Variants of Reed Sternberg Cells

Variant Reed–Sternberg cells and the corresponding subtype of Hodgkin's Lymphoma

  • Lacunar Variant: Nodular Sclerosis
  • Mononuclear variant: Mixed cellularity and Lymphocyte rich 
  • Pleomorphic/Necrotic/Mummified Variant: Lymphocyte depleted 
  • L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn Variant: Lymphocyte predominant

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic smoker comes with acute epigastric discomfort for the past one hour. ECG shows ST-segment depression. What is the immediate intervention?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of a non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS). Immediate intervention is the administration of aspirin.

Aspirin is the first drug given in acute coronary syndromes. An initial dose of 325 mg to be chewed and swallowed is given. If oral administration is not feasible, it should be given as a rectal suppository.

The following protocol must be followed in the management of patients with acute coronary syndrome:

  1. Stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation
  2. Administration of O2
  3. Treatment of sustained ventricular arrhythmia rapidly according to ACLS protocols
  4. Give aspirin 325 mg
  5. History and examination, assess cardiac biomarkers
  6. Give three sublingual nitroglycerin tablets each 5 min apart. Add IV nitroglycerin for the persistence of symptoms.
  7. Treat left heart failure if present with an after-load reducing agent or loop diuretic
  8. Give beta-blockers
  9. Give morphine for the persistence of anxiety and discomfort related to MI
  10. In patients with STEMI - Reperfusion with PCI or fibrinolysis (if PCI is unavailable within 120 min) followed by antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy. In patients with NSTEMI - antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy are indicated.

questions.text: A patient presented with intermenstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. Which of the following types of fibroid is usually associated with this symptom?
questions.solution:
Intermenstrual bleeding is common with submucous fibroids. Metrorrhagia or intermenstrual bleeding refers to bleeding that occurs during the middle of the menstrual cycle.

Metrorrhagia in a woman over 40 years warrants a dilatation and curettage procedure to rule out endometrial cancer. This is associated with fibroids in 3% of cases.

Polymenorrhoea in a patient with fibroids occurs when she has polycystic ovaries or pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Progressive menorrhagia is seen in intramural and submucous myoma due to increased vascularity, endometrial hyperplasia, and an enlarged uterine cavity.

Note: Further the distance of the fibroid from the cavity, lesser is the possibility of menorrhagia. For this reason, subserous and pedunculated fibroids do not cause menorrhagia.

questions.text: You are inserting Nova-T in a patient for spacing of births. This device contains______.
questions.solution:
Nova-T contains both copper and silver. The addition of the silver increases its effective lifespan.

In copper-carrying devices, copper wire is wrapped around the vertical stem of a polypropylene frame. Some of them have copper wire wrapped around the arms too. Based on the surface area, they are of various types:

  • Copper T 380 A
  • Multiload copper 250
  • Copper T 200
  • Copper 7
  • Copper T 220
  • Nova-T

They are effective for 3–5 years. It is estimated that about 50 mcg of copper is eluted daily in the uterus. Copper T 380A, known as Paraguard, has a lifespan of 10 years. Nova T has a lifespan of 5 years.

questions.text: A 5th standard girl is brought to the OPD with a high fever and cough with expectoration for 3 days. Her chest X-ray shows multiple pneumatoceles. Which of the following is the most common etiological agent implicated in this presentation?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia manifests as confluent bronchopneumonia, which is often unilateral and characterized by the presence of hemorrhagic necrosis and irregular areas of cavitation of the lung parenchyma, resulting in pneumatoceles, empyema, or at times, bronchopulmonary fistulas. 

The following CT image shows cavitating pneumonia by S. aureus:

questions.text: Two weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection, a 5-year-old presents with ecchymosis and petechiae all over the body. Abdominal examination revealed no hepatosplenomegaly. The platelet count is 15,000/µL and the coagulation profile is normal. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy shows increased megakaryocytes
Bleeding into the joints is a common manifestation
The condition resolves spontaneously in 80% patients

questions.solution:
This scenario is suggestive of acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura. Bleeding into the joints is seen in coagulation disorders and is not a manifestation of this condition.

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura or idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)  is an acquired disorder in which there is an immune-mediated destruction of platelets. It can be acute or chronic.

Acute ITP is common in children and is usually preceded by viral infection. It presents with mucocutaneous bleeding (epistaxis, petechiae, ecchymosis). Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever and jaundice are absent. The following laboratory features are seen:

  • Thrombocytopenia (commonly <20,000 / μL)
  • Bleeding time - prolonged
  • PT/aPTT/INR - normal
  • Bone marrow - normal/increased megakaryocytes
  • Peripheral smear - normal

This condition resolves spontaneously in 80% of the cases. Treatment is as follows:

  • Platelet count < 30,000 with risk factors for bleeding (antiplatelet drugs/anticoagulants or concomitant bleeding disorders): Oral glucocorticoids or IVIG 
  • Severe bleeding symptoms: IV methylprednisolone ± IVIG 
  • Life-threatening bleeding (like intracranial hemorrhage): platelet transfusion + IV methylprednisolone + IVIG 

Related Pearl: Differences between Bleeding Disorders and Coagulation disorders

Finding Bleeding disorders Coagulation disorders
Cause

Quantitative/ Qualitative platelet abnormality

 Deficiency of clotting factors
Sex More common in females (commonly autoimmune) More common in males (commonly X-linked)
Family history Rare (except in VWD) Common
Petechiae Characteristic  Rare
Superficial ecchymosis Small and Multiple Large and Solitary
Bleeding from superficial cuts  Profuse Minimal persistent
Hemarthrosis Rare Characteristic (most common-knee)
Deep dissecting hematomas Rare Characteristic (most common-iliopsoas)
Laboratory tests Bleeding time is prolonged PT and/or PTT are prolonged
Most common Inherited: VWD

Inherited: Hemophilia A

Acquired: Hemorrhagic diathesis of liver disease

VWD: von Willebrand disease

PT: Prothrombin time

PTT: Partial thromboplastin time

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with congestive heart failure. Which of the following is not prescribed to prevent progression and revert cardiac remodelling?
questions.solution:
Digoxin has no role in preventing cardiac remodelling. It increases cardiac contractility and is indicated for symptomatic management of congestive heart failure.

Drugs preventing ventricular remodelling:

  • ACE inhibitors/ ARBS
  • Beta-blockers
  • Aldosterone antagonists (spironolactone, eplerenone)

The activation of RAAS and the sympathetic nervous system leads to the remodelling and progressive LV dysfunction. The RAAS activation is prevented by the ACE inhibitors/ARBs and the aldosterone antagonists (spironolactone), while the overactive sympathetic system is inhibited by the beta-blockers.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease with recently diagnosed Type 2 DM was started on metformin therapy. Her repeat eGFR was 40/min/1.73 m2. Which of the following is not true regarding the further management of this lady?

choices.text: Metformin dose has to be decreased.
Metformin should be discontinued and replaced with insulin.
eGFR should be measured at least annually in her.
eGFR is preferred over serum creatinine concentration to assess renal function for metformin therapy.

questions.solution:
According to current guidelines (KDIGO 2020), metformin should be discontinued only in patients with eGFR less than 30 ml/min/1.73 m2 or kidney failure. Metformin dose should be reduced when the eGFR is less than 45 ml/min/1.73 m2.

Metformin is excreted by the kidneys, and accumulation with reduced kidney function may increase the risk of lactic acidosis (due to inhibition of hepatic gluconeogenesis). It is contraindicated below eGFR<30. 

eGFR is obtained at baseline and at least annually in all patients taking metformin. It is recommended that the eligibility of CKD patients for metformin administration be changed from one based on a single laboratory parameter (blood creatinine concentration) to one that provides a better estimate of kidney function in patients with kidney disease i.e., glomerular filtration rate estimating equation (eGFR).

questions.text: A man diagnosed with schizophrenia was on chlorpromazine and olanzapine for the past 6 months. However, he is still symptomatic. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Clozapine is the drug of choice in treatment-resistant schizophrenia and schizophrenia with persistent suicidality.

Treatment-resistant schizophrenia is the lack of response to two different antipsychotics given at adequate dosages for an adequate duration of 4-6 weeks.

If patients demonstrate even a mild amount of improvement during this period, it may be reasonable to wait before changing a medication, since patients may improve at a steady rate for 3 to 6 months.

Here, the patient’s medication history indicates a poor response to 2 antipsychotic trials, hence clozapine is indicated.

Related Pearl: Non extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotics

 

Typical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Chlorpromazine Corneal & lenticular deposits, vortex keratopathy, obstructive jaundice
Thioridazine Irreversible retinal pigmentation, QT prolongation

 

Atypical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Clozapine Agranulocytosis, metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain, wet pillow syndrome (excessive night time drooling)
Olanzapine Metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain
Quetiapine Cataract
Ziprasidone QT prolongation
Amisulpride Hyperprolactinemia
Aripiprazole Hypoprolactinemia 

Related Pearl: Pharmacological treatment of psychosis

First-generation antipsychotics are generally not preferred due to the higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects/ tardive dyskinesia.

Second-generation antipsychotics are preferred drugs:

  • Risperidone
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine
  • Aripiprazole
  • Ziprasidone
  • Paliperidone

Benzodiazepines can be added to treat associated agitation. It is the drug of choice for catatonia.

Special situations:

  • Emergency: Use a short-acting intramuscular agent such as haloperidol, fluphenazine, olanzapine, or ziprasidone.
  • Chronic compliance: Long-acting injectable is used.
  • Treatment resistance (2 failed trials): Consider Clozapine.
  • All meds ineffective: May consider ECT.

Related Pearl: Clozapine treatment guidelines

Clozapine treatment guidelines:

Indications:  Treatment resistant schizophrenia, schizophrenia associated with suicidality.

Adverse effects: 

  • Agranulocytosis
  • Seizures
  • Myocarditis
  • Metabolic syndrome

questions.text: A fisherman was rushed to the ED following a near-drowning incident. On arrival, he was unconscious and was not breathing. He was resuscitated and stabilized. A few hours later, he developed sudden onset breathlessness and low saturation. Chest X-ray showed diffuse alveolar opacities. He was started on mechanical ventilation. What will be the recommended ventilator setting for him?

choices.text: Low tidal volume and high PEEP
Low tidal volume and low PEEP
High tidal volume and high PEEP
High tidal volume and low PEEP

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ARDS secondary to drowning. The ventilator setting recommended is low tidal volume and high PEEP.

Drowning causes direct lung injury. The aspiration of water into the lungs damages the surfactant. This disrupts the alveolar-capillary membrane and leads to alveolar edema, resulting in ARDS.

The ventilator settings recommended in ARDS are:

  • Low tidal volume: To avoid barotrauma due to overdistention of the alveoli.
  • High PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure): This prevents the collapse of alveoli at the end of the expiration and improves oxygenation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man died in a road traffic accident. On autopsy, the following appearance of the kidney was noted. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?

choices.text: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen

questions.solution:
The gross image suggests that the patient had autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). This condition is not associated with hepatic fibrosis. However, patients with autosomal recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) have congenital hepatic fibrosis.

ADPKD is associated with mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1, and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2. The multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure. Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.

The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include: 
  • Hepatic cysts - most common 
  • Seminal vesicle cysts - can result in infertility
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdural hematoma
  • Pancreatic cysts 
  • Splenic cysts
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse 
There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved. However, there is a three-fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients. 

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman has just delivered a boy by spontaneous vaginal delivery. How often should her BP be recorded for the next 2 hours?
questions.solution:
For the first 2 hours following delivery, blood pressure and pulse should be recorded every 15 minutes. 

Temperature is assessed every 4 hours for the first 8 hours after delivery.

questions.text: What type of tympanogram would you expect to see in a patient with serous otitis media?
questions.solution:
B-type tympanogram is expected in a case of serous otitis media.

Here, compliance decreases i.e., mobility of tympanic membrane is restricted due to the effusion, usually secondary to negative middle ear pressure (eustachian tube obstruction). This results in a B-type tympanogram. 

Hearing tests suggestive of conductive hearing loss as seen in serous otitis media:

  • Rinne negative (BC>AC).
  • Weber - lateralized towards the worse ear
  • Audiogram - AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
  • Impedance audiometry - flat curve (reduced compliance, shift to the negative side)

Note: Tympanograph is Flat when there is Fluid in the middle ear.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman diagnosed with osteoarthritis of the knee came for a follow-up visit. On examination, the following findings were noted. Identify the marked lesion.
questions.solution:
The above image showing the knob-like appearance of the proximal interphalangeal joints (PIP) in a patient with OA is suggestive of Bouchard's nodes. They are formed due to the formation of osteophytes and tissue swelling.

Heberden's nodes develop in distal interphalangeal joints (DIP).

The images below show Bouchard's (yellow arrow) and Heberden's nodes (black arrow).

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text:
A young woman was admitted with chief complaints of dysphagia since adulthood which worsened in the last three months followed by odynophagia, nausea, and vomiting of undigested food. Her barium swallow shows features suspicious of achalasia and she is advised to undergo esophageal manometry. Which of the following will not be seen?

LES- Lower esophageal sphincter

choices.text: Absent peristalsis of the esophageal body

questions.solution:
There is increased esophageal baseline pressure in achalasia cardia.

Manometric features of achalasia cardia are as follows:

  • Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation
  • Absent peristalsis of the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure
  • Increased intraesophageal baseline pressures relative to the gastric baseline pressure

High-resolution manometry (HRM) is a gastrointestinal motility diagnostic system that measures intraluminal pressure activity in the gastrointestinal tract using a series of closely spaced pressure sensors. For a manometry system to be classified as high-resolution instead of classic, the pressure sensors must be spaced at most 1 cm apart.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a ​history of perianal pain is brought to the OPD. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the scenario is the Barberio test.

It is used to detect seminal fluid. When saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Florence test: 

  • Used to detect: semen
  • Stain used: 10% hydrochloric acid and Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water)
  • Finding: If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately

Takayama test (Haemochromogen crystal test): 

  • Used to detect: bloodstains
  • Stain used: Takayama reagent
  • Finding: If bloodstain is present, pink feathery crystals of haemochromogen or reduced alkaline haematin appear in a few minutes

Teichmann test (Haemin Crystal Test): 

  • Used to detect: bloodstains
  • Stain used: glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride
  • Finding: If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of haemin or haematin chloride appear. When hydrogen peroxide is added, the haematin crystals give bubbles of gas

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A man inspires 1000ml from a spirometer. The intrapleural pressure was -4cm H2O before inspiration and -12cm H20 at the end of inspiration. What is the compliance of lungs?(ml/cm H20)?
questions.solution:
Compliance is change in volume per unit change in pressure.

  • C= ΔV/ΔP

In this case,

ΔV= 1000 mL

ΔP= -12-(-4) = -8 cm of H2O

The minus sign indicates that the pressure has fallen by 8cms of H20 at the end of inspiration

Therefore the compliance is,

C= 1000/8= 125 mL/cm of H2O

questions.text: A neonate was noted to have cyanosis of the oral mucosa. Chest x-ray revealed a snowman appearance of the cardiac silhouette. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Snowman's appearance on the chest X-ray image is classically seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC).

The supracardiac variant can classically depict a snowman appearance/figure of 8/cottage loaf heart on the frontal chest radiograph.

The dilated vertical vein on the left, brachiocephalic vein on the top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium.

The image given above shows a snowman or figure-8 configuration. Cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascularity are evident.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: In a patient with heart failure, which of the following is not used as an inotropic agent?
questions.solution:
Nesiritide is not used as an inotropic agent. It belongs to the intravenous vasodilator class and is a recombinant brain natriuretic peptide (BNP)

Option A: Levosimendan belongs to the positive inotropes class and is a combined calcium sensitizer and PDE3 inhibitor.

Option B: Milrinone belongs to the positive inotrope class and is a PDE-3/4 inhibitor.

Option C: Omecamtiv mecarbil is a selective myosin activator that increases myocardial contractility without increasing the myocardial oxygen demand.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in heart failure

Drugs used in acute decompensated heart failure:
 
Intravenous vasodilators

Nitroglycerine

Sodium nitroprusside

Nesiritide Recombinant human BNP

Dobutamine

Epinephrine

Drugs used for rapid symptom relief

Bumetanide

Furosemide

Torasemide

Morphine Opioid - to calm the patient and decreases cardiac O2 consumption
 
Drugs used in chronic heart failure:

ARBs Used in case of intolerance to ACE inhibitors

SGLT-2 inhibitors Used as 1st line therapy- reduces mortality and morbidity

questions.text: What does BNS section 90/IPC Section 314 deal with?

choices.text: Death of mother due to miscarriage
Preventing the child being born alive

questions.solution:
BNS Section 90/IPC Section 314 deals with the death of the mother due to miscarriage.

Important sections of IPC relating to miscarriages:

BNS section

IPC section

Deals with

88

312

Causing miscarriage with consent

89

313

Causing miscarriage without consent

90

314

Death of mother due to miscarriage

91

315

Preventing the child from being born alive or causing it to die after birth

92

316

Causing the death of the quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide

Note: Quick child is a fetus that has developed to such a stage that it moves within the womb of the mother. It shall mean an unborn child whose heart is beating, who is experiencing electronically measurable brain waves, who is discernibly moving, and who is so far developed and matured as to be capable of surviving the trauma of birth with the aid of usual medical care and facilities available in this state.

questions.text: A researcher decided to use double-blinding in his trial evaluating two new therapies for cystic fibrosis. What is the characteristic feature of this concept?

choices.text: Study and control groups are blinded
Observer and group being observed are blinded
Group members and analyzer are blinded

questions.solution:
In double-blind trials, both the group members (study and control group) and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.

Related Pearl: Blinding in Epidemiology

  • Blinding is done in epidemiology to reduce the possibility of bias.
  • Types:
    • In single blind trials, only the participants or group members are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In double blind trials, both the group members and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In triple blind trials, the group members, the observers and the analyzers are unaware of the group allocation.
  • The most commonly used type of blinding is double blinding.

questions.text: A young adult presents with a 3-year history of intermittent ear discharge. He complains of poor hearing, which improves during discharge periods, but is worse when the ear is dry. Which of the following explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes the round window-shielding effect that is seen in tubotympanic type of CSOM.

The round window-shielding effect is where the ear discharge shields the round window from sound waves. During the inactive phase (no discharge), the sound strikes both the oval window and round window together and the noise cancels itself out. So, the hearing is worse when the ear is dry.

Cholesteatoma hearer is a patient with a discontinuous ossicular chain but the sound is conducted through the cholesteatoma to the footplate. On removing the cholesteatoma by surgery, the patient has worse hearing.

The term "cholesteatoma" originates from the Greek words "chole" meaning "lipids" and "steatos" meaning "fat." The name reflects the microscopic appearance of the tumor, which may contain a mixture of desquamated skin cells, cholesterol crystals, and other debris that can resemble a pearly substance when examined under a microscope.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with epilepsy gets repeated thoughts to cut off her fingers with a knife. These thoughts are detailed and distressing but do not urge her to do the action or cause any anxiety. The thoughts last for 5-10 minutes, after which she gets a seizure; then the thoughts disappear and she feels better. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient has forced thinking. The thoughts formed are not in control of the patient and are distressing.

Forced thinking is one of the recognized pre-ictal events (auras) occurring in focal epilepsy or more specifically, in frontal lobe epilepsy. It usually resolves after the episode of seizure.

Pre-ictal events (auras) in complex partial epilepsy include:

  • Automatisms (classical) - e.g., lip-smacking, rubbing, chewing.
  • Cognitive sensations - e.g., deja vu, jamais vu, forced thinking, dreamy states.
  • Autonomic sensations - e.g., fullness in the stomach, blushing, changes in respiration.
  • Affective states - e.g., fear, panic, depression, elation.

Option A: Obsessions are recurrent and persistent ideas, thoughts, urges, or images that are experienced as intrusive and unwanted and cause anxiety or distress to the patient. It is seen in obsessive-compulsive disorder.

Option B: Thought crowding is characterized by too many thoughts occurring at the same time in the field of consciousness. It is perceived as unpleasant and induces the feeling that ideas are difficult to catch. It is seen in mood disorders such as hypomania and bipolar disorder.

Option D: Thought insertion is a disorder of thought possession in which the patient feels that thoughts are being inserted into his mind by some external agent. It is seen in schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman develops pain in the eye after dark-room/prone-provocative test. Which of the following drugs should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Pain after dark-room prone-provocative test indicates occludable angles. Hence, atropine is contraindicated as it is a long-acting mydriatic and can precipitate angle closure.

Dark-room/prone-provocative test (DRPPT)- The patient sits in a dark room, face down for one hour without sleeping (sleep induces miosis). The intraocular pressure (IOP) is checked (immediately after the test, as IOP can normalize very rapidly), and an IOP rise of 8 mmHg or more is frequently considered significant.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy had painful sores in the mouth with a rash over the hands along with fever. Which of these is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The presence of fever, along with painful sores in the mouth and small, tense vescicles with surrounding erythema on the palms and soles in a child point towards the diagnosis of hand-foot-mouth disease. The most common cause of which worldwide is coxackievirus A16. 

Spread is by droplets or faecal contamination and the incubation period is 7 days. The fever is generally mild, and is followed by the appearance of lesions. The characteristic lesions are slightly oval, with a grey blister roof and a narrow rim of erythema. The oral lesions are aphthoid and are less painful than aphthous ulcers.

Only symptomatic treatment is given. The lesions generally disappear in 7 - 10 days.

questions.text: A patient on hemodialysis may develop all of the following chronic complications except:
questions.solution:
Hypovolemia is an acute complication of hemodialysis. The chronic complications of hemodialysis are:

  • Amyloidosis
  • Adynamic bone disease
  • Dementia (aluminum toxicity)

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram:
questions.solution:
The image showing bilateral ballooned-out tubes filled with contrast is suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx. 

Hydrosalpinx is a chronic cystic swelling of the fallopian tube caused by distal tubal obstruction, usually bilateral. It is associated with conditions like PID and endometriosis. Grossly, the fimbriae and tubal ostia are replaced by a smooth, dilated end. The ballooned elongated tubes are filled with clear fluid. 

Ultrasound reveals a cystic, elongated structure with thin walls, incomplete septa, and anechoic contents. Hysterosalpingography shows dilated, clubbed fallopian tubes filled with contrast. The interstitial end of the tube is open whereas the fimbrial end is indrawn and closed. This permits the dye to enter but not exit the tube during hysterosalpingography. 

Laparoscopic treatment options for those not seeking to preserve fertility include adhesion lysis and salpingectomy. For infertile women, laparoscopic neo-salpingostomy is done  for mild tubal disease. In vitro fertilization (IVF) may be a better option for severe tubal disease.

The image given below shows bilateral hydrosalpinx:

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the casualty following a skating injury. The parents encouraged him to ask questions. He talked for most of the conversation and excitedly explained he wanted to try this so his parents let him. He even painted one wall in their house and asked if the doctor wants to see it. By this behavior of parents, what they are encouraging in the child?
questions.solution:
The parents are encouraging the development of the initiative in their child which happens in the stage of initiative vs guilt, as proposed by Erik Erikson.

In this stage, children begin to explore and do things on their own. They are able to learn new concepts introduced in school and are expected to practice these lessons in real life. They know that they can accomplish these tasks, but if they fail to do so and end up asking for assistance from others, they may feel a sense of guilt. Inadequate resolution of this conflict may lead to a conversion disorder or phobia. 

Erikson's stages and goals:

Stage and age Goal
Stage One
  • Infancy
  • Birth-18 months 
 Trust vs Mistrust

Stage Two

  • Toddler
  • 18month-3 years
 Autonomy vs Shame and Doubt

Stage Three

  • Pre-school
  • 3-5 years
 Initiative vs Guilt

Stage Four

  • School going
  • 5-13 years
 Industry vs Inferiority

Stage Five

  • Adolescence
  • 13-21 years
 Identity vs Role Confusion

Stage Six

  • Young adulthood
  • 21-40 years
 Intimacy vs Isolation

Stage Seven

  • Middle adulthood
  • 40-60 years
 Generativity vs Stagnation

Stage Eight

  • Late adulthood
  • >60 years
 Ego Integrity vs Despair

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.

Juvenile polyps are malformations of epithelium and lamina propria commonly located in the rectum. It is seen in children <5 years of age. The typical presentation is painless rectal bleeding. Sometimes there may be a proliferating rectal mass.

The disease may be sporadic or syndromic. 

  • Sporadic juvenile polyp occurs as a single mass and is called retention polyp.
  • Juvenile polyposis syndrome is characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps, which may be premalignant.

Morphologically, both of these types are indistinguishable.

  • Gross appearance: They appear as pedunculated, smooth reddish lesions, and with cystic spaces.
  • Microscopic appearance: The cysts appear as dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris.

Note: Complex glandular architecture and the presence of smooth muscle cutting through the lamina propria are seen in Peutz-Jeghers polyps.

questions.text: What is the term for the phenomenon where a single mutant gene leads to many end-effects?
questions.solution:
Pleiotropism is characterized by a single mutant gene, which may lead to many end effects.

For example, in sickle-cell anemia, the point mutation in the gene not only predisposes the red blood cells to hemolysis but can also block the vessels. This leads to splenic fibrosis, organ infarcts, and bone changes. The numerous differing end-organ derangements are all related to the primary defect in hemoglobin synthesis.

Option B: In variable expressivity, a trait is seen in all individuals carrying the mutant gene but is expressed differently among them. 

Option C: Polymorphisms are caused by interactions between multiple variant forms of genes and environmental factors.

Option D: Genetic heterogeneity refers to mutations at several genetic loci that may produce the same trait. An example of this is profound childhood deafness - an apparently homogeneous clinical entity that results from many different types of autosomal recessive mutations.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis has been on treatment for the past 15 years. During an annual eye check-up, her fundus appeared as shown in the picture given. Which of the following anti-rheumatoid drugs likely led to this side effect?
questions.solution:
The image shows bull’s eye maculopathy.

Hydroxychloroquine use is associated with this side effect.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man underwent excision of a lipoma. The swelling had been excised with a clear linear incision and was sutured cleanly. In this wound, when would you expect peak neovascularization?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a clean surgical incision that is sutured is an example of healing by primary intention. In this type of healing, neovascularization reaches its peak by day 5, as granulation tissue fills the incisional space.

These new vessels are leaky, allowing the passage of plasma proteins and fluid into the extravascular space. Hence, new granulation tissue is often edematous.

questions.text: A child, upon ingestion of shellfish, developed a tingling sensation in the mouth, swelling of the face, lips, and tongue, and also complained of abdominal pain and dizziness. What type of reaction is this?
questions.solution:
This child who developed tingling in the mouth, and swelling of the lips and face after eating shelf life is an example of an IgE mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction. 

Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs rapidly and affects the whole body. It is characterized by a sudden release of histamines and other chemicals from the immune system in response to an allergen, such as certain foods, medications, insect stings, or latex. The onset of symptoms can occur within minutes to a few hours after exposure to the allergen.The primary mediators are histamine and serotonin. The secondary mediators are prostaglandins and leukotrienes. 

Clinically, anaphylaxis can present with a combination of symptoms that typically include:

  • Respiratory Symptoms: Patients often experience wheezing and respiratory distress due to bronchoconstriction. Other signs may include shortness of breath, coughing, and a feeling of tightness in the chest.
  • Skin Symptoms: Urticaria (hives) and angioedema (swelling of the skin and mucous membranes) are common. These skin reactions usually develop rapidly, often within minutes to two hours of exposure to the allergen.
  • Cardiovascular Symptoms: Hypotension (low blood pressure) is a key indicator of anaphylaxis. Patients may also experience tachycardia (increased heart rate) and, in severe cases, shock.
  • Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and cramps can occur, particularly if the anaphylaxis is triggered by food allergens.
  • Neurological Symptoms: Dizziness, lightheadedness, or loss of consciousness can occur due to the sudden drop in blood pressure and reduced oxygen supply to the brain.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

questions.text: A mother brings her 1-year-old child to the hospital with complaints that he turns blue while breastfeeding. It resolves when he assumes a squatting position. On examination, a cleft palate is seen. Labs show hypocalcemia. Which of the following abnormalities is expected to be seen in the lymphoid organs?

choices.text: Decreased size of germinal centres of lymph nodes
Decreased size of paracortical areas of lymph nodes
Increased size of the peri arteriolar lymphoid sheath of spleen

questions.solution:
Turning blue on breastfeeding with resolution on squatting describes a tet-spell or a cyanotic spell, indicating a congenital cardiac defect. Cleft palate, cardiac defects and hypocalcemia (parathyroid hypoplasia/aplasia) suggest a diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome. In this disorder, a decreased size of paracortical areas of lymph nodes is noted. 

DiGeorge syndrome is characterised by thymic aplasia, causing a deficiency of T cells and absent cell-mediated immunity. Thus, paracortical areas of lymph nodes and periarteriolar sheaths of the spleen, where T cells reside, are reduced in size. B cells are usually not affected. 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis and ptosis is the most common ocular feature of the disease.

Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder of the neuromuscular junction most commonly caused by anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. The disorder is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles where the weakness increases during repeated use and may improve following rest.

Ptosis and diplopia are common initial complaints due to early involvement of the lids and extraocular muscles (EOMs). Of them, Ptosis is a more common manifestation than diplopia. Ptosis in myasthenia gravis is insidious, bilateral, and frequently asymmetrical.

Investigations of myasthenia gravis include:

  1. Ice pack test -This tests for a transient improvement of the ptotic eyelid on placing an ice pack for 2 minutes, as  the cold inhibits the breakdown of acetylcholine by acetylcholinesterase.
  2. Tensilon (Edrophonium) test - This tests for a transient improvement in the weakness on administration of a short-acting anticholinesterase such as edrophonium.
  3. Antibody testing - for Acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies, MuSK protein antibodies helps support a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A patient is brought due to accidental exposure to the following plant roots while experimenting with herbs. Which of the following associated finding may be seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows roots resembling horseradish, suggestive of the aconite plant. Hippus is associated with aconite poisoning. 

Hippus is an abnormal exaggeration of the rhythmic contraction and dilatation of the pupil, independent of changes in illumination or in fixation of the eyes.

Poisoning with aconite has never been common. Most reported cases are accidental in nature, resulting from therapeutic misadventures. Aconite is used in herbal medicines, or to increase the intoxicating effect of alcoholic beverages.

Option B: Hunan hand is due to capsicum annum. Dermatitis and burning of hands and fingers known as Hunan hand. This is common among the pickle industry workers, who use their hands for handling chilly paste or powder for a prolonged period.

Option C: Jamaican vomiting sickness, is a syndrome characterized by vomiting and hypoglycemia, seen in ingestion of the unripe ackee fruit. 

Option D: St Anthony's fire is the burning pain seen in gangrene caused by ergot poisoning. 

The image below is of horseradish, given for comparison.

questions.text: Following anterior dislocation of the shoulder, a patient develops weakness of flexion at elbow and lack of sensation over the lateral aspect of forearm. Which of the following nerves is injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of injury to musculocutaneous nerve. Musculocutaneous nerve supplies the biceps brachii and a branch of musculocutaneous nerve namely, the lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm supplies the lateral aspect of forearm. So, injury to musculocutaneous nerve results in weakness of flexion at elbow and lack of sensation over lateral aspect of forearm.

Though axillary nerve is the most common nerve damaged in shoulder dislocation, other nerves such as musculocutaneous nerve and radial nerve can also be damaged.

questions.text: A child with a fever and rash was brought to your OPD. Oral findings as shown in the image were observed. During which period can this disease spread to others?

choices.text: 4 days before and 2 days after the appearance of rash
2 days before and 2 days after the appearance of rash
4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash
2 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash

questions.solution:
The given image shows koplik spots, which are a pathognomonic sign of measles. The period of communicability for measles is 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash. The patient is isolated for 7 days from the onset of rash. 

Related Pearl: Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

questions.text: While in a health camp, you notice a child with fever and rash. On subsequent history, you find out that similar symptoms occurred in her friend 6 days back. How will you epidemiologically categorise the child you examined?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the child is categorised as the index case. It is the first case that comes to the notice of an investigator or physician.

The primary case is the first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit.  

A secondary case is one that develops after contact with the primary case. 

A suspect case refers to a patient who has all the features of the disease but has not been diagnosed with it yet.

Note: There is no such term as tertiary case.

questions.text: Identify the disease in which the cataract shown in below image is present.
questions.solution:
• The above image characteristically depicts a Christmas tree cataract.
  • Myotonic dystrophy is associated with Christmas tree cataract and salt and pepper fundus.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female is brought to the casualty with seizures for the past 10 minutes. History from relatives suggests no seizure-free intervals in the past 10 minutes. After stabilizing the vitals of the patient, which is the first drug you administer to the patient?
questions.solution:
This scenario described above is of status epilepticus. The first drug used in the management is lorazepam.

Status epilepticus refers to continuous seizures or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired consciousness in the inter-ictal period. For practical purposes, it is defined as any one of the following:

  • Continuing seizures >5 minutes or
  • No regaining of consciousness between 2 seizures.

Management of status epilepticus:

questions.text: An 82-year-old man presents to the ER with fever and tachycardia since last night. On examination, he is drowsy, his BP is 92/54 mmHg and his temperature is 103 °F. His wife tells you he had been diagnosed with a urinary tract infection 5 days ago for which he had been prescribed antibiotics. He is a known case of colon cancer and also has a history of myocardial infarction 6 months ago. What type of shock is he likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of septic shock as a result of gram-negative sepsis originating from a urinary tract infection.

Gram-negative organisms contain lipopolysaccharide in the outer membrane, which triggers the release of cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor (TNF). These cytokines cause a cascade of events culminating in increased capillary permeability and redistribution of circulatory volume into the interstitium. It is also known as warm shock, due to fever and increased perfusion.

Other types of shock are:

  • Anaphylactic shock - sudden circulatory collapse due to type I hypersensitivity reaction
  • Cardiogenic shock - ventricular failure, often following myocardial infarction; is a form of cold shock
  • Hypovolemic shock - due to blood or fluid loss

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can overcome an increase in heart rate and renin release seen in patients with CHF?
questions.solution:
Metoprolol is a selective β1 blocker. Beta blockade reduces the sympathetic stimulation of the SA node and thus reduces the heart rate. In the same way, β1 receptors in the JG apparatus are also inhibited by metoprolol, and thus, renin release is reduced.

Option A: Minoxidil is a K+ channel opener that was earlier used in hypertensive emergencies for its vasodilatory action on blood vessels. This has no effect on renin release and heart rate can increase due to reflex sympathetic stimulation.

Option C: Metolazone is a thiazide diuretic that can be used even in severe renal failure.

Option D: Milrinone is an inodilator. It increases cardiac contractility and causes vasodilation by inhibiting the enzyme PDE3.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presented with hematemesis and ascites. Investigations revealed the presence of a tumor at the porta hepatis causing portal hypertension. Which of the following structures is least likely to be involved by the tumor?
questions.solution:
Hepatic veins do not enter/exit the liver at the porta hepatis and are least likely to be involved by a tumor in that location.

Porta hepatis is a deep, transverse fissure that is situated on the inferior surface of the right lobe of the liver.

Structures entering at porta hepatis:

  • Portal vein
  • Hepatic artery
  • Hepatic nervous plexus

Structures exiting the porta hepatis:

  • Right and left hepatic bile ducts
  • Lymphatics

The classical feature of portal hypertension are ascites, splenomegaly, esophageal varices and distended veins around the umblicus.

Clinical note:

Pringle maneuver- rapid control of hemorrhage from the vessels entering the porta hepatis can be obtained by compressing them in the free edge of the lesser omentum.

The below image shows Pringle maneuver.

questions.text: In which of the following instances can a psychologist use systematic desensitization as a treatment option?

choices.text: A 18-year-old with BMI 22, recurrent episodes of binge eating and purging for past 3 months
A 24-year-old with an irrational fear of contamination who washes her hands every 5 minutes
A 22-year-old with feelings of  worthlessness, psychomotor retardation, insomnia, fatigue, and anhedonia for 2 weeks
A 20-year-old with disorganized behavior, delusions of persecution and auditory hallucinations for 4 months

questions.solution:
Systematic desensitization is one of the behavioral therapy techniques for Obsessive-compulsive disorder (A 24-year-old with an irrational fear of contamination and washes hands every 5 minutes). It is also used in the treatment of phobias.

Systemic desensitization is based on the behavioral principle of counter-conditioning. Here, the person overcomes anxiety elicited by a situation or an object by approaching the feared situation gradually and in a relaxed state.

Systematic desensitization consists of three steps:

  • Relaxation training - patients attain a state of complete relaxation and are then exposed to the stimulus that elicits the anxiety response. The negative reaction of anxiety is inhibited by the relaxed state, a process called reciprocal inhibition.
  • Hierarchy construction - Patients and therapists prepare a graded list (or hierarchy) of fear-provoking scenes in the order of increasing anxiety.
  • Desensitization of the stimulus - Patients proceed systematically through the list from the least to the most anxiety-provoking scene while in a deeply relaxed state.

Option A: Describes a patient with bulimia nervosa.

Option C: Describes a patient with major depressive episode.

Option D: Describes a patient with schizophreniform disorder.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is found to have excessive accumulation of amniotic fluid. Such polyhydramnios is likely to be associated with all of the following conditions except ______
questions.solution:
Bilateral renal agenesis is associated with oligohydramnios as the fetal kidneys produce decreased or no urine at all.

questions.text: A patient presented with non-union of tibial fracture. The orthopedician suggested treatment by providing stability using a cast or brace. Which of the following type of nonunion does the patient most likely has?
questions.solution:
Stabilization using casts and braces are used in the treatment of hypertrophic nonunion.  

Management of nonunion:

  • Hypertrophic nonunion: Stabilization to allow chondrocyte-mediated mineralization of the fibrocartilage between fracture ends. With stabilization, healing usually occurs by 8 weeks.
  • Oligotrophic nonunion: Correcting the issues related to bone contact through mechanical compression or bone grafting to close the defects. In some cases, a combination of biologic and mechanical methods is used.
  • Atrophic nonunion: Autogenous bone graft or BMP to provide biologic stimulus at the fracture site. The other procedure done is debridement or excision of the non-vital bone ends. 
  • Pseudoarthrosis: Debridement of the pseudoarthrosis, opening of the medullary canal and providing more stability usually with compression at the nonunion site. In some cases, biologic stimulation may be helpful to promote healing.

questions.text: Which of the following site does the restriction enzyme act when RFLP is used in-order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU?
questions.solution:
Restriction endonuclease enzymes act at specific palindromic sequences that create DNA fragments of different lengths. By analyzing the fragments, specific species of bacteria can be identified. Option B is the only palindromic sequence here, hence it is the answer.

RFLP is a restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis technique that involves cutting a particular region of DNA with known variability, with restriction enzymes, then separating the DNA fragments by agarose gel electrophoresis and determining the number of fragments and relative sizes. 

Cleavage of a sample of DNA with a restriction enzyme produces a characteristic set of smaller DNA fragments. Deviations in the normal product pattern, produce RFLPs that occur if a mutation renders a restriction site unrecognizable and alternatively, generates a new recognition site.

questions.text: An elderly man on follow-up for treatment of bladder cancer presents with painless hematuria. Which of the following assays should be done on this patient?
questions.solution:
An NMP 22 assay should be done in this patient to detect the recurrence of bladder carcinoma. 

NMP 22 is a nuclear matrix protein that is used to form cell nuclei. It is shed into the urine and has a higher concentration in the urine of bladder cancer patients. NMP-22 cutoff levels for bladder cancer detection is > 10 units/mL.

questions.text: Which of the following refers to a host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development?
questions.solution:
A host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development is referred to as the paratenic host.

For example, in the lifecycle of Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm), humans are the definitive host. The first intermediate host is cyclops and the second is small freshwater fish. If the small freshwater fish with the plerocercoid larva get eaten by a larger fish, the larva survives in the larger fish. This makes the larger fish a paratenic host.

The host is an organism that harbors the parasite and provides nourishment and shelter to it. It is relatively larger than the parasite. The types of hosts include: 

  • Definitive host: This host harbors the adult parasite and its stages of sexual reproduction.
  • Intermediate host: This host harbors the larva or the stages of asexual multiplication of the parasite.
  • Paratenic host: This host harbors only the larval stage of the parasite which does not develop further. 
  • Reservoir host: This host harbors the parasite and acts as an important source of infection to other susceptible hosts, especially in endemic areas.
  • Accidental host: This host harbors a parasite that is not usually found in the host.
