questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with redness and photophobia of the left eye was seen in the OPD. An image of a characteristic lesion of her eye is as shown below. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a white-pinkish nodule surrounded by hyperemia on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus with associated symptoms of redness and photophobia most likely has phlyctenular conjunctivitis. The given finding is referred to as a phlycten.

 Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction due to endogenous allergens like Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

It is characterized by the following:

  • Phlycten that may eventually form ring ulcers
  • Shallow marginal ulcer due to the breakdown of limbal phlycten known as scrofulous ulcer
  • Fascicular ulcer with a prominent parallel leash of blood vessels that heals leaving a band-shaped opacity

Treatment: Topical steroids; atropine if the cornea is involved.

Note: This can be differentiated from pinguecula by the following points:

Pinguecula is a yellow triangular patch on the conjunctiva near the limbus. It usually remains free from conjunctival congestion.  The following image shows a yellow patch with tortuous blood vessels. There is no congestion as seen with a phlycten.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presented with reduced urine output, swelling of his feet, and eyelid puffiness for 1 week. He also complains of back pain for the past 3 months, unresponsive to painkillers. Investigations reveal the following. What is the possible cause of renal failure in this patient?

Hemoglobin - 7.1 g/dl
Serum urea - 63 mg/dl
Serum creatinine - 3.9 mg/dl
Urine analysis - Positive for Bence-Jones proteins
questions.solution:
Bence-Jones proteins on urine analysis are suggestive of multiple myeloma. It causes acute kidney injury (AKI) by the following mechanisms: 

  • Hypercalcemia - leads to intense renal vasoconstriction and reduced perfusion
  • Myeloma light chains - cause direct tubular toxicity.

questions.text: A neonate presented with features of intestinal obstruction. The X-ray showed the following image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above plain abdominal radiograph shows a typical double-bubble sign suggestive of duodenal atresia.

The double-bubble represents dilatation of the stomach and the proximal duodenum.

Duodenal atresia is often associated with trisomy 21/Down syndrome, prematurity, maternal polyhydramnios, cardiac malformations, and malformations of the hepatobiliary system.

It is caused due to failure of recanalization or partial recanalization of the duodenum or failure of vacuolization of the duodenum from its solid cord stage. The anatomic variants are as follows: 

  • Type I: 
    • most common
    • mucosal web with intact muscle wall (so-called windsock deformity)
  • Type II:
    • two ends separated by a fibrous cord, but muscle continuity present
  • Type III:
    • complete separation of two ends with a gap within the duodenum

Clinical features:

  • Obstructive features such as
    • bilious emesis (due to duodenal obstruction distal to the ampulla of Vater)
    • postprandial emesis
    • upper abdominal distension with a scaphoid lower abdomen
  • Delayed passage of meconium

Abdominal radiographs show the double-bubble sign. If distal air is present, an upper GI contrast study should be considered to exclude midgut volvulus.

Treatment:

  • The initial treatment of infants with duodenal atresia includes nasogastric or orogastric decompression.
  • IV fluids and parenteral nutrition are started to prevent acid-base imbalance.
  • Echocardiography, renal ultrasound, and radiology of the chest and spine should be performed to evaluate for associated anomalies.
  • Definitive correction of the atresia is done by duodenoduodenostomy. This procedure is also preferred in cases of the concomitant or isolated annular pancreas.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after he suffered a stab wound in the anterior chest wall. CT-scan revealed arterial extravasation from injury to the internal thoracic artery. The condition causes a decrease in blood supply through all of the following blood vessels, except:
questions.solution:
Posterior intercostal arteries are not branches of the internal thoracic artery, hence there would be no decrease in blood supply through these arteries. 

Branches of the internal thoracic artery:

  • Terminal branches at the level of the 6th intercostal space:
    • Superior epigastric artery
    • Musculophrenic artery
  • Sternal branches to:
    • Transversus thoracis muscle
    • Periosteum of the posterior sternal surface
    • Sternal red bone marrow
  • Anterior intercostal arteries for the first 6 intercostal spaces.
  • Perforating branches that pierce and supply pectoralis major and then become direct cutaneous vessels that supply the skin.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presents with fatigue. His total leucocyte count is 138 x 10^9 / L with 80% blasts on the peripheral smear. Chest X-ray shows a large mediastinal mass. The bone marrow aspirate is as shown below. What would the immunophenotyping of this patient’s blasts most likely demonstrate?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and bone marrow aspirate are suggestive of  T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Thus, immunophenotyping of the blasts would demonstrate an immature T-cell phenotype (Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive).

The bone marrow aspirate shows lymphoblast with condensed nuclear chromatin, small inconspicuous nucleoli, and scanty cytoplasm lacking granules. 

ALL is usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement in 50% to 70%. It has an abrupt stormy onset, within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms.

Clinical features of ALL include: 

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies 
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of  large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

Related Pearl: Immunophenotyping of Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL)

Type of ALL  Immunophenotype 
Early Pre-B ALL  TdT, DR, CD19, CD24 
Pre B ALL  TdT, DR, CD10, CD19, CD20, CD24, Cy Ig 
Common ALL  CD19+,  CD10+/CALLA+ 
Mature B  ALL  DR, CD19, CD20, CD24, Surface Ig 
Pro-T ALL   CD3, CD7 
Pre-T ALL  TdT, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8, CD34 
Mature T ALL  CD2, CD7, Tdt

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the clinic with a history of a reducible and painless swelling in the right groin for the past 2 months. After the clinical and radiological investigations, the diagnosis of a right-sided inguinal hernia was made. The patient is posted for hernia repair surgery. Which of the following steps will not be done in this patient during the repair?
questions.solution:
Inguinal hernia in a child is treated by herniotomy. In this procedure, repair of the inguinal ring is not done.

This is because the inguinal hernia in the pediatric population is due to the presence of patent processus vaginalis and not due to the weakening of the abdominal muscles or the ligaments.

Herniotomy involves either reduction of the hernial sac alone, or opening of the hernial sac, reduction of the contents, transfixation of the neck, and excision of the patent processus vaginalis/ hernial sac.

questions.text: In what position would you place a patient prior to direct laryngoscopy?
questions.solution:
Prior to direct laryngoscopy and intubation, the patient is placed in the sniffing position, which consists of flexion at the lower cervical spine with extension at the atlanto-occipital joint.

This is to ensure a line of sight from the mouth to the larynx so that intubation can be performed with ease. 

Cervical flexion of 35 degrees is provided by elevating the patient's head by 7-9 cm (folded sheet under the head). This aligns the pharyngeal and laryngeal axes. 

Atlanto-occipital extension is provided by the head tilt. This brings into alignment the visual axis of the mouth with that of pharyngeal and laryngeal axes.

Adequacy of head elevation can be estimated by checking the horizontal alignment between external auditory meatus and sternal notch.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male on multiple drugs presents with a round macule on his right leg for the last 7 days. The patient gives a history of similar episodes in the past which resolved spontaneously. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This is a case of fixed drug eruption and the most likely cause is ibuprofen.

Fixed drug eruptions are characterized by sharply demarcated dull red to brown lesions. They occur in lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and cause a burning sensation. The lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug.

Some of the drugs commonly known to cause fixed drug eruptions are Sulphonamides, NSAIDs, Analgesics, and Hypnotics.

Diagnosis is based on history and lesion morphology. Discontinuation of the offending drug is the first step in management.

Phenytoin and carbamazepine can lead to Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) and drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome).

questions.text: What procedure is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a sentinel lymph node biopsy using a gamma camera.

The sentinel lymph node is the first draining lymph node. SLNB was first described in penile cancer by Cabana. Sentinel lymph node biopsy is only done on node-negative tumors.

Methylene blue dye or radioisotope i.e., technetium-labeled albumin is injected into breast tissue (or subdermal tissue) at the site of the primary tumor or at the subareolar position. The sentinel node is identified as a blue node or as a radioactive node (using a gamma camera). The frozen section biopsy is sent to the pathologist for identification of cancer cells. If the biopsy is positive for cancer cells, then axillary dissection is simultaneously performed. 

Note: The combination of blue dye and technetium-labeled colloid has been reported to improve the detection of sentinel lymph nodes. Newer techniques involve the use of a fluorescent or magnetic tracer instead of the radiolabelled dye.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presented with complaints of urinary urgency followed by involuntary escape of urine. What is the etiology of the condition she's likely suffering from?

choices.text: Pelvic mass in pouch of Douglas

questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of urge incontinence. It occurs due to detrusor instability.

During normal micturition, the detrusor muscle contracts after being stimulated by the parasympathetic nerves. In detrusor instability, detrusor muscle contracts spontaneously or on provocation during filling of the bladder. It is often caused by overactivity of parasympathetic nerves. It is usually seen in older women and is caused by:

  • Decreased bladder capacity - due to fibrosis
  • Decreased sensation 
  • Central nervous system (CNS) inhibition - due to stroke, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord involvement etc.

It is associated with the following symptoms: 

  • Incontinence
  • Urge to urinate 
  • Increased frequency
  • Nocturia 
  • Urination during sexual intercourse and with the sound of water, hand-washing.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with a 3-day history of mucopurulent cervical discharge. Gram staining of the discharge revealed numerous pus cells, but no organisms. What is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this infection?
questions.solution:
Mucopurulent cervical discharge for 3 days is suggestive of acute cervicitis. As gram stain does not show any organism, gonococcal infection is less likely. In this case, Chlamydia trachomatis is the most likely organism. For C. trachomatis, the investigation of choice is the nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT).

NAATs are the most sensitive tests to detect chlamydia. These tests also have a high specificity comparable to culture, and in contrast to culture, do not depend on viable pathogens. Therefore, NAATs are generally considered the test of choice for chlamydia and have replaced culture as the diagnostic gold standard.

Mucopurulent cervicitis is the inflammation of the columnar epithelium and subepithelium of the endocervix in women. Its commonly caused by Neiserria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. 

Related Pearl: Important sexually transmitted pathogens and the diseases caused by them

Pathogen

Disease or syndrome

Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Gonorrhea, urethritis, cervicitis, epididymitis, salpingitis, PID, neonatal conjunctivitis

Treponema pallidum

Syphillis

Haemophilus ducreyi

Chancroid

Chlamydia trachomatis

LGV, urethritis, cervicitis, proctitis, epididymis, infant pneumonia, Reiter's syndrome, PID, neonatal conjunctivitis

Klebsiella granulomatis (prev called Calymmatobacterium)

Donovanosis (granuloma inguinale)

Herpes simplex virus

Genital herpes

Hepatitis B virus

Acute and chronic hepatitis 

Human papillomaviruses 

Genital and anal warts

HIV

AIDS

Molluscum contagiosum

Genital molluscum contagiosum

Candida albicans

Vaginitis

Trichomonas vaginalis

Vaginitis

questions.text: A young male presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. The biopsy of the lymph node showed RS cells with vague nodule formation and a background of reactive T-lymphocytes. The cells were positive for CD20, LCA, EMA and negative for CD 15 and CD30. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: T cell rich B cell lymphoma

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL).

Axial group (cervical) lymphadenopathy and along with the L&H variant of Reed-Sternberg cells is characteristic.

RS cells are neoplastic giant cells. In NLPHL, the cells have vague nodular formation. Immunophenotyping is positive for CD20 (B cell-associated), LCA (CD45), EMA (epithelial marker), and negative for CD15 (monocyte or macrophage-associated) and CD30 (activation marker).

The image given below shows the L&H variant of RS cells seen in NLPHL.

Related Pearl: Hodgkin v/s Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma

Features Hodgkin Lymphoma  Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
Lymph nodes  Single axial group of lymph nodes Multiple peripheral lymph nodes 
Spread Contiguous Non-contiguous
Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring  Rarely involved Commonly involved
Extra-nodal involvement Uncommon  Common

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with the following fetal presentation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of frank breech.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete: Breech with extended legs, footling, knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs
Breech type Description Presenting part
Frank breech
(with extended legs)		 Thighs flexed on the trunk, legs extended at the knee joint. Buttocks and genitalia
Footling Both thighs and legs are partially extended Foot 
Knee  Thighs extended, Knee flexed Knee
Complete/flexed Both thighs and legs are flexed. Buttocks, genitalia, foot

questions.text: An infant was admitted with failure to thrive. His reports show hypoglycemia, high glutamine, and uracil levels in urine. Gastric tube feeding was not tolerated and the child became comatose.  Parenteral dextrose was given after which the child recovered in 24 hours. What is the likely enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
This infant with failure to thrive, hypoglycemia, elevated levels of glutamine and uracil levels most likely has hyperammonemia type 2. This condition occurs due to the deficiency of the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase.

There is an accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate, which then enters into pyrimidine synthesis producing orotic acid and uracil and leading to orotic aciduria and high uracil in blood and urine. Since the ammonia from glutamine is not converted into urea, its level increases. Glutamate is not regenerated. Since glutamate is not available for transamination, amino acids cannot be used for gluconeogenesis. Hence, the glucose level drops in the blood.

Treatment:

  • Reducing intake of ammonia - Dietary protein, a metabolic source of ammonium, is restricted and caloric intake is provided by glucose and fat.
  • Increasing excretion of ammonia - Addition of phenylbutyrate, which scavenges nitrogen by combining with amino acids to form a more water-soluble product. This can be easily excreted by the kidneys.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl has just started menstruating. Under which of the following national programmes, she will be provided with a pack of sanitary napkins by the ASHA worker in her village?
questions.solution:
The girl will be provided with a pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the ASHA worker through the Menstrual Hygiene Scheme under the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK).

RKSK focuses on:

  • Development of adolescent population (10-19 years).
  • Weekly Iron and Folic Acid supplementation (100mg Fe + 500 mcg Folic Acid)
  • Menstrual hygiene: A pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the ASHA.
  • It also includes enhancement of mental health and prevention of substance abuse and violence.

Sukanya Samriddhi Yojana is a government-sponsored savings program for parents of girl children <10 years age. It helps parents to set aside money for their female child’s potential college and marriage expenses by opening an account at any post office branch or any commercial bank approved by the central government.

Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) seeks to empower adolescent girls, so as to enable them to take charge of their lives. The objectives are to:

  • improve the nutritional, health and development status of adolescent girls
  • promote awareness of health, hygiene, nutrition and family care
  • opportunities for learning life skills
  • going back to school
  • help them gain a better understanding of their social environment
  • take initiatives to become productive members of society.

Recent update: Department of Pharmaceuticals under Ministry of Chemicals and Fertilizers has recently launched ‘Suvidha’ (100% Oxo-biodegradable Sanitary Napkin), under the Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana (PMBJP) on World menstrual hygiene day. ‘Swachhta, Swasthya and Suvidha’ will be available for Rs. 1 per pad over 3200 Janaushadhi Kendras for the underprivileged women of India.

National Girl child day is observed on January 24th annually to raise awareness about the issues and challenges faced by the girl children in India and promote their rights and empowerment by eliminating gender biases, and emphasise the importance of education, health, and nutrition.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has come for pre-conceptional counselling. Her BMI is 30 kg/m2 and she is worried about weight gain during pregnancy. How much weight should she gain during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given question is obese. The recommended gestational weight gain in such a patient is 5-9 kg. 

Ideally, weight gain should depend on the pre-pregnancy BMI (body mass index) level. The gestational weight gain recommended for each BMI category by the Institute of Medicine (IOM) are as follows: 

Category

BMI (in kg/m2)

Recommended weight gain

Underweight

<18.5

12.5–18 kg

Normal

18.5–24.9

11.5–14 kg

Overweight

25–29.9

7–11.5 kg

Obese

>30

5-9.1 kg

questions.text: A child was brought to the orthopaedic OPD for evaluation of the given knee deformity. What is it known as?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is genu valgum.

A normal knee has 5-7 degrees physiological outward deviation (valgum). Any increase or decrease in angle can result in knee deformities. 

Knee deformities are:

  • Genu valgus (valgum) or knock knee - Knees are abnormally approximated and the ankles are divergent.
  • Genu varus (varum) or bow knee - Knees are abnormally divergent and the ankles are approximated.
  • Windswept deformity - Abnormal valgus deformity of one knee with varus of the other.
  • Genu recurvatum - Hyperextension at the knee joint with backwards bending.

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with sudden severe back pain. There is no history of trauma. X-ray findings are given below. MRI shows thinning of trabecular plates of the vertebrae and vertebral collapse. Levels of which of the following will be increased in her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoporosis. Cytokines stimulate osteoclast recruitment and activity in osteoporosis by increasing the levels of RANKL.

RANKL helps in diminishing the expression of osteoprotegerin (OPG), increasing osteoclast proliferation, and preventing osteoclast apoptosis.

Decreased estrogen levels after menopause actually increase both bone resorption and formation. However, the latter does not keep up with the former, leading to a high turnover. Decreased estrogen appears to increase the secretion of inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6, TNF-α, and IL-1.

questions.text: A young patient presents with loss of central vision. ERG is normal, but EOG is abnormal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the above scenario is Best's disease.

Best's disease/Vitelliform macular dystrophy is an inherited macular dystrophy in which lipofuscin accumulates in the central macula causing progressive central vision loss. It is autosomal-dominant and linked to the mutation in the bestrophin (VMD2) gene.

It is characterized by bilateral yellow, yolk-like (vitelliform) macular lesions.

The stages of evolution of the macular lesions are described as progressing from:

  • Pre-vitelliform stage
  • Vitelliform stage - scrambled egg stage with or without hypopyon
  • Vitelliruptive - the lesion breaks and visual acuity drops
  • The atrophic stage

Patients with Best’s disease usually have good visual acuity when the "yolk" remains intact.

Diagnosis: This is the only disease with relatively normal ERG results associated with an abnormal EOG. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) reveals that the vitelliform material appears as a dome-shaped, hyperreflective, and homogenous lesion, located below the hyperreflective photoreceptor layer.

The image below shows Best’s disease - the typical vitelliform lesion in an 11-year-old girl.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the lacunar ligament.

Lacunar (Gimbernat's) ligament - It is a thick triangular band of tissue formed from fibres of the medial end of the inguinal ligament and fascia lata.  It forms the medial wall of the femoral canal. The apex of the triangle is attached to the pubic tubercle.

Inguinal (Poupart’s) ligament - The thick external oblique aponeurosis stretched between ASIS (anterior superior iliac spine) and pubic tubercle. 

Pectineal (Astley-Cooper's) ligament - A strong fibrous band that extends laterally along the pectineal line from the pectineal attachment of the lacunar ligament.

Conjoint tendon - It is a condensation of tissue that runs through the lateral edge of the lower rectus sheath. It is formed from the common aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle and transverse abdominis muscle. The fibers turn inferiorly and insert into the crest of the pubis at the pectineal line immediately deep to the superficial inguinal ring.

questions.text: A blood sample is drawn on day 20 of the menstrual cycle of a young woman undergoing evaluation for irregular menstruation. Serum level of which of the following hormones help in assessing whether her cycle was ovulatory or not?
questions.solution:
Whether her cycle was ovulatory or not can be validly assessed by the reported serum level of progesterone.

Day 20 usually corresponds to the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. In case of anovulatory cycles, no corpus luteum will be formed and so progesterone levels will be low. Hence progesterone levels are valuable to predict if the cycles were ovulatory or not.

questions.text: In Guillain-Barre syndrome due to antecedent infection with Campylobacter jejuni, the autoantibodies are most commonly directed against which of the following?
questions.solution:
Autoantibodies in GBS due to Campylobacter jejuni infection are directed most commonly against GM1 gangliosidase.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in Guillian Barre syndrome

Type Antibody
AIDP Anti GM1
AMAN Anti GD1a
AMSAN Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b
  • AIDP-Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy 
  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy

questions.text: You prescribe an antibiotic course for a patient following cesarean section. What advice would you give regarding breastfeeding?

choices.text: No advice as most of drug are not present in breast milk
Avoid breastfeeding during the antibiotic course
Medications to be taken 3-4 hours before next feeding

questions.solution:
If the lactating mother needs to take medications that are deemed safe, the optimal dosing time should be 30-60 minutes after nursing and at least 3-4 hours before the next feeding.

A minimum interval of 3-4 hours allows time for partial clearance of the drug. This ensures the infants are not exposed to the peak maternal plasma concentration that may translate to higher levels secreted into milk. 

Other options: 

Option A: Most drugs administered are detected in breast milk, but most of them are excreted in very small quantities that do not cause any effect in the infants. 

Option B: Breastfeeding should not be avoided altogether for all medications. Intake of cytotoxic agents and immunomodulatory agents are contraindications for breastfeeding. 

Option D: The timing of medication should preferably be at an interval where the infants are not exposed to higher maternal plasma concentrations.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever, intermittent abdominal pain, and burning micturition. He gives a history of swimming in a freshwater lake 10 days back. Urine microscopy shows the following. Which of the following is the causative agent?

choices.text: Schistosoma species cannot be determined based on egg

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and image showing an egg that is non-operculated with the terminal spine at one pole are suggestive of infection with Schistosoma hematobium.

Species differentiation of schistosoma can be done based on the location of the spine as follows:

  • Terminal spine- Schistosoma hematobium
  • Lateral spine- Schistosoma mansoni
  • Rudimentary lateral spine- Schistosoma japonicum

The image below shows egg of Schistosoma mansoni. Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein.

Adult worms of S. japonicum live in the superior mesenteric vein draining the ileocecal region. They are also seen in the intrahepatic portal venules and hemorrhoidal plexus of veins.

The image below shows an egg of Schistosoma japonicum.

 Adult worms of S. hematobium live in the vesical and pelvic plexus of veins.

 The below image shows the life cycle of S.hematobium:

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman is rushed to the ER following a seizure. She is a known case of epilepsy but is non-compliant with her medications. Her lab values are given below. All of the following drugs can cause this presentation except:

Hemoglobin - 10g/dl

MCV - 110 fL

MCH - 40 pg

MCHC - 34 g/dl
questions.solution:
This patient likely has folate deficiency secondary to the use of an anti-folate anti-convulsant drug. Lamotrigine has no effect on folate metabolism and does not cause its deficiency.

The following anticonvulsants have anti-folate properties: 

  • Phenytoin
  • Barbiturates (amobarbital)
  • Primidone 

Folate deficiency causes megaloblastic macrocytic anemia which results in the following findings in RBCs:

  • Anemia (low Hb = 10g/dl)
  • Macrocytic (high MCV = 110 fl)
  • Hyperchromic (high MCH = 40 pg)

questions.text: An epidemiologist is assessing an outbreak of acute diarrhoeal disease in a region. He wants to predict the virulence of the causative agent. Which of the following parameters will he use for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Case fatality rate is used in this scenario as it is the most useful parameter to predict the virulence of an acute illness. It represents the killing power of disease.

Note:

Case fatality rate is an incidence proportion and not a true rate as no time interval is used for its calculation.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: You notice your senior resident performing the following test in a patient with an acute painful knee. Identify the test.
questions.solution:
The test shown in the image is the anterior drawer test. This is done to detect injuries to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).

The patient is made to lie supine on the examining table. The hip is flexed to 45° and the knee is flexed to 90° with the foot flat on the examination table. The upper end of the tibia is held in both hands and is gently pulled anteriorly. Increased displacement compared to the normal knee indicates injury to the ACL.

Lachman test is also done to detect injuries to the anterior cruciate ligament. Here the leg is in slight external rotation and the knee is in a mid-flexed to 20° position. One hand is placed to stabilize the femur, while another hand applies the anterior force to the proximal tibia, as shown below.

Apley's grinding test and McMurray's test are done to detect meniscal injuries.

questions.text: You are a surgery resident evaluating a 45-year-old female patient with complaints of burning abdominal pain for the past 2 months that is relieved on taking food. You determine the disease to have a bacterial etiology. Which of the following is the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario of a patient with dyspepsia and burning pain that is relieved on eating is suggestive of a duodenal ulcer caused by Helicobacter pylori. The urea breath test is the next step in her management for the preliminary diagnosis of Helicobacter pylori infection.

To perform this test, the patient drinks a urea solution labelled with radioactive carbon-14. The patient then blows into a tube. If H. pylori urease is present, the urea is hydrolyzed, and labelled carbon dioxide is detected in breath samples. The sensitivity of the urea breath test is >90%.

Other tests done for H. pylori: 

  • Invasive tests: The sample for these tests is obtained after an endoscopy. Tests include tissue samples for histopathology and gram staining, cultures, and a biopsy urease test. These all have a high sensitivity for H. pylori. 
  • Non-invasive tests: This includes tests for H.pylori such as stool antigen, urea breath test (simple test that can be performed on an outpatient basis) and H.pylori serology. Theyre not as sensitive as the endoscopic tests but are suitable for ruling in disease.

questions.text: In individuals with a history of substance abuse and addiction, the marked structure is believed to trigger cravings on exposure to environmental cues. Which of the following is not true about the structure?

choices.text: It forms the base of the sylvian cistern
It lies between the frontal and temporal lobe
It receives somatosensory inputs from the entire body

questions.solution:
The structure marked by the arrow is the insular lobe. The insular cortex is not entirely agranular. The posterior part of the insular cortex is granular and the anterior part is agranular.

The insula forms the base of the Sylvian cistern and lies between the frontal and temporal lobes. It receives somatosensory, viscerosensory, homeostatic, and nociceptive information from the entire body. It receives inputs from the thalamus.

questions.text: A patient with Crohn's disease has multiple skip lesions in the intestine. Surgical resection of damaged areas is being planned. Removal of which part will cause steatorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Ileal resection may lead to steatorrhoea.

The ileum is the only site of absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts. Following resection of the ileum, the loss of bile salts increases and is not met by an increase in synthesis. Depletion of the bile salt pool results in fat malabsorption that presents with steatorrhea.

The efficiency of water absorption in the jejunum is 44% and in the is ileum 70%. Resection of ileum causes reduced conservation of fluid. Loss of bile salts into the colon affects colonic mucosa, causing a reduction in salt and water absorption, which increases stool losses. 

Small bowel motility is three times slower in the ileum than in the jejunum. In addition, the ileocaecal valve may slow the transit. Resection of the ileum results in a significant enhancement of gastric motility and acceleration of intestinal transit.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a protective factor for diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
A higher intake of saturated fats is associated with an increased risk of diabetes mellitus.

Dietary factors that are protective for diabetes mellitus are:

  • Higher intake of unsaturated fatty acids
  • A minimum daily intake of 20g of dietary fibre
  • Exclusive breastfeeding

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was admitted with sudden, substernal chest pain radiating to his left arm. On examination, he was diaphoretic and dyspneic with an irregular pulse. Despite resuscitative measures, he died within an hour of admission. Autopsy revealed the following gross appearance of the interventricular myocardium. Which of the following microscopic changes is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing dead tissue are suggestive of myocardial infarction. It is characterized by coagulative necrosis.

In coagulative necrosis, despite cell death, the outline and architecture of the cells are preserved for a few days. This is because the cell injury is mainly due to the denaturation of all proteins, including the enzymatic proteins. This prevents the proteolysis of the dead cells. Ultimately, these necrotized cells are removed by phagocytosis and the lysosomal action of the enzymes of the leukocytes.

Examples of coagulative necrosis:

  • Ischemic injury in all organs, except the brain
  • Dry gangrene

questions.text: You are monitoring uterine contractions in a term primigravida in labor. You find that the contractions are uncoordinated and the frequency is about 8 contractions every 10 minutes. Which of the following is incorrect regarding your finding?

choices.text: It is common in nulliparous labour
Management includes wait and watch policy

questions.solution:
The given clinical finding is suggestive of uterine tachysystole. Oxytocin administration is not beneficial here as it leads to hyperstimulation of the uterus.

Tachysystole (hypertonic uterine dysfunction):

  • The uterine contractions are uncoordinated and increased in frequency (>5 contractions in 10 minutes)
  • Contractions occur with an increase in the baseline tone without rest in between them
  • It is associated with late active phase dysfunction i.e., when the cervix is almost 7 cm dilated
  • The most common cause is occipito-posterior position. Hence, a wait and watch policy is adopted
  • It is more common in nulliparous females
  • Oxytocin administration leads to hyperstimulation of the uterus and is not recommended.

Hypotonic uterine dysfunction:

  • Uterine contractions are inadequate
  • It is associated with early active phase
  • It is more common in nulliparous females.

questions.text:
A first-year psychiatry resident gets a call regarding one of his patients who has been brought to the ER with high-grade fever and pharyngitis. The patient was started on clozapine two weeks back for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. His oral examination reveals the following picture. What would be the appropriate management?
  1. Stop clozapine
  2. Reduce the dose of clozapine
  3. Administer granulocyte colony-stimulating factor
  4. Switch to another antipsychotic medication
  5. Give antibiotics
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of high-grade fever and pharyngitis and the simultaneous development of oral ulcers (image) in a patient on clozapine is suggestive of drug-induced agranulocytosis. The treatment is to stop clozapine immediately, administer granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF), and start empirical antibiotics.

Agranulocytosis is a rare, but fatal complication of clozapine. It is defined as an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) < 500/mm3, or white blood cell (WBC) count < 2000/mm3. It can initially manifest as a local infection with high-grade fever, sore throat, oral and perianal ulcerations.

These symptoms appear rapidly within days to weeks following initiation of drug therapy.

Clozapine is generally considered to be more effective than other antipsychotic drugs and is often used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia (poor treatment response to 2 or more antipsychotic drugs). Hence, a switch from clozapine to another (less effective) antipsychotic drug is not done in a patient with drug-induced agranulocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about visceral pain?

choices.text: It is mediated by B fibers

questions.solution:
Visceral pain is poorly localized, unpleasant and associated with nausea and autonomic symptoms. It often originates from thoracic and abdominal cavities, transmitted through small type C pain fibers. 

It often radiates (or is referred) to other somatic structures perhaps due to convergence of somatic and visceral nociceptive afferent fibers on the same second-order neurons in the spinal dorsal horn that project to the thalamus and then to the primary somatosensory cortex.

When pain is referred, it is usually to a structure that developed from the same embryonic segment or dermatome as the structure in which the pain originates. This principle is called the dermatomal rule. 

Example: the heart and the arm have the same segmental origin.

Feature

Aδ fiber

C fiber

Stimuli

Mechanical

Thermal

Polymodal

Myelination and tract

Myelinated and carried via Neospinothalamic tract

Unmyelinated and carried via paleospinothalamic tract

Conduction velocity

12–30 m/s

0.5–2 m/s

Impulse conduction

Fast component of pain 

Slow component of pain 

Neurotransmitter

Glutamate

Substance P

questions.text: Which interstitial lung disease is likely to be seen in a patient suffering from systemic sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) pattern of ILD is the most common pulmonary manifestation in systemic sclerosis.

The CT scan of NSIP shows ground-glass opacities. It responds to steroids given along with azathioprine or cyclophosphamide.

Other connective tissue diseases associated with ILD:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Sjögren syndrome
  • Dermatopolymyositis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text:
A young woman is rushed to ED due to wheezing and gasping for breath. She is unable to speak in full sentences. Her husband reports that she has had a cough with fever for 3 days. On examination, PR- 121/min, RR- 32/min, and has cyanosis. Her ABG analysis and chest X-ray are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?

ABG analysis: 

pH- 7.48

PaO2- 64 mmHg

PaCO2- 32 mmHg

HCO3- 25 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of dyspnea, tachycardia along with the ABG analysis suggestive of respiratory alkalosis and chest-Xray showing hyperinflated lungs is pointing to a diagnosis of acute severe asthma. A history of cough with fever is indicating a probable respiratory infection to have triggered the asthma exacerbation. 

Features of acute severe asthma vs asthma with impending respiratory failure: 

Acute severe asthma Asthma with impending respiratory failure
Dyspneic, speaks in words Mute patient
Agitated patient Silent / confused patient
Heart rate > 120 /min, tachycardia Relative bradycardia
Pulsus paradoxus present Pulsus paradoxus absent (due to respiratory muscle fatigue)
Accessory muscles of respiration used Paradoxical breathing is seen
Loud wheeze throughout the respiration Silent chest
Peak expiratory flow rate < 40 ml/min Peak expiratory flow rate < 25 ml/min
Respiratory alkalosis Respiratory acidosis
Hyperventilation leading to low or normal PaCO2 Normal or rising PaCO2

Note: The X-ray is not showing the features of ARDS and pneumothorax, hence they are ruled out as the right options. 

Asthma is often under-diagnosed and under-treated, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. World Asthma Day is held annually on the first Tuesday in May to ensure availability of and access to effective, quality-assured medications. “Asthma care for All” is the theme for the 2023, promoting the development & implementation of effective asthma management programs in all countries.

questions.text: A man complains of bluish-black discoloration of the sclera and pinna for the last 6 months. Since childhood, his urine has turned black on standing, as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient with urine that turns black on standing and blackish discoloration of soft tissues (oochronosis) is characteristic of alkaptonuria. It occurs due to the excretion of homogentisic acid in the urine.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive condition due to the deficiency of homogentisate oxidase (also called homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase). The homogentisic acid in these patients is oxidized to benzoquinone acetate and polymerized to form black-colored alkapton bodies, which deposit in soft tissues like cartilage, and this phenomenon is called ochronosis.

In the following images, A shows normal urine and B shows urine from patients with alkaptonuria

Related Pearl: Amino acid Enzymatic Disorders and the Associated Enzymes

Enzyme defect

Phenylalanine hydroxylase

questions.text: In a patient with GDM complicating pregnancy, there was severe bleeding following the delivery of the placenta. On abdominal palpation, the fundus felt soft and later became hard on massaging. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, a soft uterus that becomes hard on massaging indicates an atonic uterus. Uterine rupture is a risk factor of traumatic PPH, not atonic PPH.

Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Thus, bleeding from the placental implantation site is not arrested.

GDM complicating pregnancy can cause macrosomia, which is a risk factor of this condition.

Risk factors for atonic PPH:

  1. Primiparity or grand multiparity
  2. Previous PPH
  3. Overdistended uterus as in multi-gestational pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia
  4. Precipitate labour
  5. Prolonged labour
  6. Uterine malformations
  7. Uterine fibroid
  8. Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin
  9. Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/ abruptio placenta
  10. Obesity
  11. Age >40 years

questions.text: A woman came with complaints of breast pain following surgery. Her MRI is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows curvilinear hypointense lines (arrows) in the left breast implant indicative of the collapsed shell floating in the silicone gel. This is called the linguini sign that is seen in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant.

After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the fibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines.

Multiple hyperintense foci on T2-weighted images are sometimes found within the implant lumen. These findings are referred to as the salad oil sign or droplet sign.

Indications for breast MRI:

  • Screening for DCIS in high-risk patients
  • Evaluation of breast implants
  • Evaluation of breast scar tissue versus recurrent tumors.

Ultrasound is the preferred modality of imaging in suspected cases of extracapsular rupture. The snowstorm sign on USG is seen in extracapsular rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding positive health in today’s world?

choices.text: It is dependent on social, economic, and cultural determinants
It is a mirage because of changing environment
It means that the body and mind are at peace
It includes provision of free health camps by the government

questions.solution:
The provision of free health camps by the government is a concept of state medicine.

Health does not merely mean the absence of disease or provision of diagnostic, curative, and preventive services. It is a state of physical, mental, and social well-being. 

The state of positive health is based on the idea of perfect functioning of the body and mind. According to this concept, health is:

  • Biologically a state in which every cell and organ in the body is functioning at optimum capacity
  • Psychologically a state in which the individual feels a sense of perfect well-being and mastery over his environment
  • Socially a state in which the individual's capacities for participation in the social system are optimal

This concept is too idealistic and can never become a reality. Humans can never be so perfectly adapted to the environment because everything in our life is subject to change.

As the goal of positive health is unattainable, a broader concept of improving the quality of life has emerged. This highlights that positive health depends on medical action and also on economic, cultural, and social factors in the community.

questions.text: A patient has a ​blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below?
questions.solution:
The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 30 mg/min.

Calculation:

Step 1: Calculate total filtered glucose:

In this question,

  • GFR = 90 ml/min
  • Plasma glucose concentration = 200 mg/dL= 2 mg/ml (1 dL=100 ml).
  • Total filtered glucose = GFR X Plasma glucose concentration.

                               = 90 ml/min X 2 mg/ml
                               = 180 mg/min.

Step 2: Check transport maximum:

In the above question transport maximum is 150 mg/min.

Step 3: Calculate the excretion:

Excretion = Total filtered glucose - Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Maximum)

  = 180-150 mg/min
  = 30 mg/min

questions.text: The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for which of the following structures:
questions.solution:
The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium.

The costal margin, xiphoid process, and the mid-clavicular line are seen in this image. The examiner draws a laterally convex line that extends from a level below the 2nd costal cartilage (as clued in by the sternal angle) i.e., 3rd costal cartilage to about 3 spaces below i.e., the 6th costal cartilage. This line is about 1.2 cms lateral to the sternal edge. These suggest that the region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium.

The projection of the cardiac borders, of an average adult, onto the anterior thoracic wall forms a trapezoid.  This can be mapped out using the percussion method by looking for cardiac dullness. 

The varying heart borders and the corresponding surface markings are as follows:

  • Upper border: Slopes gently from the second left costal cartilage to the third right costal cartilage. It corresponds to the left atrium.
  • Right border: Convex to the right and runs from the third to the sixth right costal cartilages, 1–2 cm lateral to the sternal edge. It corresponds to the right atrium.
  • Inferior border or acute border: Runs leftwards from the 6th right costal cartilage to the cardiac apex which is located approximately 9 cm lateral to the midline, often in the left 5th intercostal space or level with the 5th or 6th rib. It corresponds to the right ventricle.
  • Left border or obtuse border: Convex laterally on the left. It extends superomedially from the cardiac apex to meet the second left costal cartilage about 1 cm from the left sternal edge. It corresponds to the left ventricle.

questions.text: You read a news alert that mentions a novel drug has received marketing approval for diabetes mellitus and that it has shown positive results in a pivotal trial. The trial it passed corresponds to which phase of clinical trials?
questions.solution:
Phase III trials are usually considered pivotal trials and are necessary for the approval of the majority of drugs. 

Phase III trials, also called multi-site, pivotal or effectiveness trials are done for 3–5 years. It is a large randomized double-blinded comparative trial performed on patients with the target disease. It aims at establishing the value of the drug as compared to the existing standard of care.  When the initial Phase III trials are complete, the sponsor (usually a pharmaceutical company) applies to the FDA for approval to market the drug. This application is called either a New Drug Application (NDA) or a Biologics License Application (BLA).

Note: In some drugs related to rare diseases or malignancies, phase II studies are considered as pivotal trials and the drug may be approved on the basis of phase II studies.

Related Pearl: Phases of Clinical Trials

Phase I

(First in human)

Phase II

(First in patient)

Phase III

(Multi-site trial)

Phase IV

(Post-marketing)

10 – 100 

50 - 500 

500 - 3000

Large or according to study

Usually healthy volunteers

Patients with the target disease

Patients with the target disease

Real-world patients

Open-label study

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Usually the observational or open-label

Human pharmacology and safety: To determine safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetic parameters

Therapeutic exploration and dose-ranging: To determine efficacy and dose-ranging

 

Therapeutic confirmation and comparison: Indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. Monitoring of adverse reactions is done. 

Postmarketing surveillance: To monitor drug interactions, compliance and long-term or rare side effects

Extends from months to 1 year

1–2 years

3–5 years

Unending, after drug approval

questions.text: A 44-year old previously healthy lady, presented with complaints of pain in both her ankles, knees, and elbows. On examination, a tender rash as shown below is noted. The chest x-ray showed bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image given shows erythematous shiny plaques over the shin, indicative of erythema nodosum. The characteristic triad association of erythema nodosum with bilateral hilar and right paratracheal adenopathies, with or without pulmonary infiltrates, and polyarthritis is known as Löfgren syndrome. (it is a type of acute sarcoidosis).

Arthritis in sarcoidosis is usually symmetrical; the ankles (>90% cases), knees, small joints of the hands or feet, wrists, and elbows are involved.

Erythema nodosum is the most common non‐specific lesion of sarcoidosis and the first manifestation of the disease but may not be present in all patients. It may be accompanied by fever, polyarthralgia, and uveitis.

Inflammatory markers are elevated in >80% of patients with acute sarcoid polyarthritis. Serum ACE level is usually increased, and rheumatoid factor is negative. 

It usually resolves spontaneously. Some require treatment is with oral corticosteroids. The prognosis is very good. 

Option A: Heerfordt Syndrome is a rare presentation of sarcoidosis and is characterized by the presence of parotid gland enlargement, facial palsy, anterior uveitis, and fever.

Option B: Tuberculosis generally does not show bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

Option D: Rheumatoid arthritis also presents with polyarthralgia and erythema nodosum. Rheumatoid factor is often positive without chest involvement.

questions.text: A middle-aged obese woman had elevated liver enzymes on routine follow-up. A USG showed grade 2 fatty liver. She is non-diabetic, non-hypertensive and has never consumed alcohol. Which of the following can be considered as a first-line pharmacological treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
An obese woman with grade 2 fatty liver in the absence of alcohol consumption is suggestive of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Vitamin E is considered as a first-line pharmacological treatment option for NASH in non-diabetics when diet and lifestyle changes have failed. 

Vitamin E is well tolerated and shows modest improvements in aminotransferase levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH. It is important to note that vitamin E must be considered only for non-diabetic patients due to cardiovascular risks with chronic vitamin E therapy.

Note: The FDA in 2024 has approved Resmetirom, a thyroid hormone receptor-beta (THR-beta) agonist for noncirrhotic NASH with moderate to advanced fibrosis.

questions.text: A microbiologist working with mycobacteria notes moist, smooth, flat, white colonies growing on Lowenstein-Jensen media. Which species of mycobacteria is she likely studying?
questions.solution:
The species of mycobacteria being studied here is Mycobacterium bovis. It forms moist, smooth, flat, white colonies on Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) media that break-up easily when touched. 

Mycobacterium bovis belongs to the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex. It causes tuberculosis-like disease in humans. 

Lowenstein–Jensen medium is a commonly used, egg-based, selective media for mycobacteria. It contains:

  1. Egg- Provides fatty acids and protein required for metabolism
  2. Malachite green- Prevents the growth of contaminants. Makes it a selective medium.
  3. Mineral salt solution- Buffer
  4. Glycerol- Source of carbon, favors growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis. LJ medium without glycerol, which contains pyruvate, is used for culture of M. bovis.
  5. L-asparagine- Nitrogen source

The image below shows M.bovis colonies on LJ media.

 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised and irregular with a wrinkled surface. They are creamy white or buff-colored, tenacious and difficult to emulsify(rough, tough, buff).

questions.text: You have witnessed your neighbor being bitten by a rabid dog. You should advise him to wash the wound with soap and water for a minimum of:
questions.solution:
Following dog bites, the bite wound should be washed with soap under running tap water for 15 minutes.

Local treatment of the bite wound is essential for the prevention of rabies and can reduce the infection rate by up to 80%. The following steps must be followed:

  • Cleansing: Washing under running water with soap or irrigation with a catheter in case of deep wounds
  • Chemical agent: Alcohol or tincture /0.01% aqueous solution of iodine or povidone-iodine is effective for inactivation of residual virus
  • Suturing: Must be done only following 24-48 hours if necessary, under the cover of rabies immunoglobulin locally and minimal stitches
  • Antibiotics and anti-tetanus measures when indicated

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has undergone a total thyroidectomy procedure and has been shifted to the post-op ward. 2 hours later she develops stridor and dyspnea, but her voice is normal. Which of the following vocal cord lesions is the most likely cause for her condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture of stridor and dyspnea with a normal voice is most likely due to bilateral abductor paralysis (B/L RLN injury). It is the most dangerous vocal cord lesion.

All the other options will have an abnormality in the voice. Normal voice is seen only in B/L RLN injury.  

In bilateral abductor paralysis,

  • Both the cords lie in the median or paramedian position, the airway is inadequate causing dyspnea and stridor. This may lead to death if untreated.
  • The voice is good.
  • Dyspnea and stridor become worse on exertion or during an attack of acute laryngitis.

Related Pearl: Various Vocal Cord Palsies

Type of palsy U/L Abductor B/L Abductor U/L complete B/L complete
Nerve RLN (left) Both RLNs RLN+SLN (left) Both RLN+SLN
Cord position Paramedian   |\ Both in  Paramedian   || Cadaveric   [\ cadaveric (intermediate) position [[
Voice Hoarse Good Hoarse Aphonia
Dyspnea - + - -
Aspiration - - +/- +
Treatment Wait & watch (palsy with least consequences) Tracheostomy, lateralization Wait & watch, medialization Tracheostomy + Epiglottopexy

Guide: \ is normal moving cord; | is paramedian; [ is cadaveric.

questions.text: A highway truck driver has presented with profuse rhinorrhea and sneezing. Which of the following drugs will you prefer to prescribe to him?
questions.solution:
The truck driver is suffering from allergic rhinitis and fexofenadine can be prescribed to him. This is preferred as it is a second-generation antihistamine having minimal/no sedative effects as it cannot cross the blood-brain barrier easily.

Pheniramine, promethazine, and hydroxyzine are first-generation antihistamines which should not be prescribed to drivers and heavy machine workers because they are lipophilic and cross the blood-brain barrier easily and cause sedation. 

Highly sedative first-generation antihistamines:

  • Diphenhydramine
  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Promethazine
  • Hydroxyzine

questions.text: A mammogram done for a 45-year-old female patient with a breast lump was reported as BIRADS category 0. What is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Category/score 0 in BIRADS suggests an incomplete assessment.

All breast imaging should be reported by BIRADS (breast imaging-reporting and data system).

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition % Chances of Malignancy Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Not applicable Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Essentially 0% Annual screening
2 Benign finding Essentially 0% Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding >0% but ≤2% 6 monthly mammograms for the next 2 years
4

 

4A: low level of suspicion for malignancy >2% to ≤10%

4B: moderate suspicion for malignancy >10% to ≤50%

4C: high suspicion for malignancy >50% to <95%

 Biopsy
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy  ≥95% Appropriate action should be taken 
6 Known biopsy-proven malignancy Appropriate treatment

questions.text: The following image shows which type of GI motility?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the migrating motor complex.

The image shows 3 phases: 

  • Phase I - quiescent period
  • Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity
  • Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity

This occurs during the inter-digestive period at intervals of about 100 min and passes in the aboral direction at the rate of 5 cm/min. Its main function is to clear intestinal contents and prepare for the next meal.

Option A: Peristalsis is a propulsive movement, which consists of a segment of contraction behind and relaxation in front.

Option B: Segmentation and mixing help in mixing intestinal contents with digestive juices and provides time for digestion and absorption.  

It consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward.

Option D: Basal Electrical Rhythm is fluctuation in the resting membrane potential of smooth muscle cells of the intestine as shown below.

questions.text: An outbreak of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection was reported in the surgical ward of a hospital. Which of the following precautionary measures would you recommend to best curb its spread?

choices.text: Administration of vancomycin empirically to all the patients
Wearing masks before performing invasive procedures
Washing of hands before & after treating the patients

questions.solution:
Among the given options, washing hands before and after treating the patients is the most effective way to curb the spread of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infections.

In addition to this, personnel with active S. aureus lesions and carriers should be excluded from areas having patients at highest risk for severe staphylococcal infections like newborn nurseries, intensive care units, operating rooms, and cancer chemotherapy wards. In such individuals, the application of topical antiseptics such as mupirocin to nasal or perineal carriage sites may diminish the shedding of MRSA.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following itchy cutaneous lesions to the OPD. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The skin lesion in the above image shows characteristic purple, flat, polygonal papules seen in lichen planus.

The lesions of lichen planus can be described as 5Ps — purple, polygonal, pruritic, plane topped (flat), papules.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke?

choices.text: No separate centres for stroke, DM and cancer
Implementation in over 10 districts in 5 states
Subcentre has facility for diagnosis and treatment

questions.solution:
District hospital has specialized facilities for the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS).

The NPCDCS has separate components for cancer and other non-communicable diseases like diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and stroke. It has been implemented in over 100 districts in 21 states.

At the subcentre level under NPCDCS, screening and referral are done.

Note: The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke(NPCDCS) has been changed to the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases(NP-NCD) to include new diseases and new health initiatives.

The new diseases included in the NP-NCD are: 

  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
  • Chronic Kidney disease
  • Asthma and Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • ST elevation myocardial infarction

questions.text: A primigravida with 38 completed weeks of gestation has gone into labor. Oxytocin was started to augment labor. The second messenger system through which oxytocin acts is _____
questions.solution:
The second messenger system through which oxytocin acts is the phospholipase C system.

It activates the enzyme phospholipase C which breaks down some phospholipids in the cell membrane into IP3 (phosphoinositol triphosphate) and DAG (diacylglycerol). DAG then activates protein kinase C and IP3 mobilises Ca2+ from mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum to bring about smooth muscle contraction and other cellular responses.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin

2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
