Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: Which of the following people would you not classify as a high risk contact of SARS-CoV2?

choices.text: A family member who lives in the same household as the patient
A doctor who examined the patient with a surgical mask and gloves
A passenger in the same bus as a symptomatic patient for 6 hours and the patient later tested positive
A sanitary worker who cleaned the linens of the patient

questions.solution:
A person traveling in the same environment and not having significant exposure to the confirmed case is not classified as a high-risk contact.

A contact of COVID-19 is a person living in the same household or having direct physical contact with the patient/infectious secretions without appropriate PPE or a person who was in a closed environment or at a distance of within 1 meter of a COVID-19 case.

High-risk contacts:

  • Touched body fluids of the patient
  • Had direct contact with the body of the patient during the physical examination without proper PPE
  • Touched or cleaned the linens, clothes, or dishes of the patient
  • Lives in the same household as the patient
  • Comes in close contact (within 1 meter) with the patient without necessary precautions
  • A passenger in close proximity with the symptomatic patient for 6 hours and the patient later tested positive


Low-risk contacts:

  • Shared the same space but does not have a high-risk exposure to the confirmed case.
  • Travelled in the same environment but does not have a high-risk exposure to the confirmed case.

questions.text: A mother brings her  3-year-old boy with the complaints that her child's urine smells like her tomcat's urine. She also gives a history of generalized seizures and perioral desquamating lesions. On examination, the child has global developmental delay and diffuse thinning of the scalp. Investigations reveal multiple carboxylase deficiency. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Biotin is the treatment of choice for multiple carboxylase deficiency.

Multiple carboxylase deficiency refers to one of two inherited defects of biotin metabolism. Tomcat urine is characteristically seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency.

  • Neonatal/infantile form is caused by a deficiency of holocarboxylase synthetase and presents in the first week of life with lethargy, poor muscle tone, and vomiting.
  • Juvenile/late form is caused by biotinidase deficiency and is associated with a slow but progressive loss of biotin in the urine, leading to organic aciduria. It is characterized by alopecia, ataxia, ketoacidosis, dermatitis, seizures, myoclonus, and nystagmus.

Both infantile and late-onset multiple carboxylase deficiency can be treated with pharmacological doses of biotin.

It is called multiple carboxylase deficiency because biotin is a water-soluble vitamin that is a cofactor for all 4 carboxylase enzymes in humans:

  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  • Propionyl CoA carboxylase
  • 3-methylcrotonyl CoA carboxylase

Note: 

Acquired deficiency of biotin may occur in infants receiving total parenteral nutrition without added biotin, in patients with prolonged use of antiepileptic drugs (phenobarbital, phenytoin, primidone, carbamazepine), and in children with short bowel syndrome or chronic diarrhea who are receiving formulas low in biotin. Excessive ingestion of raw eggs may also cause biotin deficiency because the protein avidin in egg white binds biotin, decreasing its absorption. Infants with a biotin deficiency may develop dermatitis, alopecia, and candidal skin infections. This condition readily responds to treatment with oral biotin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old truck driver presented with a painless ulcer in the genital area. On examination, a single ulcer with an indurated base was found. An image of the tissue section is shown below. Identify the staining method.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by Levaditi's method. Single painless ulcer with indurated base points towards a diagnosis of syphilis.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacillus. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Intrauterine transmission can lead to congenital syphilis. It shows corkscrew motility which can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. 

Treponema can be stained by silver impregnation methods. 

  • Fontana's method is used on smear
  • Levaditi's method is used for tissue sections

The clinical manifestations of syphilis include:

Primary syphilis: The typical primary chancre usually begins as a single painless papule that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, with a characteristic cartilaginous consistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer.

Inguinal lymphadenopathy is bilateral and may occur with anal as well as with genital chancres. The chancre generally heals within 4–6 weeks (range, 2–12 weeks), but lymphadenopathy may persist for months.

Secondary syphilis: The various features include mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions and generalized nontender lymphadenopathy. macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionally pustular syphilides. Other features of secondary syphilis include sore throat, fever, weight loss, malaise, anorexia, headache, and meningismus. Ocular findings associated with secondary (or later/ unknown-stage) syphilis include pupillary abnormalities and optic neuritis as well as the classic iritis or uveitis.

Latent syphilis: Early latent syphilis is limited to the first year after infection, whereas late latent syphilis is defined as that of 1 year’s duration (or of unknown duration). T. pallidum may still seed the bloodstream intermittently during the latent stage, and latent syphilis in a pregnant woman may infect the fetus in utero. 

Neurosyphilis:  The major clinical categories of symptomatic neurosyphilis include meningeal, meningovascular, and parenchymatous syphilis.

Cardiovascular syphilis: Cardiovascular involvement results in uncomplicated aortitis, aortic regurgitation, saccular aneurysm (usually of the ascending aorta), or coronary ostial stenosis.

Congenital syphilis: The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, anemia, jaundice,  thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

  1. Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL),
  2. Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy (RPR or VDRL)
  3. Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA)

Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: A middle-aged man who is a known case of diabetes and chronic bronchitis presents to the OPD with low-grade fever and productive cough for 5 days. Which of the following is not a virulence factor of the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes an acute exacerbation of COPD characterized by low-grade fever, increased cough, sputum production, and shortness of breath. The most common cause of these are non-typable H. influenzae which lack a capsule and so capsular antigen cannot be a virulence factor.

All H. influenzae have the following virulence factors:

  • Outer membrane proteins (OMP)
  • Lipooligosaccharide(LOS)
  • Pili

In addition to the above factors, H. influenzae type b also has its capsular polysaccharide as a virulence factor.

The differences between Hib and non-typable strains are given below:

Feature Type b strains Nontypable strains
Capsule Made of Ribosyl-ribitol phosphate Unencapsulated
Pathogenesis Invasive infections due to hematogenous spread Mucosal infections due to contagious spread
Clinical manifestations
  • Meningitis and invasive infections incompletely immunized infants and children
  • Epiglottitis
  • Cellulitis
  • Pneumonia
  • Otitis media in children
  • Exacerbation of COPD, 
  • Puerperal sepsis
  • Sinusitis
Vaccine Highly effective conjugate vaccines Not available

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated for chronic headaches, infertility, and galactorrhea. MRI of the brain shows the following finding.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and brain MRI showing a pituitary adenoma are suggestive of a lactotroph adenoma (prolactinoma). 

Pituitary adenomas are usually found in adults. The most common genetic alterations in this condition are mutations in G ­proteins (particularly GNAS). 

Depending on their size, they are classified as:

  • Microadenomas - diameter < 1 cm
  • Macroadenomas - diameter > 1 cm

They may be functioning or non-functioning. The most common type of functioning pituitary adenomas are prolactinomas.

The clinical features of prolactinoma include:

  • Due to mass effect - 
    • Features of raised intracranial tension
    • Visual field disturbances (bitemporal hemianopia) - due to compression of optic chiasm
    • Hypopituitarism - due to compressed hypophyseal stalk
  • Due to hyperprolactinemia -
    • Galactorrhoea
    • Amenorrhoea or oligomenorrhoea
    • Infertility
    • Loss of libido
    • Gynecomastia

Serum prolactin concentrations tend to correlate with the size of the adenoma. The normal range of serum prolactin is 5-20 μg/L. The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with a prolactin level >200 μg/L.

Related Pearl: Classification of Pituitary Adenomas with Associated Syndromes

The various types of pituitary tumors are listed in decreasing order of frequency:

Adenoma cell origin

Hormone

Lactotroph

Gonadotroph

Hypogonadism, mass effects, and hypopituitarism

Somatotroph 

GH

Acromegaly (adults)

Corticotroph

Prolactin, GH

Hypogonadism, galactorrhea, acromegaly

Thyrotroph

GH: Growth hormone

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone

questions.text: A middle-aged obese man is being evaluated at the sleep clinic. During his EEG recording, he is awake with his eyes closed. Which of the following waves will be predominantly seen?

choices.text: Predominant alpha waves with intermixed beta activity
Predominant beta waves with intermixed alpha activity
Predominant theta waves with intermixed delta activity
Predominant delta waves with intermixed theta activity

questions.solution:
In a normal adult awake patient lying quietly with his eyes closed, alpha waves are predominantly seen intermixed with a variable generalized beta activity.

This alpha rhythm is attenuated when the eyes are opened.

questions.text: Neostigmine is administered to a post-op patient to reverse neuromuscular blockade. What is its mechanism of action?

choices.text: It blocks the action of acetylcholine
It interferes with the action of choline transferase
It interferes with the action of choline acetyl transferase
It interferes with the action of acetylcholine esterase

questions.solution:
Muscle weakness is improved by neostigmine as it interferes with the action of acetylcholine esterase.

Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used mainly to improve muscle tone in people with myasthenia gravis, and also to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants such as rocuronium and vecuronium at the end of an operation. 

Inhibition of acetylcholine esterase increases the acetylcholine levels in the synapse that can act on receptors over the large surface area and for longer periods of time, reducing the weakness.

questions.text: Urine sample of a patient has been collected for analysis. How soon should it be analyzed?
questions.solution:
Urine samples should be analyzed within 2-4 hours after collection to avoid cell lysis and precipitation of solutes. If urine analysis is not possible in the given time, then the sample can be stored at 4-8 oC for a maximum of 12 hours.

Urine samples can be collected using the following techniques:

  • Midstream sample during spontaneous voiding
  • Fresh specimen from an indwelling catheter
  • Suprapubic needle aspiration of the bladder, especially in infants

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with fever, chills, and dysuria. On per-rectal examination, his prostate was tender and boggy. His PSA level was 7.4 ng/dl. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bacterial prostatitis and should be managed by antibiotics.

A rigorous and prolonged treatment for 2-6 weeks with an antibiotic that penetrates the prostate wall is indicated (trimethoprim, ciprofloxacin or aminoglycoside). Incomplete infection eradication lead to recurrent attacks and chronic prostatitis.

Acute bacterial prostatitis is usually caused by an ascending urinary tract infection (UTI) or reflux of infected urine into prostatic ducts. The most common organism is Escherichia coli. An associated increase in levels of PSA(>4ng/ml) may be present due to prostate inflammation.

Catheterization and prostatic massage are contraindicated in patients with suspected acute prostatitis, as they increase the chance for bacteremia and sepsis. Instead, suprapubic tap should be performed to alleviate retention.

Chronic bacterial prostatitis is the sequela of inadequately treated acute prostatitis.
Diagnosis includes: 

  • Three-glass urine test - If the first glass with the initial urine sample is clear, but the second and third samples contain prostatic threads and leukocytes, it indicates the presence of prostatitis.
  • Digital rectal examination - Prostate may be normal, boggy, or tender.
  • Prostatic fluid examination - post-prostatic massage fluid shows pus cells and bacteria.

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant woman at 11 weeks of gestation was diagnosed with falciparum malaria. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Quinine is the drug of choice for falciparum malaria during 1st trimester of pregnancy.

The treatment of falciparum malaria during pregnancy is as follows:

  • 1st trimester - quinine
  • 2nd and 3rd trimester - ACT-AL in North-Eastern states and ACT-SP in other states

questions.text: A primigravida was admitted to the labor room at 41 weeks of gestation for the induction of labor. What is the dose of misoprostol used for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Misoprostol (PGE1) is given as 25mcg 3-6 hourly vaginally or 25mcg 2 hourly orally for the induction of labor.

It is associated with the following side effects:

  • Uterine tachysystole
  • Meconium stained amniotic fluid
  • Uterine rupture

questions.text: Which of the following components is not seen in a Bain circuit?
questions.solution:
Bain circuit belongs to Mapleson's semi-closed breathing system, which lacks carbon dioxide absorber.

Components of Mapleson's system are

  • Breathing tube
  • Fresh gas inlet
  • Adjustable pressure limiting (APL) valve 
  • Reservoir bag

Carbon dioxide absorber (e.g. soda lime) is a component of the closed or circle system. This allows rebreathing of anesthetic gases after the removal of exhaled carbon dioxide.

Classification of breathing system

Bain's circuit with its components, fresh gas inlet, corrugated breathing tubes, APL valve and reservoir bag.

Circle system with its components, CO2 absorber, fresh gas inlet, an inspiratory uni-directional valve and inspiratory breathing tube, a Y-connector, expiratory uni-directional valve and expiratory breathing tube, APL valve and reservoir bag.

questions.text: A patient presents with the following intensely pruritic lesions that started 2 years back. History reveals that the lesions are more severe in winters and relatively milder in summers. Choose the incorrect statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: It is also known as eczema craquelé
It may occur due to zinc deficiency

questions.solution:
The above image showing dry, scaly eczematous lesions with a characteristic crazy-paving pattern (eczéma craquelé) is suggestive of asteatotic eczema. It usually develops in the elderly, not in children.

It affects the legs, arms, and hands of elderly people in the context of very dry skin. The condition is usually chronic, relapsing each winter and clearing in the summer, but eventually becoming permanent. 

 It may be a presenting sign of myxoedema. It can also be due to zinc deficiency.

Drugs implicated include:

  • Diuretics
  • Cimetidine
  • Topical corticosteroids

questions.text: A patient comes to the sleep clinic and the following pattern is seen on polysomnography. What type of breathing pattern is it?
questions.solution:
The breathing pattern shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes respiration. It is characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing, followed by a gradual decrease that results in a temporary stop in breathing called apnea.

It is caused by an increased sensitivity of the respiratory center to arterial PCO2. There is an apneic phase, during which arterial PO2 falls and arterial PCO2 rises. These changes in the arterial blood gas content stimulate the respiratory center, resulting in hyperventilation and hypocapnia, followed by recurrence of apnea. It is present in 40% of patients with advanced HF and usually is associated with low cardiac output.

questions.text: A 35-year-old presented with fever and ulcerated tonsils. His peripheral smear showed lymphocytosis. The Monospot test was negative. Tonsillectomy was done, and the biopsy showed the following picture. The larger cells were positive for CD20, EBVLMP1, MUM1, and CD79a and negative for CD15. Background cells were positive for CD3.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) positive diffuse large-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).

The histopathological findings show large cells with multilobed irregular nuclei. These cells are positive for CD20, CD79a, IRF4/MUM1, EBVLMP1. The smaller cells in the background are CD3+ which is a T-cell marker.

It is seen in the elderly (>50 years) and without immunodeficiency or prior lymphoma. 70% of the cases are extranodal and mainly affect skin, lung, tonsil, and stomach with or without LN involvement. 30% of the cases have LN disease alone.

Option A: This is not infectious mononucleosis as the monospot test is negative.

Option B: It is not Hodgkin lymphoma because it is positive for CD20 and CD79a and negative for CD15.

Option D: It is not EBV positive mucocutaneous ulcer as the patient is immunocompetent and it is strongly positive for CD20. 

Note: EBV positive mucocutaneous ulcer occurs in immunocompromised patients and reverts to treating the immunocompromised state. It shows polymorphous infiltrate and atypical large B cells with RS cell-like morphology admixed abundant T cells.

There is a uniform expression of CD30, MUM1, PAX5, OCT2. There is variable expression of CD20,CD45, CD15, CD79a, BCL6.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman who is taking OCPs presents with weakness and fatigue. Her laboratory investigations and peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 5 gm%

TLC - 1200 cells/mm3

Platelet count - 60,000/μL

MCV - 102 fl

MCH - 40 pg/cell
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anaemia due to the following reasons:

  • History of OCP use
  • Hemogram shows decreased hemoglobin and increased MCV
  • Peripheral smear shows anisopoikilocytosis, macroovalocytes, and hypersegmented neutrophils

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

Related Pearl: Features of Peripheral Blood Smear in Different Anemias

Heinz bodies (revealed by special staining),‘Bite’ cells

questions.text: According to the Japanese classification for gastric carcinoma, which of the following is the level 5 lymph node?
questions.solution:
Suprapyloric nodes are the level 5 gastric lymph nodes.

The japanese classification for gastric carcinoma (JCGC) staging system divided lymph nodes into 16 groups based on the likelihood of metastasis from the primary tumor and removal of lymph nodes during gastrectomy.

The surgery for gastric cancer involves the removal of the primary tumor and lymph nodes. Depending on the extent of lymph node stations removed, the surgery may be either  D1 or D2 gastrectomy. 

D1 gastrectomy involves the removal of lymph node stations 1-6. D2 gastrectomy involves the removal of lymph node stations 1-11.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the marked area in the image?
questions.solution:
The marked area in the image of the left kidney is related to the stomach.

The anterior relations of the right kidney:

Intraperitoneal
  • Right lobe of liver
  • Small intestine
Retroperitoneal 
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • 2nd part of duoednum  
  • Hepatic flexure of colon 

The anterior relations of the left kidney:

Intraperitoneal
  • Stomach
  • Jejunum
  • Spleen
 Retroperitoneal
  • Left suprarenal gland
  • Pancreas
  • Splenic vessels
  • Splenic flexure and beginning of descending colon

The posterior relations of the kidneys:

  • One vessel - subcostal vessels
  • Two ligaments - medial and lateral arcuate ligaments
  • Three nerves - subcostal, iliohypogastric, and ilioinguinal nerves
  • Four muscles - diaphragm, psoas major, quadratus lumborum, and transverse abdominis.
  • The right kidney is related to the 12th rib and the left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th ribs

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with a history of cholelithiasis was rushed to the casualty with complaints of vomiting, abdominal distension, and obstipation. On examination, high-pitched bowel sounds were heard. Her  X-ray erect abdomen is given below. Which statement is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is associated with Rigler's triad
Jejunum is the most common site of obstruction
CT scan is the investigation of choice
Enterotomy is done in the absence of strangulation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an X-ray showing gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) and multiple air-fluid levels indicating small bowel obstruction is suggestive of gallstone ileus. The distal ileum is the most common site to be obstructed in gallstone ileus because it tapers before entering the cecum.

Gallstone ileus is caused by the obstruction of the intestinal lumen by a gallstone, leading to a mechanical blockage. Big gallstones will not be able to pass through the normal cystic duct. This causes inflammation of the gallbladder and results in pressure necrosis. This in turn leads to biliary-enteric fistula formation.

Plain radiographs demonstrate air-fluid levels consistent with a small bowel obstruction. Rigler's triad is seen in gallstone ileus. It includes:

  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia)
  • Ectopic gallstone (Radio-opaque shadow in the right iliac fossa)

The investigation of choice is the CT scan. Pneumobilia is a ubiquitous finding because the fistula that permitted a stone to pass into the duodenum allows air into the gallbladder and the biliary tree.

Initial management involves keeping the patient nil per-oral, IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and analgesics. 

If there is no strangulation or peritonitis, it can be managed by:

  • Milking the stone beyond ileocaecal junction
  • Crushing the stone
  • Enterotomy to remove the stone

If there is perforation or strangulation, resection and anastomosis are done.

Cholecystectomy should be performed to avoid future complications. Fistula closure can be performed along with cholecystectomy or it can be performed later (two-stage procedure).

Given below is a plain X-ray of the erect abdomen showing air in the biliary tract (pneumobilia).

A large gallstone causing gallstone ileus is shown below.

questions.text: A patient has complains of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert's stain?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria. This organism is stained using Albert's stain which contains toluidine blue 'O' and malachite green. Both these dyes have an affinity for acidic cytoplasm as they are basic dyes.

Albert’s, Neisser’s, and Ponder’s stain are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules(Volutin / Babes Ernst granules) of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Corynebacterium diphtheria appears as green-coloured bacilli with purple-blue-coloured metachromatic granules in cuneiform arrangement.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl was brought by her parents with itchy blisters on her face and buttocks that developed quite suddenly. History revealed an episode of streptococcal pharyngitis 2 weeks ago that was treated with penicillin. Direct immunofluorescence microscopy revealed IgA deposition, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing linear deposition of IgA at the dermo-epidermal junction is diagnostic for linear IgA disease or chronic bullous disorder of childhood or IgA pemphigoid.

It is the most common immunobullous disease in infants and children. It may occur <5 years or at 60-65 years of age. It occurs in genetically susceptible individuals and can be triggered by drugs like vancomycin, penicillin, and NSAIDs. The main target antigen is BP180 or BPAg2. 

The classic triad of clinical features is:

  1. Tense blisters
  2. Vesicles
  3. Annular erythema

Onset is abrupt in children with involvement of the perioral and perianal regions. In adults, the extensor areas and trunk are affected. The blisters are arranged in an annular pattern. This is called the crown of jewels or string of pearls appearance, as shown below.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next?

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Immediate cesarean section is done as the first twin is in breech presentation. Uncomplicated dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies are terminated at 38 weeks of gestation. 

Timing of delivery depends on the type of twin pregnancy:

Type of twin pregnancy Timing of delivery
Dichorionic diamniotic 38 weeks
Monochorionic diamniotic 34 - 37 weeks + 6 days
Monochorionic monoamniotic 32 - 34 weeks by Caesarean section

 The mode of delivery depends on the 1st twin:

1st twin presentation Mode of delivery
Vertex Vaginal
Breech Cesarean section
Transverse Cesarean section

After delivery of 1st twin, if the 2nd twin is in breech, assisted breech delivery is done. If the 2nd twin is in a transverse lie, the internal podalic version is done under GA in the OT followed by breech extraction.

Complications in attempting vaginal delivery in non-vertex presentation (i.e) transverse and breech:

  • Interlocking of twins
  • Fetal head trapping above the cervix
  • Umbilical cord prolapse

According to ACOG criteria (2019), preeclampsia requires proteinuria of grade 2+ or more. In the case of pre-eclampsia, termination of pregnancy must be done at 37 weeks. According to the updated criteria, this patient does not have pre-eclampsia. Hence, a Caesarean section can be done at 38 weeks as for any uncomplicated DCDA twin pregnancy.

questions.text: While evaluating a patient with secondary amenorrhoea, you administer her estrogen and progesterone. However, withdrawal bleeding is not seen. What is the likely site of lesion here?
questions.solution:
The absence of withdrawal bleeding after the estrogen-progesterone challenge test points towards a local endometrial lesion.

Estrogen–progesterone challenge test is indicated as an investigation in case of secondary amenorrhea. It depends on estrogen-primed endometrium being present in the uterus. 

Procedure:

  • Ethinyl estradiol 0.02 mg or conjugated equine estrogen 1.25 mg is to be taken daily for 25 days.
  • Medroxyprogesterone acetate 10 mg daily is added from day 15–25.
  • Alternately, one course of oral contraceptive pill is given and to observe whether withdrawal bleeding occurs or not.

Results:

  • If there is no bleeding, a local endometrial lesion is present such as uterine synechiae. This is to be confirmed by HSG or hysteroscopy.
  • If withdrawal bleeding occurs, the endometrium is responsive but the endogenous estrogen production is inadequate. Hence, the defect lies in the ovary, hypothalamus, or pituitary.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the pediatric OPD with clinical findings as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image reveals an infant with sparse and kinky hair. This, along with loss of developmental milestones and truncal hypotonia, strongly suggests a diagnosis of Menkes disease, which is caused by defective lysyl oxidase. 

Menkes disease results from a deficiency of lysyl oxidase co-factor i.e copper. This is due to a defect in the ATP7A gene, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Note :

  • ATP7A mutation: Menkes disease - X-linked recessive
  • ATP7B mutation: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: Patients with all of the following conditions have ER-positive and HER2-negative tumors except:
questions.solution:
ER-positive, HER2-negative status on immunohistochemistry is suggestive of the luminal type of breast carcinoma, which does not include secretory carcinoma. 

The ER-positive, HER2-negative molecular subtype (luminal type) commonly includes the following histological subtypes:

  • Well and poorly differentiated lobular carcinoma
  • Tubular carcinoma
  • Mucinous carcinoma
  • Papillary carcinoma

Secretory carcinomas are usually ER-negative and Her2/neu negative (basal type).

Related Pearl: Molecular classification of breast cancer

 

Molecular subtypes 

Receptor status

Histological subtypes

Luminal A type 

(most common, best prognosis)

Mutated gene- BRCA 2

ER/PR- +ve

Her2- -ve

Ki-67- 

<14% (low)

Lobular carcinoma

Mucinous carcinoma

Tubular carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma

Luminal B type (HER2/neu negative)

Mutated gene- BRCA 2

Her2- -ve

Ki-67- 

>14% (high)

Poorly differentiated, lobular-carcinoma

Luminal B type (HER2 positive)

ER/PR- +ve

Her2- +ve

variable

Mutated gene- TP53

ER/PR- -ve

Her2- +ve

Ki-67-

Basal type (Triple-negative)

Mutated gene- BRCA 1

ER/PR- -ve

Medullary carcinoma

Adenoid cystic carcinoma

Secretory carcinoma

Metaplastic carcinoma

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

Defining Features

ER-positive, HER2- negative

ER- negative

HER2- negative

~40-55% (Low proliferation)

Typical patient groups

Older women, men, cancers detected by mammographic screening

BRCA2 mutation carriers

Young women, BRCA1 mutation carriers, African American and Hispanic women

questions.text: The oral thrombin inhibitor which can be used for prevention of stroke in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation is?
questions.solution:
The oral thrombin inhibitor which can be used for the prevention of stroke in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation is dabigatran. However, it is contraindicated in patients with mechanical heart valves.

Option B: Ximelagatran is also an oral thrombin inhibitor, but it has been discontinued due to the risk of hepatotoxicity.

Option C: Lepirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor used mainly in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

Option D: Saxagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor used in the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image?

choices.text: The principle is to make eye emmetropic.
Image is real, inverted, and magnified.
It may be done even in patient's with a hazy media.

questions.solution:
The procedure is indirect ophthalmoscopy and its principle is to make the eye highly myopic. 

A convex lens is used, commonly +20D. The image formed is real, inverted, and magnified. It is used for assessing and managing retinal detachment and other peripheral retinal lesions. It may be done with hazy media because of strong inbuilt illumination.

Related Pearl: Difference between direct and indirect ophthalmoscopy

FEATURE DIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE  INDIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE
Condensing lens Not required Required
Examination distance As close to the patient's eye as possible At an arm's length
Image Virtual, Erect Real, Inverted
Magnification 15 times 4-5 times
Illumination Not so bright, so not useful in hazy media Bright, so useful in hazy media
Area of the field in focus About 2 disc diameter About 8 disc diameter
Stereopsis Absent Present
Accessible fundus view Slightly beyond equator Up to ora serrata
Examination through hazy media Not possible Possible

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with fever and earache. On examination, the tympanic membrane appears congested and bulging with a loss of landmarks. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
The scenario points towards a diagnosis of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM). Antibiotics form the mainstay of treatment in acute suppurative otitis media, and if the tympanic membrane is bulging, myringotomy should be done. 

Myringotomy is the procedure involving incising the tympanic membrane to evacuate pus. It is indicated when:

  • The tympanic membrane is bulging and there is acute pain.
  • There is an incomplete resolution despite antibiotics and the drum remains full with persistent conductive deafness.
  • There is persistent effusion beyond 12 weeks.

The FDA recently approved the Tula system to deliver local anesthesia directly towards the eardrum and painless placement an ear tube. This is indicated for patients six months of age and older, thus eliminating the need for general anesthesia in children for myringotomy procedures.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: On your neurology rotation, you come across Ashu, a 5-year-old child who presented with a 6-month history of ataxia, headaches, and vomiting. He was admitted to the ward for further evaluation. MRI scan showed a brain tumor with a combination of solid and cystic components. Biopsy findings of the tumor are shown in the image.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows condensed masses of glial filaments occurring in compact areas suggestive of Rosenthal fibers. The clinical features, MRI findings, and histopathology point towards a diagnosis of pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytoma is a low-grade astrocytoma tumor. It is the most common type of astrocytoma in children. These are classically found in the cerebellum (infratentorial) and the optic pathway regions.

There is usually a 3-6 month history of limb ataxia, secondary headaches, and vomiting. Mural nodule, a contrast medium enhancing nodule within the wall of a cystic mass is seen on MRI. 

The tumor has a low metastatic potential and is rarely invasive.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic woman presents to your OPD with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge and intense itching. What is the likely causative agent for her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of moniliasis and Candida albicans is the likely causative agent.

The risk factors for moniliasis are:

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obesity
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Immunosuppression
  • HIV
  • Pregnancy
  • Steroid therapy
  • Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Poor personal hygiene.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text:
Match the following methods of mosquito control to the appropriate examples.
Method of control Example
l.Biological control a.Larvicidal oil
ll.Genetic control b.Sex distortion
lll.Chemical control c.Source reduction
lV.Environmental control d.Barbados millions

choices.text: I – a, II – b, III – c, IV – d
I – b, II – d, III – c, IV – a
I – c, II – a, III – b, IV – d
I – d, II – b, III – a, IV – c

questions.solution:
The correctly matched methods of mosquito control are:

Method of control Example
Biological control Barbados millions
Genetic control Sex distortion
Chemical control Larvicidal oil
Environmental control Source reduction

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented with seizures. On examination, hypopigmented macules and facial angiofibromas were present. CT image is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows calcified subependymal hamartomatous nodules. The CT findings along with hypopigmented macules (ash-leaf macules) and facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) is suggestive of tuberous sclerosis. It is associated with renal angiomyolipoma and cardiac rhabdomyoma.

The image given below shows calcified subependymal hamartomatous nodules:

Related Pearl: Cutaneous lesions of Tuberous sclerosis

Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis presents in childhood with a triad (Vogt triad). The triad comprises of:

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.

The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.

Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.

Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients

Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman was diagnosed with papillary carcinoma thyroid. CT cuts from the middle mediastinum showed metastatic deposits. In this section, which of the following structures will not be visualized?
questions.solution:
The left recurrent laryngeal nerve will not be visualized in this section, as it is not present in the middle mediastinum. It is located in the superior mediastinum.

Related Pearl: Divisions and contents of the mediastinum

Major contents of thoracic cavity

    • Aortic arch
    • Left common carotid artery
    • Left subclavian artery
    • Brachiocephalic trunk
    • Right and left brachiocephalic veins
    • Superior vena cava (upper half)
    • Azygos vein near its opening into superior vena cava
  • Left recurrent laryngeal nerve
Inferior mediastinum Anterior
  • Thymus (inferior extension)
  • Mediastinal branches of internal thoracic vessels
  • Sternopericardial ligaments
Middle
  • Heart
  • Phrenic nerve
  • Tracheal bifurcation and bronchi

    • Ascending aorta
    • Superior vena cava (lower half)
    • Inferior vena cava
    • Pulmonary trunk and branches
    • Pericardiophrenic arteries and veins
Posterior
  • Thoracic aorta

questions.text: A 60 kg adult male has a haematocrit reading of 40% and a plasma volume of 3L. What is his total blood volume in L?
questions.solution:
His total blood volume is 5 litres.

Calculation:

Hematocrit is a percentage, as it is 40% which equals 40/100= 0.4.

(Normally, Total blood volume is 8% of body weight).

questions.text: An elderly woman with hypothyroidism presents to the ER with decreased consciousness, hypothermia, sinus bradycardia, and hypotension. Her family members reveal that she has not been taking her thyroid medications recently. Investigations reveal elevated TSH levels and reduced T3 and T4 levels. All of the following can be used in the treatment except:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of myxedema coma. Hypotonic IV fluids are avoided in the course of treatment of this condition. However, hypertonic saline is used.

Hypotonic fluids may exacerbate water retention and dilutional hyponatremia secondary to impaired renal perfusion and inappropriate vasopressin.

Treatment of myxedema coma includes:

  • Levothyroxine (T4) can be administered as a single IV bolus of 500 μg. Although further doses are strictly not required, it is continued at 50-100 μg/day.
  • An alternative mode of treatment is the IV administration of liothyronine (T3) or via NG tubes with doses ranging from 10-25 μg every 8-12 hours in case T4 to T3 conversion in myxedema is impaired.
  • Parenteral hydrocortisone should be administered to treat a condition of impaired adrenal reserve in profound hypothyroidism.
  • Hypertonic saline or IV glucose may be recommended for treatment.
  • External warming is indicated only if the temperature is less than 30oC.

questions.text: A 25-year-old marathon runner presents with complaints of joint pain and rashes over the face. She says the rashes appear on exposure to the sun. On physical examination, a butterfly rash is seen over her face sparing the nasolabial folds. Which of the following antibodies will you evaluate to screen this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The best screening test in this condition is to evaluate for the presence of antinuclear antibodies (ANAs).

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Antibody Prevelance % Antigen Recognized Clinical utility
Antinuclear Antibody 98 Multiple nuclear Best screening test; repeated -ve test make SLE unlikely
Anti dS-DNA 70 DNA(double stranded) High titres are SLE specific & in some patients correlates  with disease activity, nephritis & vasculitis
Anti-Sm 25 Protein complexed to 6 species of nuclear U1 RNA Specific for SLE; no definite correlations; most patients also have anti RNP 
More common in black & asians than white
Anti-RNP 40 Protein complexed to U1 RNA Not Specific for SLE; high titre associated with syndromes that have overlap features of several rheumatic syndromes including SLE;
More common in blacks and whites 
Anti-Ro( SS-A) 30 Protein complexed to hY RNA,
Primarily 60kDA and 52kDA		 Not Specific for SLE; associated with sicca syndrome, predisposes to subacute cutaneous lupus & to neonatal lupus with congenital heart block; associated with decrease risk of nephritis
Anti-La( SS-B) 10 47kDa protein complexed to hY RNA Usually associated with anti-RO, associated with decreased  risk for nephritis
Antihistone 70 Histones associated with DNA
(In nucleosome & chromatin)		 More frequent in drug induced lupus than in SLE

Sensitive prothrombin time (DRVVT)
Predisposes to clotting, fetal loss, thrombocytopenia

This is not a useful clinical test

(includes antiglutamate receptor)		 60 Neuronal & lymphocyte surface antigens In some series, a positive test in CSF correlates with active CNS lupus

questions.text: A patient who was started on treatment for glaucoma comes to the casualty with acute onset breathlessness. On auscultation, bilateral wheeze is heard. Which of the following drugs might have led to this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bronchial asthma which was most likely precipitated by timolol.

Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that reduces intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous formation. It precipitates bronchial asthma in susceptible individuals by beta-2 blockade.

Betaxolol is a beta-1 selective blocker that is used in glaucoma and has a lower propensity to precipitate bronchial asthma.

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin (PGF-2 alpha) analog and does not precipitate bronchial asthma. 

Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and does not precipitate bronchial asthma.

questions.text: You are studying the literacy rate of a community with a total population of 10000. Out of these, there are 2000 children from 0-6 years of age, and 4000 literate individuals above 7 years of age. What is the effective literacy rate of this population?
questions.solution:
The effective literacy rate of this population is 50%. 

It is calculated as follows,

Effective literacy rate = (Number of literate persons aged 7 and above x 100) / population aged 7 and above in a given year. 

In the given scenario, people aged 7 years and above = 10000 - 2000 = 8000. Out of these 8000 people, 4000 are literate.

Thus, effective literacy rate = 4000 x 100/8000 = 50%.

Related Pearl: Literacy Rates

Literacy rate

  • The literacy rate in India currently is 74.04%
  • According to the 2011 census, Kerala has the highest literacy rate among Indian states with a value of 93.91%

questions.text: Thirty minutes after a blood transfusion is started, a patient develops chills and severe flank pain. Her temperature is 102.4 F, SpO2 is 96%, and her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. She then begins bleeding around her IV catheter site. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR). 

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

questions.text:
Which of the following are true for a screening test?

1) Done on apparently healthy

2) Applied to individuals

3) Time-consuming

4) Relatively inaccurate results

5) Based on one criterion/ cut off
questions.solution:
Screening tests are done on apparently healthy individuals, the results of the test are relatively inaccurate, the tests are based on one criterion.

The difference between screening and diagnostic tests is given below:

Screening test Diagnostic test

Done on apparently healthy

Done on patients with signs and symptoms

Applied to groups

Applied to single patients

Based on one criterion or cut-off point

Based on evaluation of a number of symptoms, signs, and laboratory findings

Less accurate

More accurate

Less expensive

More expensive

Not a basis for treatment

Used as a basis for treatment

The initiative comes from the investigator or agency providing care

The initiative comes from a patient with a complaint

Screening tests are recommended in the following conditions:

  • Early diagnosis changes the disease course
  • In a disease with an asymptomatic stage
  • In a disease with a test for diagnosis and treatment
  • The natural history of the disease is well known

questions.text: Matching is done for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Matching helps only in removing the known confounding factors.

Matching is the process by which controls are selected in a way that they are similar to cases in certain pertinent variables (e.g., age) that are known to influence the outcome of the disease. If not adequately matched for comparability, these variables could confound the results.

questions.text: An intern asks for your advice regarding the disposal of needles from the needle tip cutter after a vaccine drive. Which of the following bins will you advise her to discard them in?
questions.solution:
Waste sharps including metals (both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps) are to be discarded in the white bin.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows Kocher’s thyroid dissector which is used during a thyroidectomy to dissect the upper pole of the thyroid.

The instrument is blunt and therefore damage to the superior thyroid artery or external laryngeal nerve is unlikely.

questions.text: A male patient who is suffering from a psychotic disorder is on antipsychotic, antidepressant and antihypertensive treatment. He suddenly developed tachycardia and chest tightness. On evaluation he had metabolic acidosis. ECG showed widened QRS complex and prolonged QT interval. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of torsades de pointes. Only amitriptyline causes this condition, among the above drugs.

Torsades de pointes (French: twisting of points) is a life-threatening form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline on ECG.

questions.text: The illustration below shows alternative splicing of a gene which has intron segments 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. It yields two products A and B, by the action of different promoters. You are provided with the promoters w, x, y, and z, each of which binds to a different segment as shown below and acts in the marked direction. Which of the following promoters will you use to get product A?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, using primers W and Y will yield the desired product A.

Promoters or DNA regulatory elements usually precedes the desired exon to be transcribed. It helps redirect transcription of only the desired exons of a gene to yield a product. Alternative splicing utilizes different promoters to code slightly different products from the same gene. 

In this question, the desired product A has segments 1,3,4,5 whilst the other product B has 1,2,4,5. The difference between both is the presence of seg 3 in product A and the presence of seg 2 in product B. As the product in question is A, only seg 3 is required while excluding seg 2 and ensuring seg 1,4 and 5 intact.

  • Seg 1- Needs to be transcribed and so W is essential
  • Seg 2- Does not need to be transcribed.
  • Seg 3- Needs to be transcribed and so Y is essential
  • Seg 4- Needs to be transcribed but Z is not essential as Y continues the transcription in the direction shown by the arrow. 

The answer is hence promoter W and Y.

questions.text: Chest X-ray of a 60-year-old woman with dyspnoea at rest revealed right-sided pleural effusion. A pleural fluid analysis was done. Which of the following findings would rule out a transudative cause?
questions.solution:
High protein content in the pleural fluid would rule out a transudative cause. In a transudative effusion, the fluid has low protein content, little or no cellular material, and low specific gravity.

It is essentially an ultrafiltrate of the blood plasma. It is produced as a result of osmotic or hydrostatic imbalance across the vessel wall. There is no increase in vascular permeability.

The table below gives the differences between transudative and exudative effusion.

Features Transudate Exudate
Process Passive (increased pressure) Active (inflammation)
Vascular permeability Normal Increased
Plasma protein leak Absent Present
Protein content of fluid

Low S.G<1.012

Low protein

High S.G>1.020

High protein
Fibrin Absent Present
Inflammatory cells Absent Present

 

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient comes to you with the following lesions. He tells you that he used to develop similar lesions since childhood but they always heal without scarring. His father also suffers from a similar condition. Which protein is defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and the image showing superficial blisters are suggestive of epidermolysis bullosa simplex, which is an autosomal dominant condition associated with a defect in K5/K14 proteins. 

Epidermolysis bullosa congenita is a group of congenital mechanobullous disorders that arise after trauma and are common over the hands, feet, elbows, and knees. There are three forms of this condition.

Type Defective protein

Features
Epidermolysis bullosa simplex K5/K14

Intraepidermal blister with split in basal layer

Heals without scarring
Junctional epidermolysis bullosa Laminin

Dermoepidermal junction blister with split in lamina lucida layer

Perioral involvement is  frequent

May heal with scarring
Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophica Collagen VII in anchoring fibrils

Subepidermal tense blisters with defect in sublamina densa

Frequent mucosal involvement

Heal with scarring

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady, a known case of chronic osteoarthritis of the hip, has a trivial fall while climbing the stairs. Her right lower limb is in slight external rotation. X-ray pelvis is shown below. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and X-ray are suggestive of right-sided fracture neck of femur, Garden stage IV. Since the patient is >65 years with existing arthritis, the best choice of treatment is total hip arthroplasty.

In the absence of arthritis, fracture neck of femur in patients >65 years, is treated by hemiarthroplasty.

The image given below shows total hip arthroplasty done for fracture neck of femur.

Related Pearl: Treatment of fracture neck of femur

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a painless palpable lump in her left breast. She had sustained a traumatic blow to her left breast 1 month back. Mammography showed a radiolucent cystic lesion with rimmed calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The typical history of a breast lump following trauma and mammography findings of a radiolucent cystic lesion with rimmed calcification suggests a diagnosis of fat necrosis.

About half the affected women with fat necrosis of the breast have a history of breast trauma or previous surgery. It can present as a painless palpable mass, skin thickening or retraction, or mammographic densities or calcifications.

Histologically, necrotic adipose tissue with foamy macrophages, multinucleated giant cells, and chronic inflammatory cells are seen often with hemosiderin deposits, fibrosis, and calcification.

The following image shows an area of fat necrosis within breast tissue.

Note: Calcifications are seen on mammography in the following conditions -

  • Apo­crine cysts
  • Hyalinized fibroadenomas
  • Sclerosing adenosis
  • Duct ectasia 
  • Breast carcinoma- shows irregular densities and small, numerous, clustered calcification (microcalcifications).

questions.text: An infant with hydrocephalus is found to have pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly. On further investigations, he is also found to have rugger-jersey spine on X-ray. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the infantile form of osteopetrosis. It is characterised by decreased osteoclastic activity due to defect in carbonic anhydrase ll proton pump.

The excessive new bone formation with defective resorption leads to abnormal development of the skull, especially causing narrowing of the foramina of the skull. This leads to various complications like hydrocephalus, cranial nerve compression leading to deafness and facial palsy, sinus blockage, etc. 

Failure of bone resorption results in poorly formed medullary cavity. This leads to defective hematopoiesis in the medullary cavity and stimulation of extramedullary hematopoiesis. Hence, the infant presents with pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly.

Abnormal bone density may also lead to altered vasculature causing complications like osteitis of the mandible.

Excess bone density also leads to endobone appearance and rugger jersey appearance of vertebrae on radiograph. X-ray spine of a patient with osteopetrosis is given below.

Renal osteodystrophy also shows rugger jersey appearance of vertebrae on x-ray. However, renal osteodystrophy is a complication of chronic kidney disease and the patient is an infant. So the likely answer in the patient in the given scenario is osteopetrosis (Option B).

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presented with sudden onset descending paralysis and blurred vision  3 days after the intake of canned food. On examination, the patient has quadriparesis with areflexia. Both the pupils are nonreactive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of acute onset descending flaccid paralysis with a history of consumption of canned food is suggestive of botulism.

The incubation period from ingestion of contaminated food to the onset of symptoms in food-borne botulism is usually 8–36 h but can be as long as 10 days and is dose-dependent. The clinical syndrome of botulism consists of bilateral cranial-nerve palsies that may progress to respiratory compromise, a bilateral descending flaccid paralysis of voluntary muscles, and even death.

Cranial nerve deficits may manifest as some of the following:

  • diplopia
  • dysarthria
  • dysphonia
  • ptosis
  • ophthalmoplegia
  • facial paralysis and impaired gag reflex

The absence of cranial nerve palsies makes botulism highly unlikely, as does a lack of cranial nerve deficits at the onset of illness. Pupillary reflexes may be depressed and fixed or dilated pupils are sometimes noted.

The cornerstones of treatment for botulism are meticulous intensive care and administration of botulinum antitoxin.

Option A: In poliomyelitis, weakness is generally asymmetric, more proximal than distal, and may involve the legs (most commonly), the arms, or the abdominal, thoracic, or bulbar muscles.

Option C: Guillain–Barre syndrome is usually associated with ascending flaccid paralysis.

Option D: Tetanus causes spastic paralysis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with complaints of acute pain and swelling of the knee joint. He is reluctant to move the limb. Ultrasonography shows joint effusion. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of septic arthritis. The next best step is the aspiration of the joint fluid to confirm the diagnosis and identify the organism.

Empirical antibiotic therapy has to be started immediately after aspiration. It is not the first step as giving antibiotics would interfere with the identification of infective organisms from the aspirated fluid. Blood culture is positive only in a few cases and has very little diagnostic value. 

USG is the most reliable investigation to detect effusion at an early stage. MRI is reserved for infections in obscure sites like the sacroiliac or sternoclavicular joints.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was started on an antipsychotic drug that decreased his hallucinations significantly. Three days after starting the medication, he developed torticollis and orofacio-lingual movements. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has developed acute muscular dystonia (spasm of muscles of tongue, face, neck, and back) which is an extrapyramidal side effect of haloperidol. This occurs within 1-5 days of drug intake.

questions.text: What is the scientific name of this plant whose roots & leaves were historically used in the treatment of asthma?
questions.solution:
The above plant is Datura stramonium, also called Jamestown or Jimsonweed.

The active ingredient in Datura stramonium includes anticholinergic alkaloids such as atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. These were helpful in relieving the symptoms associated with asthma via inhibition of M3 receptors on bronchi, leading to a decrease in bronchospasm and tracheobronchial secretions. 

In India, the root and leaves of Jimsonweed were burned and the smoke was inhaled to treat asthma, though with great caution. Around the 1800s, British colonists observed the ritual and introduced the belladonna alkaloids in western medicine for the management of asthma.

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea
